PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the A.C.T. respectfully shows-
That X-rated videos denigrate true human values and lower community standards.
That the continued availability of this pornography is contrary to the wishes of the majority of Canberra people.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to take action to bring about the prohibition of X-rated videos in the A.C.T.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth:
1. We reject in principle the need for a national I.D. card on the basis that it will be a gross violation of individual liberty.
2. We reject the notion that the government can claim a mandate for the proposed legislation and state categorically it does not reflect our will.
3. We believe that, as with the proposed Bill of Rights legislation, the government's methods and arguments in promoting this legislation have been under-handed and undemocratic.

4. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and that its implementation will result in further attacks on individual freedom and responsibility, the family and the Church and that the real intent is the promotion of a powerful secular humanist ``big brother'' government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should together with the House of Representatives take action to reject this proposed legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Australia Card.

2. That this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security.

3. That we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life.
4. That we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Taxation Office and other departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Port Pirie Education Centre, South Australia: Restoration of Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. has for twelve years fulfilled a wide range of education needs among underprivileged and isolated rural people in the upper north of South Australia:
That the Federal Government's withdrawal of base grant funding will in effect cause the Centre to close at the end of 1987:

That Federal Government managerial incompetence is evident in deciding to cause the closure of the Centre at the same time as approving a Community Employment Program grant of approximately $50,000 to upgrade the Centre's grounds.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Federal Government will restore base grant funding for 1988 and beyond to ensure that the Port Pirie Education Centre Inc. can continue to provide its wide range of educational services to the people of the upper north of South Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable The President and members of the Senator in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to the state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government in recent months and the interaction between Social Security pensions and the above mentioned adjustment, your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to restore the pension base for the calculation of future adjustments and that the restoration be effected in conjunction with the Social Security adjustments in November 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charge for Directory Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We consider the Federal Government's decision to have Telecom charge for the cost of ``Directory Assistance'' inquiries will greatly disadvantage, the sick elderly and the handicapped.

Specifically, it will impose an unjustified financial burden on those with sight impediments and reading difficulties, such as the elderly. It will also disadvantage physically handicapped people and persons confined due to illness.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the government to:
Reverse its decision to have Telecom charge for ``Directory Assistance'' inquiries.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Medicare Agency: Rosebery, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the closure of the Medicare Cash Payment Agency in Rosebery, Tasmania on 31st March 1988 which will result in a loss of the cash reimbursement facility and direct representation from Medicare.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH ACT PRINCIPLESDEFENCE (PUBLIC AREAS) BY-LAWS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, I shall withdraw Business of the Senate notice of motion No. 1 standing in my name for three and four sitting days hence respectively for disallowance of certain National Health Act principles and Defence (Public Areas) By-laws. As I am withdrawing a notice of motion, I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, the health principles guide the exercise of official discretions determining nursing home fees. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances sought advice on appeal procedures. The Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) has assured the Committee that discretionary powers are to be progressively eliminated as a new uniform fee system is introduced. A transitional appeal mechanism is in place involving State based fees review committees of inquiry. Secondly, the by-laws control access to certain Commonwealth land. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) has agreed to stipulate than only `wilful' acts of destruction or interference with flora, fauna or property will be punishable offences. For the information of honourable senators, I seek leave to incorporate the Minister's two letters in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Dear Bob

I refer to your letter of 27 October 1987 about the Financial Arrangements Principles for the determination of nursing home scales of fees which have been formulated pursuant to subsection 40aa (7) of the National Health Act 1953. I apologise for the delay in replying. I understand that in the absence of a reply before 20 November 1987, and as a precautionary measure, you have given notice that you would move a motion in the Senate on behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances that the Principles be disallowed.

You have raised questions concerning the use of discretionary power by the Secretary of the Department under the Principles and the appeal avenues open to nursing home proprietors affected by such decisions. In particular, you asked whether or not the discretionary decisions are subject to review by the AAT.

As you will be aware, the National Health Act (NHA) and the Nursing Homes Assistance Act (NHAA) were amended with effect from 1 July 1987 to authorise the phased introduction of new funding arrangements for all non-Government nursing homes for the aged. The arrangements applying prior to 1 July 1987 under the NHA provided for fees to be determined for each nursing home which reflected the home's actual operating costs, subject to a test of reasonableness exercised by the Secretary (or his delegates). Under an alternative arrangement for nursing homes operating under the NHAA, each home's net operating deficit was funded by the Commonwealth. The administration of these two cost reimbursement schemes was complex and depended heavily on the exercise of discretionary powers.

In contrast to this the new funding arrangements introduced from 1 July 1987 will gradually phase-in a system of national uniform nursing home fees where discretionary power will be gradually removed.

From 1 July 1987, the NHA provides for fees to be determined by the Secretary taking into account the formulae contained in Section 40ag. The Principles under Sub-Section 40aa (7) are designed to ensure that the formulae are fairly and consistently applied.

Under the formulae, the fees for all non Government nursing homes for the aged will be coalesced again using a fixed formula, to a national uniform level on 1 July 1991 in respect to infrastructure costs. When all existing nursing homes have had the infrastructure costs which they incurred up to 30 June 1987 assessed and validated by the Secretary, there will no longer be a need for the Secretary to exercise any discretionary power under the Principles in relation to the infrastructure component in fees. It is expected that this point will be reached during 1988/89.

In addition, on 1 July 1988 the government intends to commence the phasing-in of national uniform nursing and personal care staffing standards for nursing homes. Similarly, once the uniform staffing standards are fully in place (probably by the end of 1989) the Secretary will no longer need to exercise a discretionary power under the Principles in relation to the nursing and personal care component in fees.

Decisions flowing from the exercise of these powers are not subject to review by the AAT. Notwithstanding this, however, I wish to stress that there is an effective review mechanism available to proprietors who are dissatisfied with any decisions of a discretionary nature taken pursuant to the Principles.

When a scale of fees has been determined by the Secretary, compliance with that scale becomes a condition to which the approval of premises as an approved nursing home is subject (sub-section 40AA (6) (c) (i) of the NHA). The mechanism which provides for a Ministerial review of a nursing home's scale of fees is established by sub-section 40AE (2) of the NHA. It is appropriate to explain the effect of this provision in two parts, as amendments to it are proposed in the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987 which is currently before the Senate-

(i) In its current form, where the Secretary does not alter the conditions applicable to the nursing home (including fee levels) in accordance with a request by a proprietor, that proprietor may request the Minister to review the Secretary's decision. This review must be conducted in accordance with the Principles which were in force at the time the decision was made and which continue in force at the time of the undertaking of the review (unless the Minister is satisfied that it is not appropriate to apply any particular principle) (subsection 40AE (3A)).

(ii) Under the proposed amendments, where the Secretary makes any fees determination with which a proprietor is dissatified, that proprietor will be able to request the Minister to review the Secretary's decision. This review will be conducted in accordance with the Principles which were in force at the time the decision was made (subsection 40AE (3A)).

Under both the current and proposed arrangements, subsection 40AE (4) provides that before any Ministerial decision can be taken on review, the proprietor's request must be referred to the Nursing Homes Fees Review Committee of Inquiry, established under the NHA. There is a Committee established in each State. In making its report to the Minister, the Committee would have regard to the same Principles as the Minister is required to apply.

In the conduct of their examinations of requests for reviews, the Committees of Inquiry seek written submissions from the proprietor and the Department. In addition, the proprietor and representatives are afforded the opportunity to present their case orally to the Committee.

In addition to the review mechanisms on the merits through the Committees of Inquiry and the Minister, there is also judicial review available through the Federal Court. Once a decision has been made by the Minister, the proprietor of the nursing home may seek the review of that decision pursuant to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

Since the establishment in 1973 of the review mechanism in subsection 40AE of the NHA a significant number of proprietors have sought redress through it, with only a small minority subsequently appealing to the Federal Court about the decision taken on review.
Accordingly, in my view, there is a mechanism for an effective review of the merits of the decisions to arrive at a scale of fees taken under the Principles.

I trust that the information set out above is sufficient to enable the Committee to see fit to withdraw its notice of motion. Should you wish, I would be happy to arrange for an officer of the Department to meet with you to clarify any aspects of this matter.
Yours sincerely
Neal Blewett
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
10 December, 1987
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
