SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to debate notice of motion No. 3 cognately with notice of motion No. 4 standing in my name.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That new orders 12a, 12b and 12c and Section V of the Schedule contained in the Export Control (Fees) Orders as amended (Amendment), being Export Control Orders No. 17 of 1987 and made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

Notices of motion Nos 3 and 4 relate to the Export Control (Fees) Orders as amended (Amendment), being Export Control Orders No. 17 of 1987 and made under the Export Control Act 1982. That most complex wording relates to the imposition of a 15c per head fee imposed on the beef industry by this Government. Notice of motion No. 3 relates to the disallowance of that part of the order which specifically relates to the fee. It is my view that it is a valid notice of disallowance; it relates to part of an order. Those in the Minister's office, being from the House of Representatives and failing to understand the procedures of the Senate, have disputed that it is a valid disallowance motion. So, in order to secure myself, in notice of motion No. 4 I call for the disallowance of the whole order.

However, if the Government Minister at the table, the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), acknowledges that notice of motion No. 3 is a valid notice of motion to disallow, I will withdraw notice of motion No. 4 and there will be no need to put that vote to the Senate. But if the Minister is not prepared to agree to that, we will have to vote on both notices of motion.

Turning to the substance of this matter, Export Control Orders No. 17 is a component of what is called the integrated action plan on chemical residues found in the beef marketed overseas by Australians. This plan involves a national ban on DDT and other persistent organochlorine pesticides, such as dieldrin, in agriculture. In a Press release on 14 August, the Government announced that it would be upgrading the national residue survey, with annual expenditure increasing from $1.8m to $5.6m. The Government also announced that the industry would be required to fund 50 per cent of the national residue survey which previously had been fully funded by the Government. There was no consultation with the industry when the Government issued that Press release on 14 August imposing this fee on the industry. In a subsequent Press release just over a month later, namely, on 18 September, the Government announced not only that it was imposing the fee, but that it was imposing the levy of 15c per head to be applied retrospectively to 1 July 1987. So there was an announcement in August in which the Government said, `We are going to impose a levy', and in September it announced that the levy would be 15c a head and that it would be applied retrospectively to 1 July 1987.

The Liberal and National parties are opposed to the levy anyway, for reasons I will come to in a few moments, and they are totally opposed to the retrospective application of penalties. Although the national residue survey applies not only to beef-it applies to all meat, dairy products, eggs, honey, grain, grain products, fruit and vegetables-the levy is being applied only to livestock slaughterings. The livestock industry is the only industry required to fund the national residue survey between July and December 1987. There is no guarantee that this situation will change next year. We are all aware of the problems of the cattle industry at the moment, but it is our view in the Liberal and National parties that most of these problems are largely outside the control of the cattle industry. Chemicals were sold in Australia when their use was banned elsewhere and legislation was not properly policed. The matter certainly is very complex, so complex that we will be moving, probably later today, to set up a Senate committee to inquire as to the reasons for the problems the cattle industry currently suffers.

The industry has entered into an annual commitment of over $30m to fund mass testing of cattle carcasses. Clearly, the industry has satisfied its markets right around the world with its present testing procedures. To date, this testing has been funded by a non-statutory body-in other words, it is not imposed by the Government. These vendor levies have been imposed voluntarily but will be funded by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation's slaughter levies from April 1988, with government matching assistance sought but not obtained. We are aware that there are several hundred cattle properties already quarantined where residue violations have been reported and the livelihood of the producers has been removed. We are very concerned about these people, who are facing ruin as a result of these quarantining procedures.

We believe that the removal of the retrospective component of this levy is essential, that there needs to be a clarification of the role of the national residue survey and that there should be equity among all rural sectors encompassed by the survey. The cattle producers, supported by the sheep meat producers, seek adequate government consultation about these levies and cost-sharing arrangements for the total chemical residue testing program. For these reasons, the Liberal and National parties support the disallowance of the fees imposed by these orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do not support the disallowance motion moved by Senator Lewis, in spite of the fact that similar motions have been on the Notice Paper for at least a week in our name following representations from the livestock industry, particularly the Cattle Council of Australia, which raised the issues which Senator Lewis has clearly outlined, issues which go to what has been happening, particularly in the beef industry, subsequent to the discovery that we have a problem of chemical residues in our livestock industry. The problem was addressed very quickly, and the industry must be commended for having acted as quickly as it did. Of course, it had no choice but to do so because its livelihood was at risk in terms of our ability to persuade our major trading partners that we could handle the problem, that we could clean up the residue where it was found to exist and that we could institute testing regimes, both here and in the importing countries, which would guarantee the quality of the product.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an established fact that the industry has done that responsibly, and at great expense to itself, but we must not forget that today we are being asked to disallow export orders which are critical to that very export, which the industry itself has done so much to guarantee, and which enable that export to be continued in the face of a particularly difficult problem. In the view of the Australian Democrats, to so disallow would be to take the extraordinary risk of sending out signals which could be interpreted as indicating a moving away from the current position which the cattle industry has been in and has taken-that of the responsibility for the maintenance of that export industry, again, at great cost to itself.

The reason the Australian Democrats have spent a good deal of time on this and have taken up the issue with the Cattle Council of Australia is that there is a great deal of justice in the points which the industry has made. In a sense, the proposal for disallowance is quite understandable because, in this instance, the national residue survey is being upgraded at further expense to the beef industry. That cannot be denied for one minute, and it is not denied. However, like all of the other systems that have been set up since this problem came to notice, at this point there is no alternative simply because the national residue survey has been a considerably important issue in negotiations that have taken place for the maintenance of our beef exports. This upgrading is a requirement, certainly in the case of the United States, for the continuing export of our meats to that country at least. I am quite sure that any perception that there was not a commitment to this in Australia would destabilise that market, if not the Japanese and other significant markets.

However, that does not get us very far in terms of the beef industry. It is critical that the cost of the national residue survey specifically and costs associated with the responsible attitude of the beef industry be spread more widely, and as soon as possible. Already the Government takes on a 50 per cent share of the funding, I assume on behalf of the rest of the community, but in the primary industry sector the burden is being borne specifically by the livestock industry. At the beginning of next year other commodity groups will become co-funders, with the livestock industry, of the upgraded national residue survey. In the view of the Australian Democrats, that will inject some justice into that process.

It is worth noting that the national residue survey is separate from the intensive testing of organochlorines, which is 100 per cent industry funded. We need to stress again that in this context the industry is bearing an enormous burden, but I suggest that is nothing to the burden which it would bear if what we do in this place sends out these sorts of signals to our trading partners, which quite clearly would be the result of this action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you put the notice of motion down?

—As I have already explained to the Senate, the notice of motion was put down by the Australian Democrats from the point of view that there are genuine concerns and genuine points of justice that need to be aired on behalf of the beef industry. It is important that we look not just at what the industry has done so far, as Senator Lewis has pointed out, but also at what the Government has done so far so that we can have a clear picture of what can be done in the future. The cost of residue testing in the USA is an additional cost that has to be taken into account. The cattle industry is spending $550,000 a week on residue testing and the recouping of levies of $350,000 leaves an enormous debt in that industry.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the issues that have been raised with us is what happens to those hundreds of farms and properties which are at the moment being isolated and quarantined, again on a voluntary basis responsibly by the industry. I think it is important that we recognise that those people have been encouraged to take what action they can if it is a matter of going to the wall, and in some instances it certainly is, and they have been encouraged to take up their cases under the rural adjustment scheme. From consultations that I have had some people are reluctant to do that, and I can understand that reluctance in an industry which has worked very much on a self-help basis. I suggest that we recall the remarks of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) who, of course, is responsible for the administration of the rural adjustment scheme, when he said last week on the National Farm Report that if independent producers are experiencing hardship because of this issue they should be encouraged to take it up under the rural adjustment scheme. As I said, I understand that people have hesitated to do that, and I believe they should not, because this is an industry in trouble. It may not be one which is recognised as being in as deep trouble as perhaps the grain industry, but I am sure that on an individual basis there is assistance available for those people.

During this week of consultation with me, the beef industry-Senator Lewis referred to this-raised the lack of consultation in this issue. I think we have to look at that complaint-which is what I would term it-which the cattle industry has brought to me at least, and obviously to Senator Lewis, and see what has happened. There is a clear indication from the Australian Agricultural Council that there has been ongoing work in consultation amongst a variety of groups and organisations. The 126th special meeting, which was held in Canberra on 5 June, I think made great strides in that process. It decided: `to implement a mandatory trace-back system . . .; `to establish an extension task force to develop and implement as quickly as possible a program aimed at the proper use of agricultural and veterinary chemicals'; and agreed to a standing committee of the Australian Agricultural Council to seek representation `on the following task forces . . . which have been established by industry'. So there was a direct decision, subsequently implemented, for the industry task forces and the Agricultural Council to work together.

I think we should note what these task forces are and what they are doing. First of all there is the legislation task force. The report of its meeting was before the Senate a couple of weeks ago. I noted on that occasion that that task force is `to nationally identify short and long term issues against the background of existing legislation and recommend changes'. The participants in that task force are the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council, the National Farmers Federation, the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia and the Standing Committee on Agriculture. The convenor of this task force is the director of the Cattle Council of Australia, Mike Pendergast. Presumably, bringing Australian Agricultural Council representation to that task force provides a very high level of government consultation.

There is also the sampling task force, which is to review short and long term issues related to residue sampling regimes in Australian meats. Represented there is the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC), the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation, Ausmeat, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's relevant meat research laboratory, the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories and the Standing Committee on Agriculture. The convenor there is from the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council. The job of the third task force, the traceback and identification task force, is to review short and long term issues regarding positive traceback systems in Australian livestock. Again, there is a similar broad range of representation. There will be the Sheepmeat Council, the Cattle Council of Australia, the Australian Council of Livestock Agents, the Australian Lot Feeders Association, the Standing Committee on Agriculture and the Australian Meat Exporters Federal Council, with a convenor from the AMLC. As well as that, the industry established a compensation task force to investigate comprehensive insurance schemes against the rejection of their products.

It became obvious to me, during the negotiations over the past little while, as well as subsequent to the release of this report in the Senate a few weeks ago, that while industry is of course widely represented, through the Australian Agricultural Council and its own industry task forces, at least some parts of the industry have a perception that their voices are not being heard, specifically on the issue of the burdens that they have borne in maintaining our vital meat export trade, and hence the proposal to disallow these export orders. We must remember that the residue problem was not caused by the cattle industry, and the Democrats believe that it must be seen as a national problem, and not simply a problem of one particular industry. While we have considerable and strong sympathy with the livestock industry in general over the burden that it is bearing, the problem here is that we are in danger of sending out the wrong kinds of signals.

One of the things that we have to do is to look at the issue in its broadest sense, because in disallowing these orders, all that we could do would be to prevent this additional levy which, I repeat, was essential to the upgrading of the national residue survey and remains essential, only for those few weeks from the original moving of the notice of motion last week until the end of this year. That may be a satisfactory symbolic exercise for the industry, but it is a short-sighted perception. It would also demonstrate a lack of commitment to the upgrading of the national residue survey. That upgrading will include other industries from the beginning of next year, and that is very welcome because this problem is relevant not only to livestock and the beef industry, but also to agricultural industry around Australia.

As we have said, hundreds of farmers have voluntarily quarantined their farms and it is important that we address that issue. Earlier this morning, I moved a notice of motion for the establishment of a Senate committee to address the broad issue of agricultural use of chemicals in Australia and it seems to me that that is the way to address the real concerns that have been put forward by the Cattle Council of Australia and by the livestock industry in general. I say this because we must not do anything that would send out the wrong kinds of signals. The sorts of points which need to be made by this Senate are the ones some of which I have already made: Industry has been responsible and government has responded as quickly as government is capable of doing. I refer here also to State governments.

It is an area of concern to us in this place that up until now this Parliament has had no jurisdiction over agricultural and veterinary chemicals and, having had discussions with the Minister, I welcome the prospect of legislation on the issue of agricultural and veterinary chemicals at Commonwealth level being introduced at the very beginning of the next session. We need to send out signals that there is a sense of responsibility and a determination that as a nation as a whole we want to sustain our beef export industry and indeed our exports of all meats and agricultural products. The Democrats believe that to do this we have to do far more than has currently been done. We also have to think about issues which perhaps have not been getting sufficient thought. I can understand why the immediate issues are always the ones that get the most thought and concern. How should we test? How can we continue to export? Who must pay?

I have already said that we believe there is inequity in the forms of payment that have been set in place. We must not continue to assume that this matter is the total responsibility of the meat industry. We also have to ask ourselves why these chemicals have been used, what effect they have had-what effects the chemicals we are currently using are having or may be having. We need to address the broader issue of the effectiveness of chemical use, which is beyond the realm of the currently potentially damaging use of chemicals. There is currently a recognition of the problem of increasing resistance to agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Just last week on the Country Hour the chairman of a task force within the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Association addressed that issue. He said that it is a major concern for the chemical industry that resistance is increasing across a range of chemicals. In relation to weedicides in particular, he proposed an integrated weed management system which would introduce processes other than simply use of chemicals, other management procedures which are available.

It is the Australian Democrats view that it is one thing to look at the problem in the short term and that it is quite another thing to recognise that what we saw in May of this year was really just the coming to the surface of a quite significant problem which had to be addressed in the industry where it was found but one which clearly demonstrated to us that we have a potentially ongoing problem. As I have said, even the chemical industry itself recognises that we need to look beyond simply moving from one chemical to another once that chemical is found to be damaging or ineffective. I have been disturbed by some comments that I have before me from the Weekly Times of 2 December in which the Victorian Minister for Agriculture is quoted as saying that producers must bear the onus for chemical residue problems. My question to him would be: Which producers? Is he talking about the agricultural producers or is he talking about the producers of the chemicals and the various people in the whole distribution chain? I would say that we need also to look at what kind of advice has been given to rural producers of all kinds by State departments of agriculture. We need to look at what kinds of new advice they may be able to be given in the event that it is decided that the advice has been limited to advice surrounding the use of chemicals.

Let me go back specifically to the disallowance. The Cattle Council of Australia and the cattle industry itself supported the upgrading of a national residue survey. Of course they did because, as I have said, they have had a responsible attitude all along on the issue. They understand the ramifications for the export of their product and other products from this nation. I and the Democrats understand the level of frustration and concern that the cattle industry will be taken for granted in all this. It is perhaps a very common human trait that if people pick up responsibility they are usually lumbered with it for the rest of time. I do not want to see that happen to the cattle industry any more than the cattle industry wants to see it happen, so I think we have to address that issue.

As I have said, I have had discussions with the Minister. I believe that when I move for the establishment of a Senate committee it will have terms of reference aimed at doing several things: firstly, providing the sort of forum which the industry has told us it does not believe that it has had through the Australian Agricultural Council; secondly, looking at just what mechanisms are in place, including national and State legislative mechanisms, to continue to address this issue and to ensure equity in terms of the costs involved-that is, equity across the whole board not just within primary industry itself because this is not just a primary industry problem; and, thirdly, looking at where we go from here to ensure that nothing like this ever happens again within Australia, certainly with regard to our agricultural industries and also with regard to the whole range of environmental and health problems which are associated with chemical abuse, overuse and misuse or ineffectiveness. This is an issue which is increasingly causing concern. I have put this range of issues to the Minister as being matters which need to be addressed. I am confident in the expectation of support from the Government. Of course, that is essential because unless there is support from any government for an initiative such as this, particularly where such important trade matters are at issue, it is really not an exercise which could be confidently expected to be of any value at all.

The Democrats have decided that to take the kind of step proposed by Senator Lewis would be to put our export industries at risk. We are also cognisant of the fact that any inquiry which is established must clearly state a continuing commitment and sense of responsibility, both from industry and government and from the community at large on this issue, in the interests of our export industries and in the interests of the environment and public health as well. For those reasons we are not supporting Senator Lewis's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thoroughly and absolutely support Senator Lewis's motion for the disallowance of the Export Control (Fees) Orders. There is nothing special or unique about the motion but there is something terribly predictable about the attitude of the Australian Democrats to it. Last night, on the issue of the resource rent tax, they were bought off for a miserable $5m to fiddle around with a few windmills. I wonder what the price is today. They had given notice of a motion themselves for the disallowance of these orders but, after one talk with the Government, they were seduced into withdrawing it. What is their excuse? They do not want to put the industry at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: The bottom line is that we already have a national residue survey (NRS) which is funded exclusively by the Government. We now have the Government demanding that, on top of all the other costs the rural sector has, the farmers pay 50 per cent of the cost of the national residue survey, not only for beef and all other animals but also for all on-farm costs. The Democrats support this charge on the basis that if they do not they will be putting the industry at risk. What tortuous logic. It is not logic; it is not meant to be logic. It is another sell-off by the Democrats.

What will the Democrats do now? They will have an inquiry. They not only sell their souls but they are also plagiarists. The coalition parties first put forward the proposition for an inquiry. We quite properly discussed it with the Government and the Democrats and suddenly, predictably, the Democrats are on their feet saying that they will have an inquiry. They do not even have original thoughts. This idea came from the coalition and as it was the nearest thing that the Democrats could get to looking respectable, they got up and plagiarised it. The Democrats have no integrity.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will withdraw that notice of motion too!

—That is right. We will find next that they will change their minds about the inquiry, unless they can find some loony group which supports them and which will, in some ways, be affected by it. What is the Government asking of the rural sector? It is asking the rural sector to fund half of the cost of the upgraded national residue survey and, over three years, that cost of $11.3m will be added to the current ongoing cost of an annual budget of $1.8m. That is what is being asked of the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the incompetence of the national residue survey so far, the Government has decided to upgrade it and change its programs. As I understand it, in 1987-88, the Government is talking about taking 25,000 samples. It ought to be remembered that the national residue survey is being upgraded not only because of the pesticide problem but also because the European Economic Community has placed a ban on meat products containing certain hormones. It ought to be remembered--

TALK.START.PARA: —A broad chemical problem.

—That is right; we have a broad chemical problem which the Democrats are suggesting ought to be paid for and carried by the cattle industry. But the significant component of the upgrading of the NRS is the non-meat component. That will be substantially enhanced from 1988-89 onwards and equal emphasis will be given to that as well.

SPEECH.PARA: We might ask ourselves: Why is it necessary for there to be an upgrading of the NRS? What has suddenly happened that has caused the need? This program has been an absolute disaster, an abject failure. Before the pesticide crisis the only sampling that was done for organochlorines was by the national residue survey and that testing was done only at export abattoirs. But inasmuch as some of the beasts that came out of those abattoirs were consumed domestically the testing was done for the domestic market as well. When a violation occurred the results of that violation were passed to the various State governments and they were also provided to the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service.

We might well ask ourselves: What was the next inevitable step? We had violations. Then no further step was taken, although I understand that, in some cases, the State governments went to the farmer and, to use their expression, they counselled him. They said, `You have a problem and we suggest that you do not do it again'. That was the end of the contribution of the NRS. We might ask ourselves: Why, in the middle of this year, did we suddenly have a crisis with our United States of America (USA) export market? It was because violations had been detected for a number of years right across Australia, but with particular emphasis in Western Australia, and absolutely nothing was done about them. The national average of violations varied between 0.4 and 0.45 per cent. In Western Australia the average level of violation was over one per cent-250 per cent higher than in the rest of Australia. Did that ring bells? If it did, they were very muted, and the Department of Primary Industry and the State agricultural departments were very deaf. Not a thing was done about it until the Americans took more care at their end of the market. Their testing detected real problems and, as a result, there has been intensive testing in Australia. The Government's solution is simply to load the cost of its own scandal, its own cover-up and its own incompetence on to the poor old farmers-not the broad spectrum of the rural sector but, just for the moment, the cattle producers. The Government does not load the cost on to the shippers, the consumers, the companies which bought the beef and sold it in the United States or the chemical industry; it is simply loaded on to the poor old farmer.

What is being asked of the farmer now? Besides paying the 15c a head, the farmer is being asked, as a result of the incompetence of the NRS, to undertake the cost of the intensive testing which is taking place, which is between $38.50 and $40 a test. He is being asked to buy back every pound of contaminated beef from the United States. The shippers, the Government and the purchasers are not being asked to buy back this beef; the farmer has to buy back his own beef, which he has already sold. Who is paying for the testing of the beef that is quarantined in the United States in containers? Who is paying for what is described as pyramid testing in the United States? It is not the United States consumers, the United States purchasers, the shippers, the chemical companies, the Australian community or the Australian taxpayers, but the Australian farmers and nobody else.

We find that this Government is prepared, like Pontius Pilate, to wash its hands of its own incompetence and pass it back to the rural sector-at a time when the rural sector is already in a significant downturn, other than for those farmers who are blessed with sheep. In my own State of Western Australia alone, about 183 farms in the south-west have been quarantined. That represents about 85,000 hectares of prime grazing land. `Quarantined' means that a farmer cannot grow beef on that area.

The Government says to farmers, `Have your stock agisted somewhere', but it does not tell them where. It does not tell the farmer how he is going to pay $1.50 to $2.50 per week per beast for agistment costs; it does not tell him how he will pay his transport costs, which amount to about $13 or $14 per head for an average trip of 230 to 250 kilometres; it does not explain to him how he will pay the $80 a tonne for the additional fodder cost; it does not tell him where he is going to put his beasts in the middle of summer in a dry season; and it does not tell him what he is going to do on the farms where the cows are already calving and there is another calf at foot. Overnight, farmers in Western Australia have found that they have absolutely no income, no prospect of income and no means of adjusting or making arrangements so that they can earn a livelihood in another way.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Democrats say they should be encouraged to go to the wall.

—The Democrats tell us that they are going to make the rural sector pay half the cost of the national residue survey to save the industry. I ask the Democrats to stand on their feet in this chamber and tell us why the Government should not continue to pay it as it did in previous years. Why is it that suddenly, in a time of rural crisis, the farmer is required to pay half the cost?
—And retrospectively.

—And retrospectively-I thank the honourable senator-to 1 July 1987. The Democrats intend to support this legislation, which increases the levy on beef to $18-a modest increase of 300 per cent! And the Democrats tell us that they support the rural sector. The Democrats are going to support legislation which, besides the upgrading of the NRS, provides an additional cost of $5 per head for intensive testing. Besides the farmer paying the 15c per head there will be an additional cost of $5 per head-and the Democrats are supporting the legislation. At a time when the rural sector is between a rock and a hard place, what do the Democrats do? They attach themselves like lean leeches to this Government and shovel all the cost on to the rural sector. I ask: What are the Democrats all about? What is this Government all about? They are about abrogating responsibility, about ensuring that somebody else assumes responsibility for the mistakes of the Government in the past.

SPEECH.PARA: As I say, the NRS is being upgraded for one reason only; because it has been demonstrated by the American Government that its management is incompetent. To overcome the sins and the failures of the Federal and State governments, the solution is simply to charge the farmer 15c a head. That is the solution, the panacea, that this Government offers. I fully support Senator Austin Lewis's proposal for the disallowance of this charge of 15c. It is the least that can be done to ensure that the farmer receives some relief.

In conclusion, I remind the Senate why at the end of the day we have problems with the NRS. The testing carried out was not intensive or even detailed testing; it was just random testing of the industry. It was such random testing that, by the time a sample was taken and analysed, the beast which had created the violation was in a Coles New World supermarket or on the high seas on its way to America. The Government's answer was, `We could not do anything about the violations because the beef had left the abattoirs'. To compound that sin, the NRS could not even tell the State governments or the farmers where the violation came from. No steps were taken to ensure that the source of the violation could be categorised. That is just symptomatic of the problems confronting the industry now.

Later this afternoon we will be debating the Live-stock Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill and associated legislation, together with the initiative of the coalition for the establishment of a Senate select inquiry to examine the whole range of problems which confront the rural industry in respect of pesticides. Perhaps that will be a more suitable time for a more detailed debate. All decent, responsible, concerned senators who care for the Australian rural industry, a $2.5 billion annual industry, will support Senator Austin Lewis's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support Senator Lewis's motion for disallowance. The Government and the Australian Democrats have treated this industry in a most shabby way. The livestock industry plays a significant role in the economy of Australia. Every week a total of $90m is injected by the industry into our economy; $4.9 billion will be injected into it in the period 1987-88. The industry is one of Australia's profitable industries. It reduces our foreign debt and earns this nation important export dollars and yet it gets no recognition whatsoever from this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with interest to Senator Powell's contribution. I concentrated as hard as I could but I could not follow one word that she said. She seemed to be making some hollow excuse for completely backing away from what the Democrats believed two weeks ago. However, we have come to expect that from the Democrats. Last night they sold out on the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Bill. The previous time it was before the Senate they voted with the coalition but last night they voted against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—I understand that some shabby deal has been done between the Government and the Democrats, and we have become used to this. It may be for additional staff, extra office accommodation or a few windmills. I do not know why the Democrats sell out their principles but they have certainly become the political prostitutes of Australia. That is the best way I can describe them. One never knows where they are; they will change their minds at any time and for any reason. Let rural Australia judge the Democrats at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: If rural Queensland did not vote for the Democrats the number of Democrats would be reduced by one. It is only because rural Queenslanders, for some misguided reason that I have never been able to understand, support the Democrats that Senator Macklin can here destroy their livelihoods. I will be adding this measure to the list of sins the Democrats have committed against rural Australia over the five years that I have been a member of the Senate.

I get back to the difference in this Government's attitude to primary industry and to secondary industry. On 1 September, as a result of the national residue survey, the levy charged per beast slaughtered was increased by 15c, and this was made retrospective to 1 July. The beef industry has accepted the responsibility and more than accepted its share of the problem. It has imposed levies to clean up a mess that it did not cause. Probably the only thing Senator Powell said in her speech that made sense was that the residue problem was not caused by the cattle industry, and yet that industry has accepted the responsibility to clean up the problem. In the last 12 months it has imposed between $15m and $25m in voluntary levies. It has reduced the figure for violations from 0.04 to 0.007. The industry has recorded areas of heaviest violations, and it has done a magnificent job in correcting the residue problem.

However, as has been said in the Senate, the problem was not caused by the industry. It merely used the chemicals, the products, that were endorsed by the various State and Federal governments. Yet it has been forced to shoulder the whole of the responsibility. Every day it is spending $130,000 to clear up this problem, or to minimise it, and yet it has received absolutely no help from the Government. When the steel industry got into trouble the Government allocated it $500m over five years, when the car industry got into trouble it got $300m over five years and when the coal industry got into trouble it got $40m. Yet the beef industry, which plays such a critical role in the economy of Australia, has had absolutely no help from this Federal Government. I continually say in the Senate that this Government has one rule for primary industries and another for secondary industries.

I have a list of some of the anti-rural measures that the Democrats have supported over the past three years. They voted with the Australian Labor Party on its anti-rural tax package. They voted to impose the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, to quarantine farm losses and to remove the full tax write-off by farmers of water conservation expenditure. In 1986 the majority of Democrat senators supported Government Bills to recover the subsidy paid on imported fertilisers, thus ensuring the Bill's passage, and this cost rural Australia $12m. In 1985 the Democrats opposed the move to restore fuel rebates introduced by the last Liberal-National Party Government. This cost rural Australia $67.5m. The list goes on and on.

The Democrats have completely changed their direction. Only a couple of weeks ago they gave notice of a motion supporting the abolition of the 15c per beast levy. The beef industry has done everything in its power to clean up its industry, even though the problem was not primarily its fault. It used only the chemicals that were recommended and endorsed by the various State governments. Tomorrow or the next day we will pass legislation that will impose another levy which will fund the testing of residue in all cattle. Imposing retrospectively a levy of 15c a head on the cattle industry is a shocking action by this Government, an action that has proved what we already know-that this Government has no affinity with the industry. The Government does not care; it has done nothing for rural industry except impose one cost after another. It has shown that there is a two-tiered system and that secondary industries get all the support they need at the expense of the rural industry. I certainly support the motion of disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this disallowance motion very briefly because we have a very full program today. However, I consider it to be a most important disallowance and it is something that I have been particularly concerned about from the time it came up. Today we have seen a further Democrat double back flip which highlights the insanity of the way in which the Australian Democrats support measures that will absolutely stifle a very vital part of Australian industry. There is no reason on earth why the Government cannot continue funding the national residue survey. Even the Democrats agree with that. Only a couple of weeks ago they put down a notice of motion identical to that which we are debating today. Of course, the normal decision-making process took place, which is what they consider to be testing the water and seeing what they can get out of the Government in return for a vote. But they have now changed their mind.

SPEECH.PARA: I am even more concerned today to hear Senator Powell say that many of the farmers who have been quarantined and who are currently quarantined should be encouraged to go to the wall. She also said `if rural producers are experiencing hardship'-`if' being the operative word. If she does not know, as spokesman for the Australian Democrats, that there are people experiencing rural hardship because of the pesticide problems, it is about time she did. Her incompetence in this area is something about which we are absolutely amazed. Any threat to Australia's beef trade with the United States of America can be viewed as a threat to the Australian economy generally. Yet the Australian Democrats do not see this issue as important enough for them to vote for this motion of Senator Lewis-which is identical to the one put down by them.

The farmers will be asked to pay a levy of 50 per cent where the Government was previously paying the whole lot. How can the farmers afford to pay this when overnight they have been put into a position of nil income? In my State of Western Australia there are between 170 and 180 farms in total quarantine. As my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne said earlier, they have been told to agist their cattle elsewhere. Where do they take them? How do they get out of quarantine? How do they pay the money to have the cattle agisted elsewhere? How do they pay for the feed? None of these matters has been taken into consideration. The Government is purely and simply saying, `You go and solve the problem'.

The Department of Agriculture in Western Australia-I have to give credit where credit is due-has been very helpful in many areas. But the Western Australian producers in particular will be very badly affected by legislation that is coming up later this week. I think it represents a significant added cost that the farmers simply cannot afford at a time of crisis. If the Government and the Democrats say that they can afford it, it is about time they talked to the rural producers and the cattle producers; they simply cannot afford it. How can a dollar be squeezed out of someone who does not have a dollar? This levy has come at a time of quarantining as well as a reduction in stock prices.

These two things combined are certainly factors that should be taken into consideration by the Government and the Democrats; but obviously it is all too hard. State governments have shirked their responsibilities, as well as the Federal Government, and it is about time that they both decided to assist these producers and get them out of this tight spot. Incidentally, this is a tight spot that they did not get themselves into in the first instance. They were using the chemicals that they were advised to use. The great tragedy of this whole matter is that the departments here did not take the lead from the United States in the 1960s when such chemicals were banned. It is about time the governments really looked at their responsibilities because the concern over the increase in levies relates to a very important principle. It is the justice of expecting the livestock producers of Australia to bear, unaided, the necessary costs of ensuring that our meat exports are free of chemical residues.

I do not think it is a matter of simply saying that the primary producers have a serious problem and that the taxpayers should bail them out. As Senator Boswell said a couple of minutes ago, the Government has not blinked at bailing out other industries in Australia when they have run into difficulties. Why is it now bashing the rural producers again? A few years ago it was said that it does not matter about the policies that are brought down for the rural sector because this Government will never get a vote out of them anyway. It is a very cynical approach to hit consistently a very important section of the Australian economy is such a way. The fact is that the producers are not simply looking for taxpayer handouts; it is not their attitude. Of the overwhelming number of people that I have spoken to, none have indicated that they are looking for a handout. They are looking for justice.

Beef producers are having their farms quarantined, with cattle rendered absolutely immovable and unsaleable simply because they have complied with procedures approved by the Department of Agriculture. Let us not forget that aspect of it. The departments have approved the procedures and yet now the Government is saying that we should not take any responsibility for it. It is most important to stress that the meat residue problem is not the fault of the livestock producers. The industry sector is being asked to finance all of the activities for the collection of the levies, to allow the Government to get off the hook. Therefore, I very much support the motion of Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been an interesting debate, probably for the level of vitriol directed at the Australian Democrats. It is fascinating that the Opposition parties would not have supported our notices of motion, if we had wished to press ahead with them, on the grounds that they know and very much realise that, if we had voted with them, the type of damage that would have been done to the industry would have been immense. They would also turn around under those circumstances. They are quite happy to do a little grandstanding exercise but I suppose no one can begrudge them that in the week before Christmas. The facts of the matter are quite clear. The Australian Democrats put down a notice of motion with regard to this item prior to the Opposition parties waking up to the fact that it was an issue.
—Not true.

—Senator Knowles can look at the Hansard and see which one went down first. In fact, today's Notice Paper indicates which one was first. The circumstances are fairly clear. In this place people put down notices of motion time and again for a couple of reasons. The first one is to grab hold of the issue and say that it is an issue. This is something that the Government has to address. Possibly the best example of that particular operation in this Parliament is with regard to the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which does this on a fairly constant basis so that it is able to raise those issues with the Government at a better level of leverage. If the honourable senators on the back bench do not understand that particular operation that is probably why they are on the back bench. But other people who actually have the responsibility for these exercises have to engage in that as it gives them leverage. It makes the Government direct its attention to the exercise.
—Don't insult the listening audience.

—It is very simple to do with Senator Knowles. The operation with regard to chemicals in the agricultural industry is a very delicate one. From the point of view of trade, a matter for which I have responsibility as spokesperson for the Democrats, I recognise the delicacy of the issue with regard to our United States markets. In the last 14 months I have visited the United States Congress twice and have lobbied it with regard to our trading position. It is fairly clear that trade between our two countries at the moment is at a very delicate level.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that Australia's trading interests have been seriously damaged by the United States activity time and again. We should not give it another weapon by allowing it to move in on any of our other agricultural products. There have recently been negotiations between the American Government in Washington and industry with regard to the level of chemical residues in the beef exported from Australia to the United States. Obviously, many industries in the United States have been interested in exploiting this issue to their advantage and to our disadvantage. We must be careful not to give United States industry a weapon with which it is able to beat us about the head. The Government, quite rightly, has taken the view that we need more stringent national residue surveillance with regard to our meat exports. It has taken that view-with the full support of the industry, by the way-in the very clear knowledge that, if it did not take that action, it could jeopardise our entire export trade to the United States. That cannot be contemplated under any circumstances.

It is interesting that the previous couple of speakers in the debate-Senator Boswell and Senator Knowles-raised the chemical residues issue. No reference was made, of course, to the previous Government's inactivity over a long period. National agricultural and veterinary chemical legislation is about 20 years overdue. We hope that this Government, which has also delayed introducing such legislation, will move as quickly as possible to overcome that hiatus in the introduction of a package of legislation to deal with agricultural industries in this country. But the Opposition decided to go further. Senator Boswell decided to throw around a few barbs by talking about deals and whatnot. That is a pretty simple exercise. I ask Senator Boswell: What did the National Party of Australia get out of its two celebrated deals with the Government regarding the increasing of the number of members of parliament and media monopolies?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McGauran was one of the members.

—I do not think that was a very good payoff. Today, for example, the Opposition parties sided with the Government because of a deal that they made on the war crimes legislation and the Cash Transaction Reports Bill. We are talking about the ability of parties to push their own policy items when none of the parties in this place is in the majority. Fairly obviously, to get one's own policies up and running, one needs, from our point of view, the support of either the Opposition parties or the Government. We will continue to follow that course because we have a policy agenda that we wish to pursue. On occasions, we have been able to get the Opposition's support for those policies. The Opposition may not want to characterise as deals the times when it agrees with us on various items. Normally, it does not characterise those as deals. When we agree with the Government, the Opposition characterises such agreements as deals, and vice versa-the Government characterises our agreements with the Opposition as deals. Quite frankly, it does not worry me a great deal because I am sure the electorate is intelligent and knows what the numbers are.

SPEECH.PARA: I am worried about this type of debate and the problems we might cause. It is all very well for some senators to get themselves a bit of media attention or a few well chosen comments for their political party, but I urge them to consider that what we are dealing with is a matter of enormous delicacy. I hope that all senators will look very carefully at any activity which could in any way allow the American industry to damage our exports to the United States before they launch into such activity, even though they might be able to score a few political points. They should not do that at the expense of a very important export industry.

We also need to recognise that responsibility for chemical residues is not simply that of the industry. We have made this point time and again. Senator Powell, in all her contributions, has made it very clear that the Democrats' viewpoint is that the Government is obviously involved in the promotion of certain chemicals to the industry; the chemical companies are obviously involved, and have a responsibility in this matter; the industry is involved, and also has a responsibility. We believe that the exercise goes much further than simply saying that the industry has responsibility for this matter. We would hope that the Government would be able to support a much wider extension of responsibility. We believe that the $10m already expended has been well spent because of the significant role that the industry plays in our economy. But without some type of legislative base which will affect chemical companies, those people who provide advice to companies, and those people who promote the use of a range of insecticides, pesticides, weedicides and herbicides, we will not have moved very far. We need to place the onus on the various companies which are involved across the board, starting with the chemical companies and finishing with the end user on the farm.

In looking at these propositions-which we have done; Senator Powell gave notice of motion for disallowance of the export control orders last week-we have had the opportunity to consider carefully all of these matters. We, unlike the Opposition, do not have the luxury of simply saying, `Provided that the Democrats are opposing it, we can do anything we like, because it won't have any effect'. We are very concerned about this matter. We wish to register our view that the responsibility should be a great deal wider than that of the end user, but we are unwilling to go down this path at this time because of the obvious exercise that the Government is undertaking with regard to the national residue survey. That upgrading is part of its general negotiations with the American Government so that the US will stay its hand. That must have been a difficult political exercise for the Government, knowing the types of pressures that the American rural sector has been able to bring to bear upon the American Government. The US Government gave $30 billion in support to the agricultural sector last year. I remind the Senate that that amount is equal to half of our total national Budget. Support to the tune of $30 billion obviously indicates that the US agricultural sector has a very powerful lobby. That lobby sought to cut off Australia's entire exports to that country by using chemical residues as the excuse. The fact that the Government has managed to prevent that occurring needs the support, not the opposition, of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak only briefly. Senator Macklin is the cause of my speaking at all. Senator Macklin rose only in support of his colleague. It was clear that the Australian Democrats were trying to find excuses for having changed their minds, finally having made a deal with the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has moved to disallow a 15c levy on cattle slaughtering to cover the cost of a residue survey. The residue survey is to be undertaken on all agricultural products but the Government has said that the meat industry alone should pay the levy. The Government will pay half of the cost of the survey. The full cost will be shared by the Government and the meat industry. The Democrats had given notice of a motion for disallowance of the orders because, I presume, they believed that they were unjust. They believed the orders were unjust not only because they are to be imposed while the survey is being undertaken but because they are retrospective to July. The Opposition will not tolerate such an unjust imposition on an industry that is already facing problems. The Democrats, supposedly, also believed that the retrospective imposition of this levy was unjust. This is not the first time that they have changed their mind. The Democrats always hang around waiting to see what they can get if the Government is prepared to do a deal. The Government does not want to pay the full cost of the survey. It wants the meat industry to pay half. So the Government has done a deal with the Democrats. The Democrats have once again changed their minds and withdrawn their disallowance motion.

In a valiant attempt to explain to listeners why the Democrats have done so, Senator Macklin rose to muddy the waters. He talked about the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I do not know whether he has ever sat on that Committee, but I have and it is a totally different concept altogether. The Australian Democrats are a political party that should know what it is doing. Originally they moved to disallow the 15c levy because they thought both the levy and its retrospective imposition were unjust. Now, because they have done a deal supporting the Government's imposition of this levy on the industry, they are telling the people, `We just did it to bring the matter to the attention of the Government. Now we have brought it to the Government's attention we will back off'. What absolute rubbish! Never has a political party insulted the intelligence of its listening audience so much as the Democrats.

When we raised the question of the few properties in Australia that had been quarantined, from necessity, because of the problem in the beef industry, the Democrats said that the growers have to bear the brunt; they must take some action, even if it means those growers will go to the wall. That is a humane attitude, it is not? Under the instruction of the Federal and State governments, a few farmers were told that certain chemicals were safe to use on their properties. They took that as being correct and used those chemicals. Now they find that they are unable to sell their meat on the export market. The chemicals are present in only infinitesimal amounts but because the Americans chose to apply a specific test, much more stringent than the tests they apply to their own beef in the United States, these properties have had to be quarantined. These farmers have calves arriving, and they are told by the Democrats that they do not need government help, even though it was government instruction that caused the problem; that they should just go to the wall.

Let the listening audience understand that the Democrats are not saying that because these people were misinformed by the Government they should get government help. They are saying that they should bear the cost and go to the wall-wrap up their properties and just go to the wall. So long as the people on the land realise the sort of support they are getting from the Democrats, that is all I am aiming to do today. It is time that the people of Australia realised what hypocrites the Democrats are and how they change their vote. They never allow anyone to know just what they are doing. They hang around to see whether they can cop a deal from the Government. That is why I have risen to speak in this debate-to point out to the listening audience what goes on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis has moved a disallowance motion. I should at least state the Government's position. These orders were made to enable the Government to recover from the industry 50 per cent of the cost component of the national residue survey relating to meat. I wonder when the Liberal Party of Australia changed its policy. I always understood that it was in favour of 50 per cent cost recovery in these areas. These charges relate only to meat, although similar orders will be made in the near future to apply the charge to non-meat products in a similar manner. These orders will be effective from 1 January 1988.

SPEECH.PARA: The national residue survey is an essential part of international trade in agricultural and fisheries produce. It provides for residue monitoring, enabling government to government certification that tolerances in the form of the maximum permissible residue levels are not being exceeded. In particular, our major market for meat, the United States, requires Australia and other countries exporting meat to the United States to maintain a system of residue surveillance at least equivalent to that of the United States itself. Australian residue monitoring procedures are subject to frequent audit by overseas authorities. The national residue survey is only one element of the mandatory inspection process for agricultural commodities. Without it, the certification demanded by most importing countries could not be given and trade would be adversely affected. As the national residue survey is an integral part of the inspection process, it is proper that the industry share the cost with the taxpayer and pay 50 per cent.

Some of these points should be noted by those who have been so vociferous in their opposition to this measure. The Government, through its efficiency measures, has reduced real costs to the industry of meat inspection by some 30 per cent since 1984. Even after the costs of the residue survey are included in the charges for the current year, the net increase per adult cattle beast is less than the rise in the consumer price index. Last year the charge was $2.61. It had not altered for two years. The current charge is $2.50 per beast. When one adds 15c, it goes to $2.65. So over a three-year period there has been only a 4c increase. Yet the Opposition is saying that we are trying to grind the beef producers of this country into the ground. What rubbish! This charge constitutes less than 4 per cent of overheads. I wonder what the Opposition is about. Does it want us to return to the good old days of the Fraser Government when we sent horse and kangaroo meat overseas labelled as prime beef? That is what happened. These inspection processes are absolutely vital.

Unfortunately, I was not in the chamber when my colleague from Victoria, Senator Lewis, moved this motion. Senator Lewis will have to forgive me for not responding to the obviously rational points he would have made in the debate-he represents the great State of Victoria. However, I was here for the harangue from Senator Crichton-Browne. If this disallowance motion were to be successful, the cost to Government would be $4m. That does not worry Senator Crichton-Browne. I think he is a secret socialist. He is always in favour of our spending money on something else. Of course he rarely supports any measure aimed at raising revenue. When he goes out on the political hustings he points to that evil place Canberra and all the money we spend. He says we are supposed to reduce massively government expenditure, yet in this chamber he tries to appeal to a sectional interest in the community by saying there should be no charge in this area. I wonder where we will get that $4m. The fee is a fairly just charge.

Senator Crichton-Browne complains because apparently Senator Powell and Mr Kerin have had some discussions about a wider inquiry, not just into inspection costs but into the whole issue of pesticides. I am not privy to any inside information but I understand that those talks are progressing fairly well. We then had a contribution from Senator Boswell, who opened his remarks by saying that he did not understand a word that Senator Powell had said. I only just managed to understand a few words from Senator Boswell. He talked about a shabby deal between the Government and the Australian Democrats. Of course any deal between the Government and the Democrats, whether there is or is not one, is always described as `shabby'. If the Opposition and Democrats vote together it is apparently a coincidence of great principles. Senator Boswell went on to say that we were not at all concerned about rural Queensland. I wonder whether he thinks that up every time he heads out of Brisbane, where he lives, into the bush?

TALK.START.PARA: —Our country vote went up.

—As Senator Maguire indicates, our country vote went up in the last election. The electors have finally woken up to the fact that the National Party of Australia no longer is the good old Country Party of old. It now consists of doctors, retailers, Melbourne city councillors and retired public servants. The embourgeoisment of the National Party is a rather sad sight to anyone who follows the great traditions of Australian politics. It now consists of a rag-bag group of carpetbaggers who live in the big city, wander out into the bush and think they can con the bush votes every three years. What a load of rubbish they carry on with these days. They now make up a city oriented party. They have betrayed the bush. It is no wonder that even the National Farmers Federation, in its most erratic moments, could not support the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Boswell went on to say, `What has the Government ever done for the beef industry?'. I am about to tell him. We have taken a lot of initiatives abroad to defend this industry. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has gone abroad time and time again to defend the beef industry since this problem first arose. We sent trade delegations consisting of backbenchers and others to the United States to defend our position and to try to get the best possible deal for primary producers. We have restructured the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and made it a far more active and better body than in the past. As I indicated in the figures earlier, we have consistently reduced the costs of inspections. We have secured markets wherever possible in a difficult environment. In places such as Japan, we have defended those markets. So Senator Boswell's contribution, as always, was just a load of hot air.

Senator Macklin made a contribution I am fairly angry about because he provoked Senator Walters into a 10-minute diatribe. But, apart from that, his contribution was relatively constructive. Then we heard from Senator Walters who apparently got up to speak only to admo-nish the Australian Democrats. Admonishing the Democrats is a very popular sport at the end of session. I do not mind that but I just wish it had been done with a little more sophistication and a little less whining. If the coalition is so upset with the Democrats why, in the last Federal election, when those opposite registered their how to vote cards, did they give the Democrats second preferences in every case? I am honest enough to admit why we did it. We prefer the Democrats to the Liberals. Sometimes our bile gets up and we wonder about that dislike and that preference but, on the whole, we have a philosophical position that the Democrats are more acceptable than the Liberals, with the exception of you, Mr Acting Deputy President.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Senator Ray has said that the Liberal Party in every State gave the Democrats its second preferences. That is not true. In Tasmania, we certainly did not give the Democrats second preferences.
—There is no point of order.

—I thank Senator Walters for her correction. I should have said `their effective preferences'. When the Liberals' preferences were distributed, the Democrats were the effective second preference. Of course, the Liberals run their preferences through Senator Harradine. We did in part, too. But their effective preferences always go to the Democrats. The only exception, I think, was in South Australia some years ago, when an experiment was tried. Talking about shabby deals, from time to time we get an emissary across from the Liberal Party of Australia saying, `Why do we not do a cut out deal? Why do we not all refrain from sending our effective preferences to the Democrats?'. We have always rejected that approach. But there are plenty of shabby deals around.

SPEECH.PARA: To sum up on this issue before Senator Lewis responds, we are saying that inspection charge costs have been held at a remarkably low level. They were $2.61 for two years. This year we got them down to $2.50 and, even with the inclusion of this 15c per head, the costs go to $2.65, which means that over a three-year period there is no way that these charges have increased by even as much as the consumer price index. They are well below such increases. It is only fair that everyone contributes. The Liberal Party and National Party of Australia position that the Government can forgo $4m in revenue is a matter of their always picking up individual items and saying, `Governments should spend money in this or that area, but we will not pass any legislation to increase revenue'. At the same time, they have this philosophical view, ranging from a $4 billion cut in government expenditure by the Liberals to a $16 billion cut by the National Party. One wonders how they can sleep at night when they try to reconcile that form of hypocrisy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I would like to thank honourable senators who contributed to the debate. I believe that the case I made against this levy was confirmed by the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) in the first minutes of his speech before he entered into an attack on the National Party of Australia. He pointed out that it was only fair that all sections of Australian agricultural primary producer industries contribute to this levy. That is the first point that I made in my opening remarks-that currently this levy is directed specifically at the livestock industry, does not cover the other industries and, therefore, is unfair.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray then confirmed my case by saying that in order to introduce this system of fairness the Government will introduce new levies-which I gather will commence from 1 January-on other sections of primary production. That was the second point of our complaint about this levy; the levy not only is imposed on only one section of primary industry but also is imposed retrospectively on that one section of primary industry. The livestock industry has to bear this levy from 1 July this year. That totally makes my case, on the basis of what Senator Ray had to say.

I will say one other thing about what the Minister has just said to the Senate. He made a plea to the Australian Democrats to continue to support the Government. I assure Senator Ray that he does not have to worry about that. It is quite clear that since Senator Chipp has left this Parliament, politically the Democrats have turned radically left and now, quite clearly, represent the fourth faction of the Australian Labor Party, to the left of the Left faction of the Labor Party. Senator Wood and Senator Vallentine probably make up the fifth faction. As there are only two of them, they do not have to have meetings as do the Democrats before they send out their faction leader to negotiate with the Government as to what will happen with legislation.

In the same way, the left wing of the Labor Party has its meetings and sends out its faction leader to discuss with the Government what it will do. The middle faction-the Centre Left; whatever it calls itself-and the so-called right faction do the same with their faction leaders. It is only a question of who is right of left and who is left of right, and I am not sure what the position is. Clearly, the Democrats are in a similar situation to the factions of the Labor Party. They have their separate meetings and keep separate minutes. Then they come along and enter into some sort of an arrangement whereby they support the Government. From time to time, in order to be able to protest that they are not a faction of the Labor Party, they occasionally vote against the Labor Party-but not when it counts. When the pressure is really on, the Democrats are always in there supporting the Government.

As I have said, I believe that my case for the disallowance of the orders was made out by the Minister in the first few moments of his response. Unfortunately, I think because the Minister was not aware of it, he has failed to respond to my request that the Government acknowledge that my notice of motion No. 3 is a valid notice of motion for disallowance. So I will have no choice but to move notice of motion No. 4, standing in my name, whether or not the motion before us is carried.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Export Control (Fees) Orders as amended (Amendment), being Export Control Orders No. 17 of 1987 and made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed.

I do not need to add any more to the debate which has taken place. I inform honourable senators opposite that I do not intend to take this to a division. As I have said, I believe that our case has been made out by the words of the Government's spokesman, Senator Robert Ray. I draw attention to the fact that up until this morning the Australian Democrats had a similar notice of motion on the books, but I gather that, having withdrawn it, they will not support my motion.
Question resolved in the negative.

I do not propose to speak at any length to these amendments because it is quite clear from what Senator Walsh said last night that the Government is opposed to them and that the Government has in fact studied them and made a very conscious decision, ahead of hearing any further debate from the Opposition, to oppose them. In essence these amendments seek to widen the deductibility of expenses incurred by an oil company in relation to the assessment of the resource rent tax (RRT) which, of course, is now going to be imposed upon the oil industry as a result of the vote of the Senate last night. The wider deductibility is primarily in regard to exploration expenses on permits held by an exploration company outside the permit area on which the production which is liable to a resource rent tax is being undertaken.

It is certainly true, as Senator Walsh pointed out, that one of these amendments includes, in the area of expenses and deductibility against assessment of RRT, any payments made under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Cash Bidding) Act 1985. That is included as a deduction. Senator Walsh had a rather dramatic view of it. He thought that the Opposition was trying to reverse the cash bidding legislation. We would like to reverse it. We strongly opposed it. In fact the Australian Democrats carried out the same exercise on that legislation as they have done on this. They originally opposed it and it was defeated, but after Senator Sanders joined the Senate he managed to persuade his colleagues to change their vote on that and that is why we have a cash bonus bidding regime. I do not imagine that the Democrats are likely to support any proposal to water it down. As I said, that is the object of these amendments and although I asked Senator Walsh last night questions about other matters, he launched into the Government's answer to these amendments. I do not know whether Senator Tate knows that, but he will be saved some trouble if I inform him of it. It is quite clear from the attitude of the Democrats that they are opposed to weakening in any way the resource rent tax. They would in fact like to see it strengthened and widened and made more onerous on oil companies, which they clearly hate and wish to see out of business. Senator Sanders has made that all too clear. I hope that everyone notes that that is really what the attitude of the Democrats is to this important industry in Australia.

The Opposition had hoped that through the debate on these amendments there could be negotiation on this question with either the Government or the Democrats, or indeed both. Apart from our total opposition to the principle of a resource rent tax, if there is to be a resource rent tax we would be anxious to reduce its impact as far as possible. These amendments that I have moved are designed to do just that and they are, in principle, correct-as Senator Walsh acknowledged last night. He said that certainly they are quite proper in principle. We have had a lot of in principle and rationality claims put by Senator Walsh in favour of this tax, and those claims espoused by him are encompassed in the basic principle of these amendments; namely, that if we are going to have a profits based tax-which RRT is claimed to be-all the expenses that an oil company has incurred in exploration should be set against the tax. Senator Walsh says that if that were the case the Government would demand a higher rate of tax or a lower threshold before the tax comes into being. That was a very gung-ho approach that the Government was able to take to this matter in the heady days back in 1984, when the RRT was announced by the Government. At that time the Jabiru oil field, off the north-west coast, had been discovered and the Bureau of Mineral Resources was telling the Government that there were very great prospects for this field, and that it could contain about one billion barrels of oil. In other words, it would almost be a repeat of the major find in the Kingfish field in the Bass Strait. But of course the forecasts since 1984 have been greatly reduced and the fields that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd is now developing at Jabiru and Challis have got, between them, perhaps 50 million or 60 million barrels and not anything like the figures that were forecast by the Bureau of Mineral Resources in 1984. The resource rent tax, the rate of tax and the threshold for the tax that were determined on those forecasts of the Bureau of Mineral Resources should, in our opinion, be greatly revised in light of the situation that has now developed.

In my speech during the second reading debate I dealt at some length with the low prospects for new oil discoveries in Australia, not only in the north-west area but all around Australia. We know a great deal more, not only about prospects in the Timor Sea but about the prospect of finding oil in any of the off-shore areas of Australia to which this tax applies. So a very different situation has existed since 1984. Yet, the Government's attitude is to plough on with legislation which was finalised in 1984, but which has not come to the Senate before now simply because of the length of time taken to draft it. As Senator Walsh made quite plain last night, the whole scheme of this legislation was determined in 1984, and negotiations with industry, which he said that he as Minister at the time undertook, were finalised in the middle of 1984, in the atmosphere of high confidence about the prospects in the Timor Sea off the north-west coast of Australia.
