The rate of tax, the threshold and so on were then determined with the prospects of great profits being obtained, but they simply will not be achieved there, and it is most unlikely that they will be achieved anywhere in the off-shore region to which this tax applies. Therefore, we believe that the Government should have been prepared to reconsider the detail of this tax in 1987, as against the views that may have been justified in 1984.

The Opposition has been prepared to negotiate for a lower volume of deductibility than these amendments provide. We have been quite flexible in seeking a variation of these amendments from the Government, but the Government is adamant, as Senator Walsh made clear last night, that it will not entertain any further consideration of the form of the amendments, even though he agreed that they are a proper and rational inclusion in a resource rent tax regime. That is unfortunate.

Likewise, the Democrats have made it perfectly clear that they will not consider any amelioration of the burden of this resource rent tax. I was interested in Senator Macklin's contribution last night, in which he explained how he at least had given some consideration to the amelioration of this tax in some respects, and the Democrats had sought amendments along not quite the same lines as these, but along another line which the Opposition would have been happy to discuss with the Democrats. However, Senator Macklin must have been rolled by the superior forces of Senator Sanders among the Democrats, because no such negotiations were ever opened between the Democrats and the Opposition once Senator Sanders got into the box seat. Senator Macklin's contribution was rational, and it is a pity that the Democrats did not take more notice of their deputy leader because he was conscious of the same problem of which the Opposition is conscious and which we are trying to ameliorate in these amendments. We would be flexible and we would have been happy to negotiate with the Government or with Senator Macklin if he had carried his views to his colleagues.

Senator Macklin went on to say an odd thing, which was that, in the end, the Democrats decided that industry would be worse off if there were no resource rent tax because the Government would reimpose the old royalty and excise regime which applies in the Bass Strait field, but he seems to have overlooked the fact that the Government could not do that except by further legislation. The Government brought in legislation which removed the application of royalties and excise to the Jabiru field and, if the resource rent tax had been defeated, the Government would no doubt have sought to impose a royalty and excise regime on the Jabiru field. The Opposition would not have opposed a royalty regime because we have always said that that is the only proper way of obtaining an economic rent, plus the company tax on profits. It would have been possible for the Senate to have defeated any attempt by the Government to reimpose an excise regime in this area. Unfortunately, Senator Macklin did not seem to appreciate that and, because of the dilemma which seemed to influence him in declining that opportunity, any further investigation of amendments to this legislation was passed by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. It has been said by Senator Durack that we shall oppose these amendments, and this is true. We feel that there is adequate deductibility already for the oil companies. They are the richest and most powerful companies on earth and they have plenty of tax lurks and perks and need no more help from this Parliament, especially from the Government and the Australian Democrats. If the Opposition wants to keep pushing the oil company barrel, that is its decision, but the oil companies are doing very nicely, thank you, and do not need any more deductibility.

SPEECH.PARA: We feel that thresholds at the moment are too high. If we moved any amendment on thresholds, it would be to lower them. That would mean obtaining more money for the people of Australia for the resource that the oil companies are renting under this resource rental tax. It is obvious that that cash price bidding program is working well. The oil companies are keen to bid on these fields and there is no reason to tinker with this program. We feel that the Bill to impose the resource rent tax, unamended and with the spin-off of a sunshine fund for renewable energy, is an important step in establishing an energy policy which will look to the future rather than to the past. We oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall also speak briefly, because I know that, as with Senator Durack, we are probably wasting our breath as we have yet another shady deal between the Government and the Australian Democrats. Senator Sanders has made clear his hatred of the oil companies but, unfortunately, he has allowed it to carry over, because it could reflect on every Australian in years to come. What the Democrats seem to have forgotten, or do not realise, or are perhaps blind to, is that we are running out of liquid fuel. We are talking about liquid fuel and not about energy materials for fuelling power stations, or fuel for industry.
—What about restructuring society? That is our policy.

—I am glad that Senator Sanders interjects because he shows exactly the stupidity of his argument. He is talking about the restructuring of society, and presumably he means going back to bicycles, horses and carts. What we are talking about is the use of liquid fuels for motor cars, aeroplanes and other vehicles that must use liquid fuels for propulsion.

SPEECH.PARA: I support the amendments moved by Senator Durack because while we do not support a secondary tax, which is what the resource rent tax is, we do seek to ameliorate it to the extent of allowing expenses to be deducted outside what is known as the permit area. This, in itself, is an encouragement for more and more companies to go out and explore because we do not have a recognised oil province in Australia and never have had. We just do not have the geological structures that are necessary for an oil province. If we are not going to have to face the threat of $3 billion-worth of imports by 1992, and maybe $5 billion by 1995, we need more people to go out and explore to see whether they can find some basins of oil which will protect us as we go towards the year 2000.

I support Senator Durack's amendments, which would give a little more encouragement to enterprise to go out and seek oil so that we do not become reliant on other countries for the liquid fuels that we shall need.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the amendments. Senator Durack, in the course of his elaboration of the reasons which led him to put forward these amendments, interspersed his remarks with an indication that Senator Walsh had last night elaborated on the reasons why the Government would reject them. I, of course, attach much greater weight than Senator Durack does to Senator Walsh's reasons and I hope other honourable senators find them as persuasive as I did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add something now as I ran out of time before. Last night Senator Walsh made some critical comments about the drafting of the proposed amendments: he claimed that they were deficient in some respects. Of course, that is not the reason why the Government has opposed the amendments; it was clear that it would oppose them no matter how satisfied Senator Walsh might have been with their drafting. The Opposition obtained very highly qualified professional assistance in the drafting of the amendments. We are perfectly well aware of the technical nature of this legislation, which it has taken the Government nearly three years to draft. Very careful attention was given by the Opposition to obtaining expert advice and assistance in the drafting of the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Such criticism comes rather ill from Senator Walsh, the Minister for Finance, who has had recently to confess to very grave errors in recent national accounts, and when I see on the Notice Paper a Bill we have to deal with before we get up to validate a wheat tax due to an error by expert advisers. Even though there might have been some error or some controversy about the quality of the drafting of these amendments, nevertheless the Government puts through legislation and publishes national accounts in which its expert advisers have made blatant mistakes. We get this time and again from the Government. I am sure that an expert lawyer or accountant, if he made a very detailed analysis of the petroleum resource rent tax package, would be able to find some errors in it as well. Maybe such errors will come to light. It is a very technical area and mistakes can be made. I am not in a position to argue about the technical quality of the amendments but the Opposition has taken care to get expert professional advice on their drafting. If the Government had been in any way prepared to negotiate on a more satisfactory resource rent tax regime of course the Opposition would have been very open to further negotiation with the Government about such technical matters. As I said, the charges Senator Walsh trumped up last night come rather ill from a Government Minister who has had to confess to some pretty major errors from the Government's expert advisers in the last week or two.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a further matter in relation to the legislation while we are in committee. I do not move an amendment but I wish to make some comment on an answer that Senator Walsh gave last night just prior to the adjournment at 10.30. I had asked Senator Walsh about the progress of negotiations which he as Minister for Finance had first announced back in 1984 when this new resource rent tax regime was unveiled. The question related to the position of the States and the Northern Territory under this legislation when it takes effect. Ultimately, although the States are not immediately affected by the application of the resource rent tax at the Jabiru field, when it is applied in all the off-shore areas of Australia, it will seriously affect the returns which the State governments now enjoy under the royalty arrangements in place with the Commonwealth in respect of developments in those areas. So I was anxious to know what arrangements the Federal Government proposed to make to recompense the States for a loss of revenue. I understood the Government had conceded that there would be a loss of revenue and that it proposed to come to some accommodation with the States to recompense them.

SPEECH.PARA: I was astonished, firstly, that Senator Walsh was able to say only that discussions will be held. Even though he said in 1984 that discussions would be held, they have not yet been held. He was able to answer only by repeating that discussions would be held, of course, before this legislation applied in an area where the States would otherwise have expected to obtain a share of royalty payments. But what I found even more astonishing was Senator Walsh's further suggestion that if the Government got the numbers in the Senate, it would squeeze the States out of any share of revenue from petroleum developments in the off-shore areas of Australia. Presumably, as the Government has support from the Australian Democrats on this legislation, it would get their support for such a proposition to deprive the States of any share of revenues derived from petroleum developments in off-shore areas of Australia, despite the fact that there is what is known as an off-shore constitutional settlement with the States which was entered into after long negotiations with the Fraser Government.

I might say that Premier Wran was a notable participant in those negotiations and the existing State Labor governments have been very pleased indeed with the off-shore constitutional settlement as a whole, not just their share of royalties. I am sure that Premier Burke from Western Australia-from which Senator Walsh comes-would be very interested to learn about Senator Walsh's threat to deprive the States of any say in any share of revenue from the off-shore areas. I hope I misunderstood Senator Walsh. Perhaps he did not intend to make the threat that he did but I can only express my complete astonishment that a responsible Minister would make a threat of this kind in such a cavalier way concerning a very serious settlement between the Commonwealth and the States which was negotiated and passed ultimately by this Parliament and which this Government has not attempted in any way to dismantle. Of course, if it did attempt to do so, I am sure the Labor State governments would be as horrified as I am.
Bill agreed to.
Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Bill 1987, Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Interest on Underpayments) Bill 1987 and Petroleum Resource Rent Tax (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill 1987 agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills (on motion by Senator Tate) read a third time.
Sitting suspended from 12.46 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, is again absent from the chamber for Question Time today, I understand due to a continuation of the reason which applied yesterday. Any questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Reynolds in relation to her portfolio or those she represents should be directed to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to the latest Business Outlook released by the Syntec research group which estimates that Australia's unit labour costs will increase in 1987-88 at a rate double that of our trading partners. It concludes:

QUESTION.PARA: In the face of this cost problem it is absurd for Messrs Hawke and Keating to assert that all is `on track' in this economy.

Against this background I ask the Minister: Firstly, on what wage cost assumptions did he base his excessively optimistic assessment released last Sunday of export growth prospects for Australian industry? Secondly, does the Government intend to make any wage policy adjustments to stem the continuing attrition of Australia's international competitiveness in 1988?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the latest Business Outlook published by Syntec. Perhaps I am a day behind and I am more familiar with the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) and Westpac--
—Four days.

—I thank the honourable senator for the sotto voce interjection, which does me no harm. I am more familiar with the CAI-Westpac survey, which I think is fairly optimistic about the economic outlook for industry generally. I was asked, in the light of the estimate provided by Syntec, which I have not read, whether I regard it as absurd for Mr Keating and Mr Hawke to have said that things were all-I forget the expression that the honourable senator used--
—`On track' was your Leader's expression.

—I think it is absurd to suggest that either of those gentlemen has ever said that in precisely those terms, or without qualification, because it is a unanimous view within the Government that there is--
—What? That is, all is not on track?
—No. There is no point in the honourable senator asking questions if he knows the answers already.
—I am trying to draw conclusions from what you are saying.

—I think it is a unanimous view within the Government that, while the major factors affecting the economy are as well on track as we might expect them to be at present, a number of difficulties will face the Australian economy in the next year or so, fore- most amongst which, of course, are the current account deficit and the size of the international debt. Those matters are constantly in the minds of Government Ministers. I am sure that Mr Hawke or Mr Keating has not said anything which does not contain those qualifications.

ANSWER.PARA: I was next asked: On what wage policy assumptions was the document, to which Senator Lewis referred, prepared? I assume that it was prepared some time ago but that is not the point. I would think it was prepared on assumptions relating to the wages outlook at the time of its preparation. That seems pretty logical to me and I think probably that is what happened. I do not want to intrude into the honourable senator's speech later, or mine for that matter, but while wages policy and relative wages are very important issues, that document was not really directed to that point. The point about that document is that it was designed to draw attention to a number of Australian companies which are highly competitive internationally in the current wages environment and the foreseeable wages environment. That is because they are companies largely for whom price, as distinct from a number of other issues, is not the major determinant of their capacity to sell their products. That is the point about that document. I suspect that, in those circumstances, it would not have gone on at great length to address wage policy issues. But I admire the honourable senator's adroitness in tying together the Syntec survey of a day or two ago and that document. It is a super long bow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Let me draw a further bow. The Minister referred in his answer to the document having been prepared on the basis of the wages policy at the time of its preparation. I ask the Minister, as I asked him in the main question: Does the Government intend to make any wage policy adjustments in the light of Australia's falling international competitiveness in 1988? In other words, has the Government's wage policy changed since the preparation of that document?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that, in a sense, I can say that it has, because only a week ago Mr Willis announced some new directions in preparing the parameters of wage policy for 1988 and beyond-a view which has been supported not only by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, but also by some major industry groups. I suppose that, in getting through the second tier negotiations and preparing for a more flexible wage fixation system, it can be said that there has been a change in the parameters of foreshadowed wages policy. That is true and that is the change.

ANSWER.PARA: However, let me just go back to another point which the honourable senator raised in his question. There has been a very real fall in wages in this country over several years now. The Government recognises the need for that adjustment to take place. But at any time at any stage in this country one could make comparisons between wages in Australia and wages in some of the countries with which we trade. For example, Korea is a very big trading partner of Australia. If the honourable senator is suggesting that, under this Government or any government of the ilk of the previous government, Australian wages would be adjusted to the level of wages in Korea, I invite him to say it outside and not here. This question about comparative wages in--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a cheap debating point. What about the nominal wage change?

—Senator Chaney has come in to bail out the honourable senator. The fact of the matter is that we cannot just say, `Australian wages should compare with those of each of our trading partners at any time'. I have already indicated to the honourable senator that there has been a change in the parameters in which wages policy will be developed in 1988 and beyond. In all that, of course, the Government will seek advice. But we will not seek advice from honourable senators opposite because in their last three years of government wages increased by 14 per cent, 14 per cent and 16 per cent. So we will not be seeking any advice from them.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, refers to the allegations of fraud made against Foundation 41 and Dr William McBride by two former Foundation 41 researchers over results obtained by Dr McBride in experiments using the anti-morning sickness drug, Debendox. I understand that Debendox was withdrawn from the market by its makers, the Merrell Dow company, due to Dr McBride's adverse reports on the drug's side effects. Given the importance of this issue to women and to the reputation of scientific research in this country, I ask: Firstly, what avenues are open to Merrell Dow to reintroduce the drug, Debendox? Secondly, have government grants been made to Foundation 41?

—Yes, I am aware of the controversy surrounding Dr McBride's research in relation to Debendox. I think at this stage it would not be appropriate for me to comment or to take sides in that controversy. The matter is still being sorted out within the scientific community. However, it is a fact that Debendox was withdrawn from the market some time ago and the decision to withdraw was taken by the responsible company, Merrell Dow. I am not clear as to what grounds the company had for withdrawing the drug, but it has, indeed, been withdrawn. Senator Aulich asks what procedures would be available to Merrell Dow if it wished to reintroduce Debendox on the market. If in the future the company does wish to reintroduce the drug, relevant data would need to be placed before the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee, and the normal evaluative procedures would apply. At this stage there is no suggestion that that procedure has been invoked.

—I refer the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer to his answer to my question yesterday about whether he knew before the release of his Forward Estimates report last Wednesday that the original September quarter estimate for the growth of business investment would be revised downwards sharply from 11.8 per cent to 0.5 per cent? Since this revision, plus the latest survey of private business investment expectations, strongly suggest that there will be no real increase in business investment in this financial year and, as a consequence, undermines the whole framework of economic assumptions which underly the Forward Estimates for 1988-89 and beyond, I ask the Minister: Was he told, either by his Department or by the Treasurer's office, of the business investment revision before the Forward Estimates were released last Wednesday? If so, why did the Minister not mention that advice during the Press conference at which he and the Treasurer sought to mislead those journalists present as to the significance of those Estimates? Does the Minister now regret this unprincipled cover-up on his part and on the part of his colleague the Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am well aware of the fact that the Stone fable, which has just been recited again here, was being furiously peddled around some of the more gullible journalists in the Press gallery yesterday by Senator Stone himself. To the best of my knowledge not even the most gullible journalists in the Press gallery bought it, but I have not looked at all the papers.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question as to whether I knew, I answered that yesterday. I knew that there was to be a revision-and that it was to be downwards-in the first published figures on business investment for the September quarter. I did not know the degree of the downward revision. As I recall it, I was told by a member of my staff who, I think, had been told by a member of the Treasurer's staff. I was not formally notified by the Department of Finance. Yesterday I did mention that I had told one of the Finance officers-I think before the Press conference was held-that I had heard that there was to be a downward revision.

As to the Press conference, we were not asked any questions about that. If members of the Opposition want to talk about cover-ups, I recommend to them a very close reading of the minute that Senator Stone had either authorised or, I suspect, written himself, addressed to the Treasurer had a Liberal government been returned in the election on 5 March 1983. Unfortunately I do not have a copy of it with me, so I cannot quote from it. Senator Stone told the former Treasurer, as he now is, the week before the election that the Budget Estimates on both the outlays and receipts side were in need of drastic revision, in particular for the 1983-84 financial year, and that there was an impending Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion. What did Mr Howard say when Mr Stone told him that fact on the Tuesday before the 1983 election? What did Mr Howard do? He covered it up. He said, `Give the electorate the mushroom treatment. Don't tell them the facts. Let the mugs go on believing the $6 billion phoney figure for a prospective deficit that I have already fed to them'. That is what Mr Howard said. Mr Howard got official advice in writing from Senator Stone, as the then Treasury Secretary, telling him that the prospective Budget deficit was not $6 billion, but $9.6 billion-nearly $10 billion.

As I said, I regret I cannot quote the precise passages because I do not have the document with me. What did Mr Howard do? When the question was put to him, `What are we going to do about it?', he said, `Sit on the figures. Let us cover them up. Let us go on'. He went on, not only covering up but also actually continuing to tell fibs to the electorate. He knew it was a fib and that the prospective deficit was $10 billion and not $6 billion. He went on telling the big fib-that it was, in fact, $6 billion-right up until election day because he thought he might be able to get away with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Leaving aside those largely irrelevant aspects of the Minister's reply, I refer to that part of his response in which he told the Senate that the reason he did not refer to this matter in his and the Treasurer's Press conference last Wednesday was that nobody asked a question about the revision to the investment figures. If I might say by observation and in passing, that was hardly surprising. Will the Minister now respond to my question as to why he sought, by that omission, to mislead those journalists present about the significance of that revision? Will the Minister agree that a falsehood by omission is just as much a falsehood as one by commission?

—It is not the custom, certainly for members of this Government, to release in advance-even if they are aware of them, and usually they are not aware of them in detail-the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) economic data or revisions of that data, particularly data which could be economically sensitive and affect things such as share prices and exchange rates. It may have been Senator Stone's custom when he was Secretary to the Treasury to give background briefings to journalists on ABS statistics and revisions to same before they were officially released by the Australian Statistician; but it is not the custom of this Government, and I hope it never will be.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to withdraw that remark which casts doubt upon my integrity.
—I ask Senator Walsh to withdraw. There is an imputation of improper motive.

—I will withdraw it, Mr President. But, regardless of whether Senator Stone made a practice of doing that, in the question he has asked he has obviously endorsed the principle that that ought to be done.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice, who is no doubt aware of calls for a special conference of all State Premiers, the purpose of which is to institute national gun laws. I ask: Will the Minister also investigate the possibility of including restrictions on the sale of ammunition in such a proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Foreman for his question. Of course, I am aware of calls for a national conference. When Mr Unsworth took this initiative and made this suggestion it was readily taken up firstly, I think, by Mr Cain. Then the Prime Minister responded by saying that he would convene a Premiers Conference to which all jurisdictions, including the Northern Territory, would be invited. It is very important that we in Australia take a national approach to the control of firearms in our community.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear from media reports over the last three or four days-from reading editorials and general headlines and listening to commentators-that there is strong public support for Australian politicians to take a stand. Perhaps this is the last opportunity that we will have to take a stand against the drift towards a United States-style society where the bearing of arms is regarded as a constitutional right, emanating from its particular frontier and revolutionary history, rather than a privilege and a concession by society-a concession which ought to be granted only in the most stringently supervised circumstances and after very high hurdles have been jumped by those who seek possession and ownership of weapons in our society. We in Australia do not want to drift that way and it is time that we, as a nation, took a definitive step in that direction to secure our preferred shape of our society.

All Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory have been invited to the Premiers Conference. I now understand that, despite some earlier speculation that the Queensland and Tasmanian Premiers would not attend, Mr Ahern has indicated that he will attend and Mr Gray has indicated that a Minister may attend to represent the views of the Tasmanian Government. That attendance would be very welcome. It would be even more welcome if both of those governments agreed to take the steps which were foreshadowed by the police Ministers meeting in Hobart a fortnight ago to have common standards and criteria for the licensing of persons who possess firearms and for the obtaining of permits to purchase firearms. On 10 December an editorial in the Daily Sun in Brisbane stated:
We want still tougher gun laws than those the Government-
that is the Queensland Government-
has ready to put before Parliament when it resumes next year.
Don't let us wait for a massacre here before semi-automatics are banned altogether.
On the same day, Thursday, 10 December, the Mercury, which is published in Hobart, stated:
Tasmania must change its mind and agree to sign the agreement for nationwide uniform gun laws . . . continued refusal would take on the appearance of callous indifference.

I believe that those editorials represent public opinion in both of those States and indicate to politicians, as do the polls published in the Age of a couple of days ago, that the public is willing to support very tough and stringent legislation in this area. Certainly, the Commonwealth is ready to play its part.

In the Australian Capital Territory, over which we have control, a dangerous weapons ordinance is being drafted at the moment to make the situation much more stringent than it is at present. I hope that this will rule out the possibility of any border-hopping between the Australian Capital Territory and the surrounding New South Wales jurisdiction. It is very important that we have uniformity in this regard. I do not necessarily mean technical uniformity in every provision--

TALK.START.PARA: —You might apply the same rules to videos.

—I understand the analogy that the honourable senator is drawing. As far as this matter is concerned, it is important that the Australian Capital Territory does not have laws which are slack compared with those prevailing in New South Wales and other jurisdictions. In regard to the importing of weapons over which we also have control, regulations at the moment prohibit the importing of automatics and semi-automatics with pistol grips. But the regulations certainly need to be tightened up, and that matter will be looked at. I have also written to my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications, asking him to review laws relating to the sending of firearms through the postal service. I expect that his reply will be available for consideration at the Premiers Conference. So the Government is taking a comprehensive approach.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to Senator Foreman's question about ammunition, I agree with him that any examination of stringent national gun laws must, of necessity, involve restrictions on the sale of ammunition. Indeed, part of the proposed national controls agreed by most Australian police Ministers in Hobart on 27 November, about which I informed the Senate last week, was the restriction of sales of ammunition to persons authorised to possess a firearm.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the Migration Amendment Bill 1987 which was amended in the Senate on 9 December 1987 to ensure that the status quo is maintained and that no fee will be paid by appellants seeking a review of status through the immigration review panels. As the amended Bill was agreed to by the other place, I ask: Have any of the prescribed fees of $240 per appeal been collected from appellants? If so, what amounts have been collected and, in the light of clause 2 of the unamended Bill and the departmental leaflet dated September 1987 stating that the fee of $240 be payable as at 16 September 1987, at what date was the collection of fees commenced? Further, in the light of the amendments to the Bill, which removed the provisions for collection of fees, will the Minister refund moneys already collected from appellants? If so, what steps will the Minister take to refund moneys to appellants in Australia and overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jenkins has asked a rather detailed question of which she was kind enough to give my office some notice. I have the following answer to part of her question from the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. In relation to the first part of her question of whether any of the prescribed fees of $240 per appeal have been collected from appellants, the answer is no. However, an administrative fee for appeals of $240 has been collected from applicants.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the second part of her question is that about $400,000 has been collected as at 14 December 1987 from this administrative fee. The answer to the third part of her question is that arrangements for the collection of the administrative fee were in place on 16 September 1987, but the first fee was not collected until the following day. In answer to the fourth and fifth parts of her question, the effect of the amendment to the Migration Amendment Bill was to remove provisions which would have provided for a legal entitlement for the reconsideration of certain decisions and the mechanisms for the collection of fees associated with the entitled services.

The Opposition has made it clear, both in the other place and in the Senate, that it is not opposed in principle to legislated appeal rights or a legislated fee. The Opposition wishes to see the details spelt out in legislation rather than in regulation. I expect that the Government will introduce legislation that will take the Opposition's view into account. It is expected that such legislation would sanction the collection of a prescribed fee for the service of reconsideration of a decision as from 16 September 1987.

In the meantime, the Government must come to a view about the continuation of the current administrative based scheme. It does not believe that senators, in deleting provisions to establish the legislated appeals system, intended that the Government abandon the current scheme which was extended after the 1987-88 Budget and which has been in operation since 1982 when it was established by another government. Similarly, the Government does not believe that the additional staff resources to reduce appeal waiting time, which were partly funded by the administrative fee, should be forsaken. It believes that the Senate would also hold that view. On that basis, the Government would also intend to continue with the current review mechanisms and the current fee requirements. As I understand it, this position conforms with the views of the Opposition as expressed in the other place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.
—When is a fee not a fee?

—That is a question which I will have to leave. Is the Minister content that, although we have not legislated, that fee has been collected retrospectively? The Bill cannot possibly come before us until the next session of parliament. Presumably, many $240 administration fees-call them what you will-will be collected between now and whenever the Bill is next before the House of Representatives. Is the Minister happy about that situation?

—Luckily, my state of being happy or unhappy is quite irrelevant. The fact is that I have been provided with the view and answer of the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in relation to this question.
—And like a parrot you gave it.
—I am not a parrot; I am representing the Minister and therefore doing my task. That is the view of the Government to be conveyed to Senator Jenkins.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the latest annual report of the Australian National Railways Commission and its reference to the Gladstone-Wilmington railway line in South Australia's mid-north. I ask: What proposals, if any, are being considered by Australian National for conversion of that narrow gauge railway to standard gauge? When is the earliest a decision might be made to proceed? What are the economic reasons for doing so?

—The Australian National Railways Commission has conducted a number of reviews, including an economic analysis of various options for the Gladstone- Wilmington line, and as a result has decided to standardise the line to Booleroo Centre. Standardisation is being progressed by replacing worn narrow gauge sleepers with standard gauge sleepers. The program was commenced three years ago and is expected to be completed by early 1989 when sufficient standard gauge sleepers will be in place to enable conversion of the line. Conversion will eliminate the cost of the break of gauge at Gladstone and this will enable the operation of block grain trains as far as Booleroo Centre. There is sufficient volume of grain traffic to justify the conversion. The project is being carried out at minimal cost as part of the normal maintenance program on the line. The actual cost directly attributable is not readily available but is estimated to be about $0.2m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Last Monday I asked the Minister whether the Government is reviewing its policy towards strategic defence research being undertaken by both the United States of America and the Soviet Union. In particular I asked-I quote from the Hansard-the following question:

QUESTION.PARA: In the light of the current evidence and the statement of Mr Gorbachev, will the Australian Government reassess its policy on this matter?

Has the Minister the response to this question he undertook to seek? Today I refer to further reports. For example, yesterday's Adelaide Advertiser ran the headline `Gorbachev's dramatic Star Wars concession'. It was reported that at the Washington summit Mr Gorbachev made an additional significant statement when, referring to the strategic defence initiative, he said to President Reagan, `You can do anything you want'. As this Soviet reappraisal of strategic defence appears to remove the Reykjavik obstacle to the further negotiation of mutual 50 per cent cuts in strategic weapons, what new initiatives is the Australian Government now pursuing to press the important disarmament goals supported on both sides of the Senate and which now have such good prospects of achievement in the coming months?

TALK.START.PARA: —That sounds like a very good dorothy dix question, but it did not come from our side. Unfortunately, I am not yet equipped to give Senator Teague a sensible answer on that subject in addition to what I said to him the other day-which was perfectly sensible as far as it went but did leave a couple of loose ends about which I said that I would seek further advice. He has asked me a further question today seeking still more in the nature of a response as to what our position might be in relation to the obviously rapidly changing circumstances, but rather than continue to rabbit on in this fashion I think it would make more sense if I were to get a sensible answer from my colleagues Beazley and Hayden and put down an answer before the end of this week.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister undertake-given that eight days have elapsed and this is a significant matter that was debated last week-to answer, quite specifically, what those new initiatives are before the Senate rises?

—I am indebted to Senator Teague for his acknowledgment of the significance of the part that Australia plays as a middle power in world disarmament forums and the way in which the rest of the Western and Eastern worlds are hanging on what new initiatives we may be prepared to contemplate in the light of these changed circumstances.
—It is a bit like a second course.
—Yes, it is a bit like that. In all the circumstances I can do no more than suggest that I will give a better answer before the end of this week.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories seen the article in the Australian of Monday, 14 December entitled `Korean koalas take a bite of tourist trade' which refers to the number of overseas made souvenirs available in Australian tourist outlets and to tourists' dissatisfaction at being unable to buy quality Australian made goods? Has the Minister any data on who does the tourist shopping, and how is it broken down between men and women? If we can safely presume that women spend many of the tourist dollars, can the Minister explain why there are no women on the committee to inquire into tourism shopping in Australia and how their needs and preferences will be taken into account? Secondly, will the Minister look at ways in which Australia's very splendid arts and crafts can be promoted and made available throughout all our tourist outlets?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for her question. I have seen the article she mentioned. No doubt honourable senators are aware that Mr Brown-the Minister for the global department including tourism-recently set up an inquiry.
—He does not like koalas.

—He has no dislike of koalas; he has not been piddled upon for some time. That Tourism Shopping Inquiry is chaired by Mr Bevan Bradbury, a former chairman of Coles Myer Ltd. It comprises a number of prominent people in the retailing industry all of whom no doubt have had experience in ensuring that the needs of the industry are tailored to the consumers. One assumes that consumers are not necessarily broken up by gender. Without wishing to pre-empt the outcome of the inquiry, there are sufficient indications that Australian manufacturers are missing opportunities by not supplying more of the goods sought by overseas tourists.

ANSWER.PARA: Visitors to Australia this year will spend about $800m on tourist shopping, which is an extraordinary amount. Unfortunately, we must concede that they would spend much more if they had available to them all of the items necessary to satisfy their requirements fully. For example, Japanese tourists leaving Australia in 1987 will probably take with them upwards of $200m which they had planned to spend but did not because they could not get the goods they wanted. Next year Australia will be host to more than two million overseas visitors and expenditure on shopping by those visitors will probably be at an all time high.

To find that replicas of our unique flora and fauna are manufactured overseas does nothing to enhance our reputation as a reliable and attractive place for tourists to shop. Unless the tourism industry, the manufacturers and the retail industry co-operate to market competitively priced quality goods, Australia will miss out on a substantial amount of foreign exchange. It is interesting to note that the article referred to by Senator Crowley states that one souvenir retailer has reported an increase in business since stocking goods manufactured in Australia. I hope that other retailers follow that example and I urge them to do so. Obviously within this country we have talented Australians in the arts and crafts industry who are producing high quality works. If those goods were sold in tourist outlets I have no doubt that they would easily outsell imported goods. Of course, the inquiry will be addressing all of those questions and will report by the end of June.

As to the second part of the honourable senator's question, there is a dearth of data on the general question of tourism shopping patterns, including expenditure by gender. The committee is currently seeking submissions from interested parties which, together with other research, should provide answers to many of the outstanding questions. I can assure honourable senators that the absence of women on the committee of inquiry is in no way intended to reflect adversely on the importance of women in tourism shopping. The committee members were selected on the basis of their particular experience in sectors of the retail and tourism industries, and, in the case of the union representative, his industrial experience and position in the key union involved. It is my hope that as a result of the inquiry Australia's high quality arts and crafts will receive the prominence and the exposure that they so richly deserve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Did I understand the Minister to say that this committee will be receiving submissions? Will the Minister advise people extensively of the opportunity to make submissions to that committee?

—As with all the inquiries that have been conducted under the watchful experienced eye of Minister Brown, I am sure that there will be more than enough publicity of the fact that submissions are wanted. When it comes to the question of gender in shopping, I am sure that not only Senator Crowley but plenty of other people will be interested in making submissions. I have no doubt that the arts and crafts industry, which has already expressed interest in the inquiry, will be making a submission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to his written answer dated 9 December in response to my question of 8 December, in which he admitted that the report from Mr Roger Beale to him on 1 September-and I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . wrongly identified a Mr Spiridon Apokis as a Director of Continental Venture Capital. He was, in fact, Director of Josa Investments, a major shareholder of Continental Venture Capital.

What was the degree of shareholding of Josa Investments in Continental Venture Capital Ltd? Is it suggested that Josa Investments exercised a degree of control over Continental Venture Capital? Will the Minister table the report of 1 September from Mr Roger Beale which contained this wrong information?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to take that part of the question, relating to the degree of shareholding and the significance of any control that may have flowed from it, on notice. I will certainly give consideration to the tabling of the report. The only question affecting a decision in that respect would be the normal freedom of information considerations about commercial confidentiality and questions of privacy or criminal process. Subject to those normal caveats and provisos, I will be happy to give sympathetic consideration to the honourable senator's request.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When will the Minister give consideration to tabling that report?
—I will endeavour to sort it out by the end of this week.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. As this is the week in which we remember the Indonesian invasion of East Timor in 1975 and the 100,000 to 200,000 people who have died there since, I refer the Minister to the following statement made by the Prime Minister on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation current affairs program PM on 19 May this year:

QUESTION.PARA: The closing of the Libyan People's Bureau was because of the Libyan connection with OPM and Fretilin.

Given that Fretilin has denied the allegation and, to date, has had no connection with Libya, I ask the Minister whether the Prime Minister has ever substantiated the accusation against Fretilin and, if he cannot, whether he is prepared to give an apology. I also ask whether the source of the allegation was a fake Indonesian document and, if so, whether he could make a copy available for translation into English. Finally, can the Minister inform the Senate how Libya has voted on the East Timor resolution at the United Nations when it has come before the General Assembly each year?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine gave some notice of this question but, I suspect, not enough. It raises issues concerning several portfolios. I will direct the substance of the question to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and seek to obtain an answer as soon as possible. Senator Vallentine will recall that she asked me a question last week in which she sought details which involved a number of portfolios, and I think she would appreciate that I responded with alacrity.

—Does the Minister for Transport and Communications agree that timed local calls would mean that callers to government offices and departments, with queued switchboards and piped music, would hold on for engaged lines at their own expense? Would this not be an outrageous burden for many sick, poor and disadvantaged welfare recipients who are forced to ring government offices for assistance? Will the Minister undertake that any timed local call scheme will not reward government inefficiency and boost revenue of Telecom Australia in this manner? Further, why has the Minister pre-empted the release on Thursday of Telecom's options paper on timed local calls by expressing a preference for a revenue neutral outcome? Has the debate been helped to date by the hysterical pre-election outburst of the Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mr Peter Spyker, and the New South Wales Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mrs Deirdre Grusovin, who have both described timed local calls as an outrageous proposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have much to add on this subject. As Senator Alston says, an options paper from Telecom will be issued later this week in which Telecom will identify the nature of the problems as it perceives them and a number of ways in which those problems might be addressed, including, in particular, problems that obviously exist so far as the elderly, disadvantaged and disabled are concerned. I do not think I am pre-empting anything by expressing a preference for revenue neutrality in any scheme that might conceivably be introduced. It has become well known in the last few days that that is Telecom's view of what, if anything, should be done in this respect. It is not a device, as some people have very wrongly claimed, to generate masses of additional revenue; rather, it is a way, in Telecom's view, of getting some rationality into the effective allocation and utilisation of an always scarce resource. Whether it is possible to allocate that resource through a pricing mechanism of this kind in a way that will not cause disadvantage or inequity is the matter that is in issue. It must be addressed by a process of consultation and discussion-preferably of a non-tendentious kind-over the next few months.

ANSWER.PARA: Issues such as the implication for callers of the queueing of calls by business enterprises and government departments will have to be addressed. One possible option-I do not know whether it would be appropriate for government departments-is the wider use of the 008 free call concept. That is something which undoubtedly also will be given consideration and will be adverted to in Telecom's discussion paper or discussions on this matter which will occur later this week. I do not think it is in anybody's interest for people on either side of the fence to make judgments about what may or may not be involved in any such new regime of this kind.

It is, as I said the other day, a difficult, sensitive issue and one that does raise very real questions about where the burden of rational resource allocation should fall. I think we would all be sensible to address the issue in a calm and rational way, rather than in the excited and overheated way in which it has tended to be discussed so far, and the way in which Senator Alston was contributing by his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to an article in last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald on the subject of the continuing division of the island of Cyprus. I ask the Minister: What steps has the Australian Government taken with either the Turkish Government or the Turkish-Cypriot regime in order that more details can be provided as to the current whereabouts of missing Greek Cypriots in the northern sector of Cyprus?

—In this year's session of the Commission on Human Rights, the Australian delegation expressed concern over the lack of progress in resolving the whereabouts of missing persons in Cyprus and urged the parties to the dispute to co-operate fully with the Committee on Missing Persons in order to bring about a quick resolution of the remaining cases. The Australian Government considers that the United Nations Committee on Missing Persons provides the best avenue for determining the whereabouts of missing persons in Cyprus. We will certainly continue to encourage the parties directly concerned to lend that Committee every assistance.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Minister will remember that last week I asked him about the container depot at Rozelle which is now closed as a result of low productivity by the Waterside Workers Federation. I am sure, because of the great importance of an efficient waterfront to Australia's export performance and economic recovery, that the Minister will now have familiarised himself with this matter. In his answer to me last week the Minister suggested that management might have been at fault in this poor performance. Is the Minister aware that the employer, Conaust (NSW) Pty Ltd, has managed to introduce improved work practices in its Melbourne depot which have resulted in a productivity rate of at least 10 containers per gang compared with 4.7 per gang at Rozelle? Is he also aware that because the Sydney branch of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia would not agree to the same improved work practices, Conaust was forced to close the Rozelle depot? I ask the Minister: Is it the position of the Government that these Sydney Waterside Workers Federation members, who will now return to a waterside workers pool, should get the productivity wage rise of 4 per cent under the second tier system, even though their poor productivity has resulted in the closure of a depot and the loss of jobs for about 30 other people?

—I am not fully familiar with the circumstances at Rozelle. I am no more familiar with them than I was the other day. That does not deprive me of the capacity to answer Senator Hamer's question, however. The point I was trying to make the other day is simply that productivity depends on a number of issues, including labour force practices, management practices and so on. If the parties do not get it right between them, they will suffer the fate of the Rozelle depot. If a work place, installation or a facility such as the Rozelle depot closes as a result of the incapacity of the parties to get it right, that is the way it will happen. The Waterside Workers Federation will presumably begin to understand that message-if it has been recalcitrant in understanding that message--
—It is a bit late.
—It may be a bit late; it may not be a bad thing. I cannot comment on that. Places do close because they are uncompetitive. New places open because they are competitive.
—They do not get a productivity rise, though.

—If the honourable senator will let me try to answer Senator Hamer's question, she can have a discussion with him afterwards and tell him where he is wrong. I very much welcome the fact that the company has apparently had more success at the Melbourne depot. Senator Hamer then asked me whether the waterside workers who were employed at the Rozelle depot should be singled out under wages policy considerations for selective punishment.
—No, it is a lack of reward-not punishment.

—A lack of reward, all right. Senator Hamer asked whether they should be singled out for a selective lack of reward. I think that would be a extraordinarily difficult exercise to undertake around the country. So my answer to that part of the question is no.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I must declare that I have a personal interest in this question. Has the Minister noted an incident last week involving a Boeing 737 aircraft operated by USAir in which the pilot of the aircraft shortly after take-off reported a complete loss of power on the starboard engine of the aircraft, which was found on examination to be due to the complete loss of the starboard engine itself, which had fallen into a field? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether he is aware of the reason for this terminal engine failure on this 737 and whether it has any implications for the 24 Boeing 737s which are operated by domestic airlines in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen, as no doubt we all have, the Press reports that a USAir B737 experienced what air accident investigators euphemistically described as an engine separation-I would have thought it was more in the nature of a divorce-at about 5,000 feet in the vicinity of Philadelphia a few days ago. The aircraft in fact made a safe landing at Philadelphia airport in the aftermath of that incident.

ANSWER.PARA: Preliminary advice indicates that an engine attachment cone bolt failure may have been the cause of the said separation. There have been several incidents overseas of such cone bolt failures in the last few years. Now for the good news-the aircraft concerned in the incidents have been B737-100/200 series aircraft. Aircraft of this series of B737s are no longer operated in Australia. B737-300 series aircraft are operated by Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia. This aircraft has a different type of engine mounting configuration. Based on the known problems with the mountings on the earlier series of B737s, the Australian first of type certification for the 300 series specifically addressed the engine mounting integrity for that aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer him to the present problems with organochlorine pesticide residues. The Minister will be aware that the national residue survey (NRS) has detected previously that over a number of years Western Australian cattle have shown levels of over twice those of other States. Can the Minister tell me why the Bureau of Rural Science, which manages the NRS, will not provide me with a breakdown of the locations where the tests in Western Australia took place and the results of the tests in the various locations?
—Who will not supply it?
—The Bureau of Rural Science, which manages the operation for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy.
—The simple answer is that I do not know. I will see whether I can get some information from Mr Kerin.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Devlin Sen A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the recent book of the New Zealand Finance Minister, Roger Douglas, titled Toward Prosperity, and in particular to a passage on page 197 in which Mr Douglas wrote:

QUESTION.PARA: Overseas research had shown that when top personal rates were cut, Government in fact collected more tax because high earners no longer went to such great lengths to avoid their tax liabilities.
Is the Minister aware of this research? If so, could it provide a basis for a lowering of the marginal tax rates?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—The supply-side effect.
—That's voodoo economics.

—I know. It is very much like it. I read Roger Douglas's book two months ago-three months ago, perhaps-and I came across that passage. I must say I was surprised by it. I, and people in my office as well, have since contacted a number of academics who specialise in tax matters. None of them are aware of any research justifying or supporting that conclusion.
—Did you ring Mr Douglas?

—No, I have written him a letter asking him whether he can refer me to this alleged research, although the fact that fairly wide inquiry among what should have been a group of people particularly well-informed on the subject has found no such research suggests to me that there is no research-at least no reputable research-which comes out with that conclusion. As somebody suggested by way of interjection when the question was first asked, this proposition is, of course, supply-side economics of the type that was embraced by John Howard in the election campaign but from which he is now trying to run away.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind the Minister that on 16 October this year he described the level of consumer debt as a national malaise which would seriously affect the economy. I also refer him to the comments made recently by the Prime Minister when he scorned the need for a higher level of domestic savings. The Brisbane Courier-Mail of 10 November reported the Prime Minister's view as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: There is no need for Australians to save more and borrow less . . . `My advice to them is to continue their patterns of behaviour.'

How does the Minister reconcile the responsible comments that he made with those of the Prime Minister, especially as figures compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show that the current level of domestic savings is the lowest ever for the period of this Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the allegation is that I made this comment at some period of my enlightenment. Is that right?
—I give you great credit for it, too.

—Oh, I thank the honourable senator very much! I did not appreciate that. If Senator Archer says that I said that, he must be right. But I am not able to comment on the remarks attributed to the Prime Minister as reported in the Brisbane Courier-Mail.
—You do not believe it, do you?

—It sound an unlikely story to me. For the benefit of Senator Stone, I might say that I have seen things the Courier-Mail has said about him and I regard those allegations as irresponsible. They are actually very flattering. I would like to put that part of the question to the Prime Minister and get his early response. Senator Archer will probably find that the level of domestic savings has started to increase significantly following 19 October this year-and that may be a good thing.

—Has the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer seen an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald reporting the contents of a letter from the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, to his colleagues defending the Liberals' election tax policy? What is the conceptual difference between supply-side economics, which Mr Howard argued was not the basis of his tax policy, and the incentive effect which Mr Howard argued was the basis of his tax policy? Would this Government implement major tax cuts to be funded on the basis of supply side or incentive effects alone? If not, what other factors would the Government consider before implementing a tax cut?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked what the difference is between supply-side theory, or Reaganomics, and Mr Howard's tax policy. The difference is that Mr Howard calls it incentivation, but it is based on exactly the same false premise. I have seen the report in the Sydney Morning Herald. If the report is correct, I am astounded. I am not really able to pass judgment on that because nobody in the Liberal Party has yet leaked me a copy of Mr Howard's letter, but I would certainly be very grateful to receive one. The journalists who have a copy of the letter apparently regard it as unethical to leak a further copy or photocopy of it to me. Assuming that the report is, if not complete, at least accurate in the essential details, I find it quite astounding that Mr Howard should now be trying to run away from the supply-side voodoo which he was so enthusiastically embracing a few months ago.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure that everybody on this side remembers the launch of incentivation early in February this year. Incentivation sank without trace in about two days because it was greeted with well deserved ridicule. What incentivation was all about, for the couple of days it was officially alive, was a proposal that we should replicate in Australia what Ronald Reagan, or the Reagan Administration, has done in the United States (US)-that is, actually test, empirically, supply-side theory. We all know what the consequences of that empirical test were in the United States (US)-a US Budget deficit which ran as high as $220 billion and which, in five years, turned the United States from being the largest absolute creditor nation in the world to being the largest absolute debtor nation.

However, leaving aside incentivation, which sank fairly quickly-there was no attempt to resurrect it by the Liberal Party, for quite sensible reasons, for a change, I suggest-in the bogus alternative Budget which Mr Howard finally produced he built into the arithmetic, such as it was, which stood behind the Budget $900m worth of increased taxed collections because of the incentive effects flowing from lower personal tax rates. That is, Reaganomics, supply-side theory, incentivation or whatever you like to call it, was actually built into the Opposition's numerical tables, but from which, assuming that the Sydney Morning Herald report is correct, Mr Howard is now trying to run away.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Lewis proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to address the underlying problems facing Australian industry.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —On my proposal the Senate is now debating as a matter of public importance this Government's failure to address the underlying problems facing Australian industry. This Government has put in an enormous amount of work in selling itself with jargon, with glossy booklets of the type I hold up, with media hype, and with the development of certain myths, such as the one just mentioned by Senator Walsh in his answer to a question-those myths repeated by a compliant and complacent Press ad nauseam. Similarly, with this Government's industry policy we have had an abundance of jargon and so-called plans for this, that and the other-each launched with a massive public relations campaign. We have had a steel plan, a motor vehicle plan, a chemical industry plan, and the plan that never was-the textile, clothing and footwear plan, which I will come to in due course. These are the so-called sectoral plans.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with these products is that the performance never matches the rhetoric of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). It never gets within a bull's roar of the Minister's rhetoric because the plans simply do not deliver. The underlying philosophy behind these plans has been an accommodation between big business, big unions and big government and a cosy arrangement to protect as many jobs and special interests as possible at the expense of the rest of the community. They have enabled many groups to exploit the taxpayers, or consumers. The vast majority of Australian firms and the productive work force within those firms are outside these sectoral plans and are ignored by this Government. Indeed, what is worse, many of them have been destroyed or are being destroyed by this Government.

It is this industrial base, the small businesses-in particular, I am referring to the small manufacturing industries-outside these grand plans of the Minister that have some of the greatest potential to overcome the unemployment and other economic problems of this country. Their import substitution products are vital to the economic well-being of the nation but, as I have said, this Government has ignored them. In many ways the Government's taxation regime has destroyed, or is destroying, these industries.

There is a malaise in Australian industry which the Government is not addressing. Certainly, the sectoral plans do not address the root cause of the malaise. The plans are alleged to address restructuring, to manage change, to work on people's attitudes, and to wean them off protection but, in the ultimate, all they do is increase the powers of the existing players while discouraging innovation and new entrants. New entrants, in particular, find it very difficult to get into the field once this Government has introduced a sectoral plan. Dr Barry Aldrich, a Sydney business consultant for the Committee for Economic Development of Australia, in a recent study of the confidential investment intentions of 25 Sydney manufacturers in a wide variety of industries, pointed out as recently as 24 November this year:
Manufacturers will make major new investments in new technology and improved plant only if they are confident that the necessary productivity gains will be achieved in practice.
Many see trade union resistance to rapid productivity improvement as a serious obstacle to direct investment in more productive equipment.

As a consequence, many manufacturers are adopting or have adopted the alternative strategy of growth by takeover, or merger with competitors. I am not arguing against takeovers or mergers-they save some companies-but there is a failure to encourage investment in new manufacturing plant that is one of the major problems of industry. This Government is not attending to that problem. Many manufacturers see the investment climate in Australia as hostile, so frequently they look overseas. Substantial new investments dedicated, in particular, to export markets are frequently seen by manufacturers as being unacceptably risky.

I know that the Minister will get up and say that he is able to quote certain manufacturers in Australia which have exported and are continuing to export. I congratulate them. I welcome them-I wish there were more-but they are the exception to the rule. They are not the rule in this country under this Government's policies. That is what this debate is all about-this Government's failure to address policies for industry which will encourage many industries instead of the elite few.

The sorts of complaints we are talking about are: high interest rates, high corporate taxes, hostility to foreign investment, many of the hindrances to investment projects created by environmental procedures and uncertainties arising from tendencies by government to support a stated policy of political expediency in particular cases-and I look at Senator Richardson's political expediency in the Queensland wet tropical north. The absence of specific investment incentives is one of the things that many exporters especially complain of. The Government's failure to buy Australian-made is a complaint I hear very frequently around Australian industry. Indeed, many Australian government authorities, in their purchasing specifications, use what might be called lock-out specifications, whereby Australian manufacturers are locked out through the use of tender documents which refer either specifically or indirectly to a specific product.

Let me say something about that. If a government authority decides that its specification will be written in the form of what it wants rather than what its functional needs are, the result is that the authority ends up with old-fashioned technology, because the person writing the specification must be looking at a specific item of equipment which he or she wants purchased by the authority. I can refer to many examples in the defence industries. The acquisition of the FFG frigates to service an aircraft carrier is a typical example of a specification, written for a particular purpose, which has ended up being a disaster. But that was in a big area. This is happening all around government departments where specifications are written quite clearly to end up with a product. If the person writing the specification has a particular product in mind, the result will be that the Department ends up with last year's rather than next year's technology, because the equipment is in existence. It might even be two, three, or up to five years, old in its technology. The Government is allowing its departmental officers to do this. I give an example. In a tender document issued within the last four weeks, IBM Australia Ltd is mentioned four times in the body of the document. It will be no surprise if IBM ends up supplying most of the equipment to fill that tender.

We have been delighted to see the recent change in regard to a tender called by the Australian Taxation Office, which refers to the functional needs of that office rather than its wants. Most government statutory authorities, in these purchase areas, call for international computers. Wang Computer Pty Ltd seems to be very popular and, of course, once a department gets a Wang piece of equipment, it is locked into Wang forever. Having tenders written for functional needs rather than specific requests is of great importance to manufacturers in all aspects of industry around Australia. It is one of the matters this Government simply has not attended to and it is about time the Minister did something about it. Australian manufacturers are not investing in plant and equipment. In substantiation, I refer to the recent correction--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you blame them?

—I agree with my colleague from Tasmania, Senator Watson, who said, `Can you blame them?'. In this climate, of course we cannot blame them. I refer to the recent correction from the Australian Bureau of Statistics whereby the figures for the growth of constant price, private gross fixed capital expenditure on equipment was written down from 11.8 per cent to 0.5 per cent for the September quarter 1987. Frankly, after 4 1/2 years of this Government and this Minister telling us how wonderfully well this industry policy is working, 0.5 per cent for the quarter ending September 1987 is not good enough-and that was before the stock market crash of October this year. What is happening in industry around Australia is of major concern.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that this Government's policies are not working. Notwithstanding the rhetoric or the high-powered publicity and the glossy publications, the policies simply are not working. Let us look at automobiles. This year, Australian production will fall to 1968 levels in the automobile industry despite the fact that this Government has had an automobile sectoral plan for about four years. Why has that happened? The Minister will try to say, `It is not my fault. We had to have a fringe benefits tax. We could not help the fall in the value of the dollar. We cannot really do anything about our high interest rates. We have to maintain them or the dollar will fall even more'. But it is his fault because he is No. 3 in this Government. It is the Government's fault that these things have been imposed on the economy and that the car industry is talking about production at 1968 levels. This Minister is No. 3 in this Government-so it is his fault that we are in this situation.

I add that, even if the car industry had achieved high sales, we would have had to find some means, other than wheels, for moving vehicles around, because car manufacturers say that there would not have been enough steel to produce the wheels necessary to cope with the number of vehicles which should normally have been produced had this Government not taken disastrous steps with regard to the fringe benefits tax and other economic policies. I have referred to glossy publications. Last Sunday, the Minister gave me a glorious opportunity by releasing the publication entitled Australian Industry: New Directions. This publication is most selective--

TALK.START.PARA: —Which way are we going now?
—As Senator Watson says, `Which way are we going now?'. The publication contains nonsenses such as a quotation from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not unrealistic to expect Australia to double its manufacturing exports in the next five years.

What nonsense that is. Anyone who looks at current investment in plant and equipment will know that it is simply not possible to achieve a doubling of manufacturing exports in the next five years. I will refer to the textile, clothing and footwear plan-the plan that never was. This plan was announced by the Minister with a lot of publicity and much hype. Right from the word go, the Minister said-and I quote from Hansard as recently as 5 June this year:
There were several principles which guided the Government during its consideration of an appropriate future strategy for these industries:
Predictability and stability of policy would be essential in such complex industries if they are to restructure and rationalise operations . . .

So the first and guiding principle of the Government was predictability and stability. What has this Minister done since then? There have been a whole lot of ministerial leaks about the possibility of changes to the textile, clothing and footwear plan, which is why I say it is the plan that never was. Last sitting week I twice gave the Minister an opportunity to deny those leaks that he and his Government are considering revising the plan.
