On each occasion, the Minister not only refused to deny that they were considering changing the plan, but he speculated further about changes to the plan-before the plan is implemented. The plan was announced in November last year and, as I say, repeated on 5 June this year, shortly prior to the election. One would not like to suggest that as at 5 June the Minister knew when the Prime Minister was going to call an election, but I bet he knew that it would be pretty close. At that stage he wanted to make sure that this industry was not going to be working against him in the course of the election. He made a great play about it on 5 June. But, come November 1987, four months later, he started to speculate about the plan being changed before it commences in March next year. That is the plan that never was.

TALK.START.PARA: —He wouldn't do that.

—Senator Button would not do that! Senator Button is marvellous at getting publicity. As I have said, his rhetoric is superb. I agree with about 90 per cent of what he says. The problem is that this Government simply does not perform to the extent that he says that it will.

SPEECH.PARA: The booklet refers to productivity figures for industry from 1979 to 1984. What about subsequent years? What about looking at the last couple of years? What happened to productivity in those years?

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell us. Come on, you tell us.

—We are waiting. The Minister and his Department have the figures. Why did they not have them published in the booklet? In any case, the Prime Minister's statement about doubling manufactures has little relevance because many manufacturers are so small that doubling their exports would be very insignificant against even a small increase in value added major exports such as coal, wool and minerals. It is absolutely essential that we do what we can to assist those industries. We need to ensure that those industries are not being given a rough deal by a lot of regulations which are in force at present. The Government would do well to look at regulations which work against those industries. Quite frankly, the booklet to which I have referred does not address the fundamental problems of high taxation, over-regulation, comparatively high interest rates and inflation, and inflexibility in the labour market.

SPEECH.PARA: As I am left with only three minutes in which to speak, let me refer finally to the editorial in today's edition of the Australian Financial Review. I thank the Australian Financial Review for bringing out this editorial on the day on which I have brought forward this matter of public importance. Under the heading `Why Australian companies should invest abroad', it says:
While total private investment within Australia increased by only 5 per cent in real terms over the past six years, Australian investment abroad has increased ninefold.
Over the past six years investment abroad has increased by 900 per cent, while investment in Australia has increased by only 5 per cent in real terms. The editorial went on to say:
One can hardly blame companies for investing overseas when the real rate of return-allowing for interest rates and corporate tax-is so low.

The article went on to suggest that those companies should invest off-shore. But what about the small manufacturer to whom I referred-the heart and soul of industries in this country which this Government is ignoring? How does that manufacturer invest off-shore if he already has all his funds tied up in investment in this country? It is that person to whom this Government must look in terms of doing something about interest rates, tax and providing flexibility in the labour market. This Government needs to introduce some of the policies which we in the Liberal and National parties have been advocating for five years. This Government has not adopted those policies. That is the reason this Government's industries policies have been a failure and continue to be a failure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The genesis of this matter of public importance is revealed by listening to Senator Lewis's speech. If he returned persistently to one theme, it was to the fact that I got a lot of publicity. He referred to that more than to anything else. Of course, he does not receive such publicity. However, the rather devious and broad-spraying attack-if I might call it that-that he made last Sunday on a publication called Australian Industry: New Directions achieved some publicity. I congratulate him on that; it is a good sign.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis's speech was a sort of grab-bag of ill-fitting concepts, suggesting that, in his role as shadow Minister, he wanders around Australian industry saying to everybody he meets, `What is your particular neurosis? Who is responsible for your problems? What can governments do to help you?'. So we get a collection of extraordinary things, such as `industry is too protected so we will have more government purchasing to protect it further' and `some industries are too protected and others are not'. He talked about the poor little mythical companies which have diabolical problems because of the things he ultimately came back to-interest rates, wages and so on. The argument does not hang together.

Let met go through a couple of the points which Senator Lewis made. He said that the Government is selling itself with hype, jargon and so-called plans. He identified the plans-steel, passenger motor vehicles and chemicals. There is no plan for the chemicals industry; there never has been. I am surprised that a shadow Minister should say that there is a sectoral plan for the chemicals industry. There is none. We reduced the tariffs in the chemicals industry, that is all. There is no plan. Senator Lewis had ample opportunity to talk about the other two plans-steel and passenger motor vehicles. He talked about steel at great length a month or two ago on the basis of Press reports. But there have been subsequent Press reports about the steel industry which he studiously ignored until I drew them to his attention. Senator Lewis says that the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Those reports suggest great confusion in industry, don't they?

—Yes-that is precisely the point I made in answer to questions at the time. Senator Lewis picked up some ratbag comment, came in here and accused me of attacking Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and so on. It is very silly to rely in this place on such reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis said that the passenger motor vehicle industry is not working. He said, `Look at automobiles; the market is down because of Government policies'. The honourable senator is precisely right. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in my presence, told the automotive industry a year ago when it complained about the reduced size of the market, the shoe is designed to pinch. What he meant by that was precisely this: this Government has faced up to the fact that we have had to have a decline in the Australian standard of living. One of the first industries to feel that, sadly, has been the motor vehicle industry. People have put off decisions about buying cars and so on. Is the honourable senator going to come in here and say that there has not been very significant, indeed massive, investment in the motor vehicle industry, that there has not been a significant improvement in technology and quality in the last year or two? That is what it is all about, is it not-investment, technology and quality? That has happened in the automotive industry and Senator Lewis knows it. When he discusses the automotive industry, he talks about the market; when he talks about something different, I do not know what criteria are in his mind. The main thing is the glossy publications to which he objects-the hype, the talk, the so-called plans, the jargon and so on. He said that the Government does not deliver.

Let us go to some of the things which Senator Lewis regards as important. He cannot just pick up these itsy-bitsy surveys all over the place, talk with a few manufacturers and decide that everything is going wrong. I am not saying that everything is going right. If we are making a transition from an economy which is totally dependent on commodities to an economy which is less dependent on commodities, we do not turn those things around overnight. There are many aspects to it, as the honourable senator's colleague the honourable member for Wentworth, ex-Professor Hewson, recognised in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 December. He simply makes the point that something is starting to happen in Australian management in the decade of the eighties, as he puts it. Ex-Professor Hewson, Liberal representative Hewson, says:

Until a few years ago . . . the mediocrity of Australian management was one of the best examples of the mediocrity of Australia. Fortunately, things may be changing. Since the turn of this decade, there have been some tentative, but . . . significant, changes. If this process is sustained, we could well look back on the 1980s as having fostered a managerial revolution of lasting significance.

The only point I make about that is that it is a very important factor in undergoing that transition from a period of dependence on commodity exports, on commodity output, which does not really require a great deal of initiative. Selling coal to a captive market, as we did in the 1960s and 1970s, does not require the same sorts of skills as are required in selling manufactured products-not the same sorts of skills at all. I think the danger in the honourable senator's position is this: true, there are high levels of achievement in Australian industry and poor levels of achievement. I draw Senator Lewis's attention to a document called Australia and the World: The Management Challenge, a document of the Australian Institute of Management which was published quite recently. Page 6 of that document mentions perceived issues in export growth, and compares companies described as high achievers with companies described as low achievers. Let us look at the issues which the low achievers regard as important. First of all, they regard price as the most important thing. Most of the issues which the honourable senator raised as being important relate to price. They are price-related factors. They regard demand as the second most important thing; they regard capacity as the third most important thing; finance is very important, and so on. They regard tariff barriers as very important, and distance from markets as important. In other words, they say it is all too hard. The high achieving companies list these as the most important factors: detailed planning, research and development, top management commitment-that is the highest factor amongst the high achieving companies-confidence, international marketing skills and quality. These are the factors which the high achievers stress as being important. They stress, for example, that tariff barriers are of very low importance.

The honourable senator should not, with respect, lock himself into a position of supporting the low achievers. What we have to do, and I think it is a collective exercise, is get more people out of the low achiever basket and into the high achiever basket. That is what this publication, Australian Industry: New Directions is all about. It is a bit of hype; I concede that. It is designed, in a sense, to be motivational, I concede that. I do not retreat from that at all. This document lists 300 companies which are making it in international markets in spite of all the dreadful things that the honourable senator says about the world. They are out there doing it-companies such as Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd, with $180m worth of exports. Perhaps it is in the right business, but it is no good our picking up those who are in the wrong business and saying that we have to look after them, because this economy cannot produce everything in the manufacturing sector; it cannot be competitive in all aspects of manufacturing. All the tables in this book illustrate that point. Senator Lewis ignored a lot of them. He was very concerned about wages. Have a look at the table on wages on page 18 of the report under the heading `Manufacturing wages in selected countries'. The low achievers still argue that the issue of wages is our most significant problem. Look at the relative wage rates for 1986, in Australian dollar terms, between Japan and Australia, between the USA and Australia and so on. It is an interesting document. All I am saying is that we do not want to get locked into that issue any longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you can't walk away from their problems, which you are doing in this debate today.
—I cannot walk away from whose problems?
—The low achievers' problems-you are saying let them die on the vine, let them wither.

—Not at all, Senator. I accept the disciplines of the market better than Senator Lewis does. Some of the low achievers will go to the wall, and some of them ought to. We have to face up to that. Look at the relative unit labour costs, on the previous page, compared with those of our trading partners. The honourable senator may well object that that table goes up only to March 1987, and at the time it was published the Syntec review was not available and we could not change the figures. But we cannot make this sort of thing a movable feast all the time, whereby we adjust all these figures to coincide with the day Senator Lewis is going to introduce a matter of public importance into the Senate. That would be an extraordinary exercise indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made some comments about what the honourable senator said about the motor vehicle plan. I concede in part some of the points he makes. We would like to do better with some of them, and we are. We would like every hamburger stall in Australia to be doing well, with government support, but that is not going to happen under this Government. All those things are highly desirable. But I want to come to what I perceive to be the main issues which the honourable senator, largely because I read what he says in the paper, listed at the end of his speech. Employment is an important issue, and manufacturing employment has stabilised in this country in the last three years. There should not be, as the honourable senator suggested, protected employment as a result of what he might have described as corporatism; that is, big companies, big unions and big government all combining to produce the car plan. It should not be done that way, and that was precisely the situation when the car plan was introduced. Read what I said, Senator. I said that employment in this industry would go down, down, down. I said the same in relation to the textile, clothing and footwear industries-that employment in those industries would go down. It is understood by the manufacturers and the unions in these industries that that will happen. It has to happen here because it is happening everywhere else, and this country can be no exception if we are to develop viable and efficient industries. Employment is an important issue.

The value of the Australian dollar is very important in terms of competitiveness. Senator Lewis chastises us about interest rates and other things, and it is appropriate that he should. But the value of the Australian dollar is very important in terms of competitiveness. Price competitiveness is one aspect of overall competitiveness. But we should not concentrate too much on it because if we get ourselves in a situation where the dollar appreciates significantly, Australian industries that have taken a window of opportunity because of price competitiveness arising from the fall of the dollar will lose it if they do not concentrate on other aspects of competitiveness, such as quality, design, good marketing and these sorts of things, as the sorts of companies mentioned in this `offensive' booklet are. Those are the sorts of things they are concentrating on. But the dollar value is important. The reason we had no significant manufacturing industry at the end of the Fraser Government's term of office was simply because the dollar had been kept overvalued for too long in order, as Mr Fraser put it himself, to try to keep the inflation rate down. That did not work either, but that is why the dollar was overvalued.

Senator Lewis raised the question of corporate tax. There is in this document a comparison of corporate tax rates. The Government is presently reviewing the corporate tax system. Let me say again and again that the present tax structure in Australia, compared with Japan, the United States and Canada, is not too bad.

TALK.START.PARA: —The primary rates.

—No, Senator, not the primary rate, not the nominal rate; the rate with the concessions that are quite deliberately built into this estimate here-the 5:3 depreciation, the research and development incentive and things such as that. I say it frankly outside this place, and I say it in here. If one is making hamburgers in Australia, for which one does no research and development, one is probably comparatively worse off than if one is making hamburgers in the United States. But we, with the greatest of respect to those who are, are not about encouraging the hamburger business as an export led or oriented business in this country. That is why the concessions are couched in the way that they are. One can make that comparison and say that one would be better off producing hamburgers in the United States of America. One might be.
—But why are you talking about taking away some of the concessions?

—That is a trade-off which would have to be discussed with the business community, and is being discussed and about which it is now making representations to us. It wants a lower tax rate and also concessions. It has to try to make up its mind as we have to as a Government. But one cannot have both.

SPEECH.PARA: In the United States, the concessions have been abolished and the overall rate of corporate tax has been lowered, but one cannot meet a businessman in the United States who does not say that, because of the Government's policies and its failure to tackle domestic and trade deficits, it is likely that corporate taxes in the United States will increase, which will take away Senator Messner at the knees, because he has been asking questions about that for a long time. Senator Lewis also drew attention to wages, which are important in terms of international competitiveness.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about flexibility in the labour market?

—Flexibility in the labour market is a very important issue. The Opposition can see that we are trying to work our way towards greater flexibility as a government but we are not about to throw the baby out with the bath water. One cannot sweep in and wave a magic wand which will produce labour flexibility overnight without creating a great deal of chaos.

SPEECH.PARA: The other issues, such as skills training, the contribution of the education system and industrial relations, are important. The table in Australian Industry: New Directions shows an appalling comparison between time lost in industrial disputes here and time lost in other countries. However, we are still about twice as good as the British on these figures. Ten years of Thatcherism experimentation have resulted, in 1986, in an appalling record of industrial relations. Our record is bad, but New Zealand's is worse, and Britain's is worse still. We are not good enough. We have an enormous way to go, and that is why, in answering questions, one has to use care. Senator Lewis asked about the steel industry, but in answering his questions I did not accede to his invitation to go around swatting people, because I do not think that that is the best way to handle it.

I am not concerned about Australian companies making significant investments overseas. I think that that is a sign of maturity in Australian industry. Most of those investments are in the transport sector and such areas, although there is some manufacturing, but it is mostly in transport. We are seeing the growth of world scale Australian companies, and that is a very good thing in many ways, because those companies will take others with them into international markets, and that is not a bad thing, so we should not be too concerned about that.

Policies in relation to the firm as an economic unit, and assisting firms as economic units, are very important. I do not have time to deal with this at great length now. The book Australian Industry: New Directions, which presumably Senator Lewis would have sent to the film censor, tries to deal with some of these issues in a positive way because we are in a process of transition, and the demonstration effects of good firms in the Australian industrial environment as a whole can be a tremendous benefit to helping us make that transition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the Opposition should have chosen these words to introduce its matter of public importance:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the underlying problems facing Australian industry.

The question itself contains the seeds of its own answer. It is clear that the Opposition does not perceive how clearly it has revealed the inadequacy of its analysis. What is industry, and what is the purpose of industry? It is self-evident that industry is the manufacture of goods and services, and the making of those goods and services available to those who need them-I say need, not want, quite deliberately. The purpose of industry in Australia, or indeed in any society, should be to meet better the needs of those people who are served. Problems such as there might be must be seen in this light. The question then becomes how well or poorly Australian industry is meeting the needs of Australians. Australian society does not exist to serve the needs of industry, but the other way around. To pose the question in the words of the Opposition is to imply that industry has needs which should override the needs of the people. What we have heard today confirms that the Opposition believes this.

The Opposition has other beliefs. Industry, presumably industry leaders and decision-makers, need larger profits, more loosening of control by the elected representatives-governments- and a politically and economically weakened work force, which is therefore more easily manipulated by management. Above all, market forces must be given free rein. Markets must determine our present and our future. We have heard from Senator Lewis how environmental constraints must be loosened because that will better fit the needs of industry.

There is a mythology which lies behind the Opposition's world views. It is powerful and pervasive, and it rejects evidence. It was touched on last night during the debate on petroleum exploration, dependence on fossil fuel and the development of renewable alternative energy forms. This mythology integrates certain beliefs and I thank the Opposition for raising this matter today, because it gives a further opportunity to lay to rest many of the idiocies in that mythology. Firstly, it says the environment available to be exploited by humans is infinite. Secondly, it says that infinite economic growth is both desirable and possible. Thirdly, it assumes that infinite technological innovation will solve problems of growth faster than they arise. Moreover, it believes that political and social problems can be solved through the application of more technology. Fourthly, it says that the model of continuous economic growth, which came into existence quite recently-only several hundred years ago, initially to explain the industrial revolution, but more recently intellectually to buttress and justify a continuation and intensification of industrialisation-is the norm of normal human behaviour and social organisation. I point out here that something approaching the human animal has been on earth for about two million years at least, and the last 200 years is not a model that can be projected into the future in that way. Fifthly, it makes the assumption that humans are infinitely adaptable and, as technology and industry change the human environment faster and faster, humans can infinitely adapt to those changes.

Unless we realise that this complex of beliefs is at variance with the real world, we shall fail adequately to address the perceived problems of any part of Australian industry. This complex of beliefs is held with religious fervour by many members of both the Opposition and the Government, and we have had a good presentation of this from Senator Button. I do not doubt that bringing reality into the thinking of both parties is not going to be easy, and I again thank the Opposition for the opportunity to explain quite simple facts yet again to those whose minds are so difficult to open.

The Australian Democrats is the only party which bases its policies fundamentally on an understanding of the relationship between homo sapiens and the environment. This understanding recognises our dependence on the continuing integrity of the natural environment. It recognises that the natural environment is finite and it recognises, moreover, that the human economy is simply a subset of the natural ecology. When I used that term yesterday, Senator Stone asked me what `subset' was. I was rather surprised that someone with a presumed mathematical background would have asked such a simple question but it perhaps indicates how little he understands of these things. I pointed out then that given that definition the human economy can expand only at the expense of the natural ecology.

The Democrats seek not a growth economy but a sustainable economy which will allow our descendants to live a quality life in balance with the ability of the natural environment to sustain indefinitely the impact which our human populations are placing upon it. Only the Democrats have their policies grounded in an understanding of biology and the physical sciences. Again, we heard Senator Stone and several other members of the Opposition laugh yesterday when I mentioned references from Science and Nature. I think one at least had never even heard of the journal Nature. I point out that they are the two most widely read scientific journals in the whole world. Only the Democrats understand the full consequences of the rapidly escalating and unsustainable impact of human populations on the natural environment. Only the Democrats are attempting to integrate this understanding into policies which relate not only to industry but also to the totality of human social organisation and direction. That is the point that Senator Sanders was attempting to pick up when he said that the Democrats are trying to change the total social structure. That is what we are really about, because unless we do there is very little future. I will go on to explain that in a moment.

Let us take a few specific examples to illustrate the radical difference between the Democrats' approach and that of the Laborials. The coal industry is said to be in poor shape. Prices per tonne on world markets have been falling. The solution proposed by the Laborials is to find ways of selling more coal. The Government seeks to reduce royalties and government charges on the coal industry. The Opposition seeks to reduce the wages of workers and the so-called power of the trade unions, and its soul mates, those who own the mines, are encouraged to become even more capital intensive with fewer workers producing ever more coal. Yesterday's Age contained a congratulatory article about the deal to export $197m worth of coal each year to Turkey until the year 2014. No doubt the Laborials think such contracts great. What they fail to recognise, or deliberately shut their eyes to, is that this approach to solving `the problems facing Australian industry' is taking us, and more particularly our descendants, down a blind alley from which it will be harder and harder to implement real, viable solutions.

Yesterday Senator Sanders mentioned the 10-volume Energy 2000 report published in 1986 by the then Department of Resources and Energy while it was under Senator Evans. Those 10 volumes used the words `carbon dioxide' once only, in a single sentence which referred to the greenhouse effect. Neither the Minister nor his Department is making judgments about industries-which they clearly hope will extend well into the twenty-first century, as indicated by the coal export contract going to the year 2014-based on the best scientific evidence relating to global consequences of those industries, consequences which will radically affect every aspect of life on the face of the planet. Is it that the Government does not care about these consequences because, of course, it will not be in government and will not have to deal with them in the year 2014, 2020 or 2040? I hope that is not the case. Is it that it is ignorant? That is not credible.

Honourable senators will remember Professor David Suzuki speaking to the Commission for the Future on the environmental constraints within which human society and particularly industry must operate if humans are to survive and enjoy a human and humane existence. Professor Suzuki's address to the Commission was broadcast on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Science Show. Professor Suzuki had been invited to Australia by the Commission, which received a rocket from this Government for extending that invitation. Professor Suzuki's message is one which this Government would rather not have heard in Australia: it might cause Australians more closely to question the short-sighted-one might say deliberately blinkered-view of the future which both Government and Opposition would attempt to sell to the Australian public. It was G. K. Chesterton who said:

There is nothing in front but a great wilderness of standardisation either by Bolshevism or Big Business. But it is strange that some of us should have seen sanity, if only in a vision, while the rest go forward chained eternally to enlargement without liberty and progress without hope.

It is that vision which the Australian Democrats hold before the Australian people. To provide another example in the energy area which Senator Button has also referred to, and I think Senator Lewis referred to it earlier, I refer to the so-called Button car plan. Speaker after speaker on the Opposition side of the Senate spoke last night and this morning on the dire future facing Australia through a shortage of liquid fuels. Repeatedly it was said that Australia was one of the poorest prospective oil regions in the world and estimates were given as to how many billions of dollars it would cost this country each year for oil imports by the mid-1990s. There is nothing wrong with the analysis so far, but the Opposition's solution to this problem-an opposition blindly wedded to bigger is better-is to spend vast sums of money exploring for oil which may not be there. Even if it is, going down that road just puts off the day of reckoning because oil is a non-renewable resource and each new production means the next barrel is harder and more expensive to find. Apparently members of the Opposition have not heard of the second law of thermodynamics.

The sensible alternative is to use our oil much more efficiently. Oil itself is not what is desired; it is the services which oil makes available that are desired. Transport consumes the largest single slice of Australia's oil and private transport the largest amount of the total transport sector. The fuel costs of transport are made up of two components-the cost per litre and the number of litres used getting from A to B. Cars which consume fuel at half the rate of the average Australian car are already in use. They are not in wider use because of the fixed costs of car ownership relevant to the costs of car use. As I indicated last night, the market responds to present or instantaneous supply and demand. It cannot and does not take into account future shortages or indeed the legitimate demands which future generations will make against those same non-renewable resources. Given the long lead time required for the car industry to tool up for new and different models, it would have made a great deal of sense if the so-called Button car plan had incorporated as one of its prime objectives making the Australian car stock substantially more fuel efficient.

There are a number of other points that I would like to have made but in summary I simply say that what is missing from both the Government's policy in relation to industry and the Opposition's criticism of that policy is any understanding of the environmental consequences of the policies being followed and the way in which they will intersect within the lifetime of our children and our grandchildren-those whom we will know in our lives-and the consequences they will have for our industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's failure to address the underlying problems facing Australian industry, which my colleague Senator Austin Lewis has brought before the Senate this afternoon, includes the failure of the Hawke Labor Government to address itself to government expenditure, the current account deficit, high taxation and the lack of incentive in the taxation system. There has been a lack of attention to the high inflation rate in Australia, a lack of attention to our foreign debt, and a lack of attention to high interest rates-which are most probably one of the greatest disincentives to industry in Australia-and to specify work practices, industrial relations and transport.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has failed, despite all the claims made by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, that the economy is on the right track, and despite statements by other members of this Government, including Senator Button, that we are on the right track. Government spending has increased at an annual rate of 3.9 per cent in the four years of the Hawke Labor Government. It is interesting to note that in the seven years of the coalition Government, government expenditure rose by only 2.1 per cent on average. Total government spending is now in excess of $80 billion, which represents about $5,000 a head for every man, woman and child in Australia.

This Government has had the opportunity to do something since 1984. When it came into office the domestic economy was on the upturn, the drought had broken and the effect of the Fraser Government's wages pause was really helping the economy. But this Government's 1984 Budget comprised a 6 per cent real increase in outlays, which we are still paying for. Because of the Government's major failure to seize this opportunity, we are still paying the price for what this Government could have done and should be doing now-that is, cutting that government expenditure.

What about the balance of trade and the current account deficit? Since May 1985, practically all monthly current account figures have been around the $1 billion mark. It is interesting to note that every time those balance of trade figures and current account deficit figures come down, the Government skites about them if there is less than a $1 billion deficit in a particular month. In 21 of the 30 months since May 1985 we have had a deficit of over $1 billion. The total for 1986-87 is some $13 billion plus, and we have had no indication that things will change. It is interesting to note that the former Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), in a statement on future trade initiatives in May 1985, said:
It is vital that as a government, we implement policies to ensure success. Our primary goal is to maintain the economy in a position of sustained non-inflationary growth.
The annual trade deficit for the end of 1985 was $881m in the red, and it was some $3 billion in the red the next year. Obviously, the only growth was in the size of the deficit.
The reason I mentioned Mr Dawkins is that we have now had Senator Button making this statement in the foreword to a publication entitled Australian Industry: New Directions:
The emphasis is now on international competitiveness, export orientation, research and development, innovation and marketing.
He went on to say:
The extent of change occurring in Australia industry is significant and highlights our capacity to adjust. This report outlines the major restructuring . . .
He said further on:
The challenge is for Australia to use and develop its rich natural, technical and human resources in a way which maximises our growth prospects in world trade.
I ask: Will that foreword be as pathetic as Minister Dawkins's statement some years ago? Will those things be realised? Under the Hawke Labor Government, I doubt that they will.

What about taxation? Government tax revenues have increased some 61 per cent under this Hawke Labor Government. They have increased from some $44 billion to $65 billion this year. The figure for all levels of government in 1986-87-Federal, State and local government-is some $81 billion. As a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP), which is the total value of all goods and services produced in a year on which a value can be placed, it is some 30.8 per cent.

Let us look at the foreign debt. Australia is now one of the top debtor nations in this world, ranking with countries such as Israel, Mexico and Argentina. Total foreign debt has increased from $13.6 billion in 1980 to $110 billion now. A lot of that has been caused by money that has been borrowed overseas that could not be borrowed in Australia because of high interest rates. Estimates are that Australia's net external debt is approximately 32 per cent of our GDP as at June 1987-that is, approximately $90 billion. Simply to prevent that net external debt position from worsening further, Australia's trade balance would have to improve by at least $10 billion. When one considers that exports of the rural community account for some 30 per cent of those exports in 1986-87, which total $13.7 billion, one realises that the improvements needed to generate an extra $10 billion, just so that we do not recede any further, are enormous. It will require all sectors of the community, especially manufacturing, to make a contribution to reducing Australia's debt.

Australia's inflation rate continues to be considerably above the average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries. Their average annual rate for 1986-87 was 3.5 per cent and Australia's was 9.3 per cent. By comparison, Japan has an inflation rate of about 0.4 per cent, the United States of America about 3.9 per cent, and West Germany, 0.7 per cent. With the collapse of the stock market, to which Senator Lewis has already alluded this afternoon, the pressures will make even more unlikely the fulfilment of the prediction of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of 6 per cent inflation by the middle of next year.

Of course, high interest rates, which I have already mentioned, have constantly been a pressure on industry and the trading sector of the economy. Our interest rates have been constantly higher than all other OECD countries. Despite repeated comments by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister that interest rates would fall-even Ministers in this place have said so-only recently have we seen any downward movements. As I have already said, they will be affected by the stock market crash and they will affect the industrial climate of this country.

Several specific factors affect industrial development and these issues deserve special emphasis. I have already mentioned the first issue, which is industrial relations. Let me quote again from Minister Dawkins's speech in 1985 regarding the progress in the national economic situation brought about by the Government:

This has involved the successful operation of the prices and incomes accord . . . the resultant stability in business and general economic conditions has been a factor in the strong recovery of investment. As well, the fact that the incidence of industrial disputation has been at its lowest level for 17 years has significantly enhanced our reputation for reliability of supply.

This Government has consistently prided itself on its industrial relations policies. The reality is somewhat different. Figures for industrial disputation over the last couple of years have declined only marginally. More significantly, the number of working days lost has again increased steadily from 1983 until this year. Of course, this is the year in which the Government completely caved in to the unions' wage demands.

There is a big cost to industry due to industrial disputes. Individual companies must take action to protect themselves against the action of unions. For example, in the car industry, where manufacturers are trying to trim inventory with the just in time system, a fear of bare assembly lines causes many to cling to just in case supplies. Management at General Motors-Holden's Ltd says that car companies build in as much as 15 days inventory supply to offset delays on the waterfront. This stock is worth more than $30m-odd. The recent dispute at Cooldrive Consolidated Industries in Victoria demonstrates just how dangerous industrial action can be for firms attempting to cut costs in this manner. It simply makes them more vulnerable to attack by unions. Some firms, such as Mitsubishi, hold an inventory off-shore to reassure overseas clients that industrial disputes will not affect delivery.

Wage costs have already been mentioned by Senator Lewis. A second major aspect obviously connected to the Government's inability to implement a policy on industrial relations conducive to the improvement of industry in this country is its failure to reduce real wage costs. Labour costs remain a major burden on the economy. As I have already said, the Government has extolled the virtues of its wages accord, yet since 1983 average weekly earnings have risen significantly. If this country's economy and its industry are to succeed they need a reduction in real wage costs and add on costs. Such a reduction is, in fact, a necessity. To improve the balance of payments by $1 billion we would need a reduction of just over one per cent in real wage costs, assuming that these costs to employers include items such as payroll tax and superannuation. A reduction in real wage costs of this magnitude-of one per cent-would increase exports by some 3 per cent. At the same time imports would fall by one per cent; aggregate employment would rise by one per cent; and gross domestic product would increase by 0.6 per cent.

Despite all its rhetoric that we Australians must tighten our belts to improve our overall economic competitiveness, the Government has failed to take steps to ensure that real wage costs are reduced. This Government has really failed to develop policies on restrictive wage costs to assist industry. This Government stands condemned for its failure to stamp out the abuses of union power. Restrictive work practices are not legitimate work practices but rather extortionate demands that the employer ignores at his peril. They have nothing to do with work safety or efficiency. Examples can be found in most industries, but particularly in the shipping and stevedoring industries which you, Mr Deputy President, have highlighted in this chamber. Two examples are, firstly, two-crew manning systems where two crews are rostered on for 26 weeks and off for 26 weeks, necessitating all positions to be unnecessarily duplicated; and secondly, overmanning, featherbedding and excessive crew numbers. Australia has 15-man stevedoring gangs while England and America have only four-man gangs. The effects on the Australian economy are disastrous.

Domestic transport costs are another area of major Government failure. In a country that is as big and diverse as ours, the Government has failed to assist the transport industry by removing some of the underlying problems. Transport costs in this country are exorbitant, compared with those in other countries and with international charges. For example, it costs Comalco Aluminium Ltd 44 per cent more to transport Australian steel from Port Kembla to Fremantle than from Fremantle to Japan. Waterfront costs account for about 75 per cent of shipping goods across Bass Strait. According to some figures it can cost as much to load cargo in Australia as it does to ship it most of the way to Europe. This Government stands condemned for the fact that it has not addressed itself to the underlying problems facing Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise to speak on the matter of public importance raised in the Senate this afternoon by the Opposition. For the sake of those who might be listening, I wish to spell out this matter of public importance. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to address the underlying problems facing Australian industry.

The first point I need to make about the matter of public importance is that it has been brought up this afternoon by an Opposition which, over quite a number of years, had an opportunity to confront some of the problems that we have had to meet in government over the last four years. Members of the Opposition when in government were quite haphazard and inadequate in their response to these problems. It should be noted that even in the last week at least a few members of the Opposition have recognised that their policies are still inadequate to face the problems that exist, not only in Australian industry but also in the whole ambit of the Australian economy. In recent days we have had a continuation of the saga from Queensland-the Stone and Sparkes show on the one hand as opposed to the Howard and Peacock show on the other, the end result of which is that the former Secretary to the Treasury, in passing a comment on the adequacy of his current colleagues and their handling of the economy, has basically said that they are unfit to govern. I think that has been the judgment of the Australian people for quite some time and it will continue to be so if the level of input from the Opposition is what it has been during the debate today.

One does not deny the fact that there have been problems in the Australian economy and in Australian industry. Senator Chaney may laugh at that, but I am sure that if he were in a position of responsibility he would also have to confront those policies. However, being the reasonable bloke that he is, he may not have the same sort of success as our relevant Ministers have had. The problems basically stem from two levels-the historical problems and the current problems. Both levels of problems are interrelated. We have inherited very high tariff barriers. This Government has been extremely assiduous about trying to rectify that sector of policy. We remember coming into the Senate time after time when the now Opposition spokespeople were Ministers and hearing them say that our future and our economic resurgence depended on primary industry, whether it was the agricultural sector or the resources boom. We were promised by a whole list of Liberal senators and Ministers, particularly before elections, that massive booms in these areas in the primary industry sector would be the salvation of the Australian economy. In government we have had to meet problems related to the drop in our terms of trade. The other lingering problem that we had to confront was one of distrust between the Government, the Opposition and the unions. Senator Stone in his former position as Secretary to the Treasury was quite keen to engender division. His were the policies of confrontation and this Government has had to meet and resolve the legacy of that confrontation. Of course, we have had the legacy of the structural foreign debt from the Howard-Stone days. I am continually amazed by the fact that Senator Stone can come into this Parliament, somewhat cleansed of all his previous sins, mistakes and indiscretions as the Secretary to the Treasury, and ask us to believe that he is now a changed person with a new direction.

Let us look at the new direction of the Hawke Labor Government. It has been a direction that has acknowledged the need for major adjustment in industry. It has been a direction which is based on the consultative process of progress. Let us compare that with the policies of the current Opposition. To find them one has to look at a whole list of spokespeople-Howard, Stone, Peacock, Carlton, Hewson, Sparkes, Sinclair, not to mention the minor players, Lewis and Messner. There are nine of them. On any particular day one might go to any one of them and come up with any response, but common to their responses are those principles that Senator Walsh has espoused here time and again-voodoo economics, and a sledgehammer approach to both the business sector and unions. But the underlying factor in all this has been a haphazard approach to the economy.

The basis of the Opposition's matter of public importance debate today has been the two claims which Senator Lewis made in this House today and in the Press in the last few days. The first is that the Australian economy has to suffer high levels of taxation. Let us look at that in terms of our international competitiveness. Our tax levels are the second lowest as indicated in a recent Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) survey of OECD countries. But despite that, the Australian Government is still reviewing the corporate taxation system. This review, which has been going on for some months, is part of an overall review of the taxation system.

Let us look at the corporate tax system. By comparison with OECD standards the Australian corporate sector has an extremely low level of taxation-the second lowest at 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product compared with the OECD average of 3 per cent. Not only can we compare Australian taxation levels very favourably with those of the rest of the world, but importantly for the course of this debate we can also compare them extremely favourably with the rates of taxation that the Australian business and private sector had to face under the Howard-Stone regime.

The second claim made by Senator Lewis is that the Government has presided over an inflexible labour market. Nothing could be further from the truth. The basic principle of the Government's policy in this area has been one of flexibility and co-operation. We have consulted with unions and peak industry sectors and we have taken advantage of the flexibility that has resulted from the depreciation in the value of the Australian dollar. But we are cognisant of the fact that unless we are cautious, we could very quickly fall into a recession and end up with a wages spiral.

Compared with our major trading partners, real unit labour costs, adjusted for exchange variations, now see Australia more competitive than it has been at any time since the early 1970s. The Opposition, in its ideologically based jingoism, does not seem to acknowledge or even recognise this empirical fact. The Opposition does not even recognise that over the last six years-since 1981-82-real unit labour costs have decreased by 8 per cent. The Australian wage and salary earner has made a major sacrifice that the Opposition does not seem to acknowledge.

I turn to industry policy-a policy on which one needs to spend some time-and rebut the claims of the Opposition. The Australian Government's industry policy is very clearly thought out. It is espoused very succinctly in the booklet that has been the subject of debate this afternoon-Australian Industry: New Directions-and stands up to scrutiny. The policy is based on four premises: first, there is a need to revitalise and restructure mature industries by the application of new technology and management practices; secondly, we recognise the need to foster new industries and activities by enhancing competitive strengths; thirdly, we support the development and diffusion of generic technologies-biotechnology, new materials, infra-technology, manufacturing technology-and recognise that these areas are basic to Australian international competitiveness in the 1990s; and fourthly, we acknowledge and we work towards living within the link between Australian industry and world economics. I do not have enough time to go through all of the Government initiatives in pursuance of these policies. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a list of 23 initiatives that over the last four years have been taken by the Australian Government-initiatives which cover the areas of research and development, national industry extension services, support for technology and business efficiency, development finance, trade promotion, offsets programs and industry sectoral plans.
