TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The responses fall within three categories. On the sectoral level, the vehicle industry plan is an important one. There is a history of opposition and resistance in this place to that plan. Honourable senators should compare the repeated intransigence of the Opposition when the plan was being developed with the current success of the plan. The value of export components is up from $277m in 1982 to $463m in 1986, and the plan is just starting to work.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of assistance plans, at June 1987 the management investment companies programs had provided a much needed $170m to companies in need of venture capital. At the same time, money and resources have been made available under the grants for industry research and development plan to small, innovative firms, especially those in the area of generic technologies.

I cannot leave this topic without mentioning the massive success of the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC). Under the Fraser Government the AIDC had assets worth in the vicinity of $962.7m. Its range of assets has now increased to $2 1/2 billion. In terms of its areas of activity, one can see that it is pivotal to Australian industry restructuring and redevelopment. The AIDC participates in industry restructuring ranging from heavy engineering, raw materials, processing programs and the white goods industry in which it has been extremely successful. Also, it provides finance, research and advice in fields as diverse as new technology, malaria vaccine, underwater robotics and biotechnology. The AIDC is a perfect example of the Government's approach. It has carefully chosen areas in which to assist industry; it has chosen to support innovative and growing enterprises within the industry sector.

The time allocated for me to speak in this debate is drawing to an end, but I make a final point. The Australian people have been presented with a very clear choice during this debate. On the one hand we have a government which has a superb economic record in terms of getting Australia back on the track.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—Senator Stone may laugh. He was Secretary to the Department of the Treasury.
—One hundred and ten billion dollars of debt-going up by $11 1/2 billion a year. What a superb economic record!

—If Senator Stone stops squawking for a while, I will read the advice that he, as Secretary to the Treasury, provided to Mr John Howard when he was his Treasurer during his last period of influence in Australian politics. In March 1983 the honourable senator, together with Mr Howard, presided over an economy which led him to write to Mr Howard as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Due to a series of post-Budget expenditure decisions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Does not Senator Stone like to hear the truth?
—I suggest that the honourable senator address the Chair.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, the honourable senator has just made a token response. Let me read the sort of advice that Senator Stone was forced to give because of his joint responsibility in the destruction of the Australian economy between 1978 and 1983. In March 1983 the last advice-the last rites-that he gave to the Fraser-Howard-Stone trifecta was:

SPEECH.PARA: Due to a series of post-Budget expenditure decisions, and slower than expected economic activity it is now estimated that outlays in 1982-83 will reach $48.7m, $1.6 billion higher than budgeted and 18 per cent higher than the previous year.
A man who could not add up now expects us to believe that he can. No matter how many calculators he has bought in the last four years, they will do him no good. He went on to advise:

When the estimated cost in 1984-85 of the new policy proposals is added, the prospect is for a Budget deficit of almost $10 billion. Such a deficit would be equivalent to 5 1/2 per cent of projected GDP, the highest in Australian post-war history.

This is the last testament to the Howard-Stone-Fraser trifecta. As I said at the start of my contribution, the Leader of the National Party has amazing gall to come into this place, together with his consorts in the Opposition, and try to argue the high economic moral ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Lewis on behalf of the Opposition, which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to address the underlying problems facing Australian industry.

It says a lot for Senator Bolkus's sense of humour that in his contribution to the debate he could talk about the economy being in good shape. I do not intend to waste the quarter of an hour allocated to me responding to Senator Bolkus. But since he chose to quote Senator Stone in another day and role, I suggest that he read what Mr Whitlam had to say in the last couple of days in a letter to the Australian Financial Review about the economic performance of the present Government. He compared the comparative economic statistics of this Government with those of the Government he headed, a government that the present Government's Ministers widely and openly acknowledge was an economic disaster but which, as Mr Whitlam pointed out, in comparative terms with the rest of the world, was performing in many respects better than the Hawke-Keating Government.

Let me return to the reasons the Opposition has brought forward a debate on the problems facing Australian industry. For the people of Australia, 4 1/2 years of Labor government have brought declining living standards. Mr Acting Deputy President, you represent the State of New South Wales for the Australian Labor Party. The simple reality is that your constituents have, during the course of this Government, seen their living standards decline. In Question Time today Government Ministers proudly indicated that real wages have declined under the Hawke-Keating Labor Government. That is a strange boast for a series of Labor Ministers to make, but it is the harsh reality that faces the people of Australia. The odd thing is that we have suffered these declining personal living standards at a time when Australia has got more deeply into debt. Our net foreign debt has gone up to nearly four times the amount it was.

In other words, it is not a case of our borrowing to maintain our living standards; we have been forced to borrow and at the same time see our living standards decline. Now every man, woman and child in Australia is overhung by thousands of dollars worth of debt and there is no sign of that debt decreasing. Indeed, the Government's Budget which was brought down only last August by Mr Keating says that that debt is increasing still further. Australia's great rise in debt is occurring at a time when the price of many of our basic commodities has improved.

The Government cannot point to the continuing decline in our terms of trade as the reason for our continuing problems because some of Australia's commodities are receiving good prices: wool is one, gold is another, and the price of aluminium has firmed somewhat. We have found some improvement in the basic large volume commodities that Australia lives on. Yet the situation of individual Australians continues to decline. We have continuing high trade deficits. The trade figures which came out today indicate a further decline in our situation with respect to imports and so on. We have a significant problem which faces us and which directly impacts on every man, woman and child in Australia.

The Government has been trying to get out of any debate on this issue by saying that Australia is much better off than other countries. But the foreign debt under which Australia now labours amounts to 40 per cent of our gross domestic product (GDP). In other words, what we owe overseas is equal to 40 per cent of the total production of this country in any year. That compares with a gross foreign debt in the United States of America of 13 per cent of its GDP. So Australia is actually in a quite perilous position. The public relations effort of the Government is the one thing that is to be commended, but the simple reality is that the country is in a knife-edge situation. With a softening of commodity prices we would face the prospect of a further significant worsening of our balance of trade. Therefore, we would see great pressure on our dollar and the whole future of the Australian economy put at enormous risk, which would of course affect the living standards of Australians.

What is the answer to all this? How is Australia to get out of its predicament? The answer is quite simple. As a country we have to produce more; we have to become a wealthier country by producing more. We have to increase our productivity and our investment. The Government likes to look at what the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has been saying about Australia. The OECD report on Australia published in March 1987 refers to the investment that is needed to increase our national wealth. Page 49 of that report states:
. . . if most of the shift to tradable goods were to occur through an expansion in manufacturing . . .

This is the area for which Senator Button is responsible and which we have been basically talking about in this debate. If we are to get an increase in our tradable goods through expansion in manufacturing this sector would need to raise output by at least one-third between 1986 and 1991. This is a very significant challenge for us. The OECD is saying that we would need to raise output by at least one-third between 1986 and 1991. It goes on to say:

Although some of this is likely to be made up from existing capacity, increased investment is certain to be needed. Total private business investment is now at historically low levels, its share in GDP amounting to 9.5 per cent compared to 12 to 13 per cent for 1965 to 1972.

The one thing we will not hear Senator Cook talking about when he contributes to this debate is the level of private investment in the early 1980s, which was very high. We will not hear Senator Cook drawing that sort of comparison or talking about the continued abysmal, frightening and dangerously low levels of investment which have occurred under this Government.

We do have an industry Minister-the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button)-and he participated in this debate. He made a rather smart alec and personal attack on Senator Lewis instead of dealing with the substance of the debate. He is a Minister who has presided over continuing abysmally low levels of investment. He thereby presides over a situation which guarantees the continuance of our very severe problems. That is the simple fact. All of the pointing to the good examples contained in Senator Button's glossy booklet of success will not do away with the fact that, unless Senator Button can achieve a sharp rise in investment in industry in this country, we are doomed economically. That is the sorry situation that we are debating. This is not some abstruse, obscure, irrelevant, academic, economists' debate. This is a debate which goes to the living standards of the men and women of Australia. These are the men and women that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I represent. These are the men and women who are seeing their living standards decline.

I said that the OECD referred to the need to increase manufacturing, to have a raising of output by at least one-third between 1986 and 1991. This is a very significant challenge for the Minister, who was at the table and who contributed in his smart alec way to this debate. I will not in any way try to fudge the issue. I now refer to the report of the Minister's own Department that was brought into the Parliament quite recently. Here we are chasing an increase in output by one-third over a five-year period. Is Senator Button presiding over something that looks as though it might achieve that sort of objective? I invite you, Mr Acting Deputy President, on your flight back to Sydney at the end of the week when you are contemplating a well-earned break, to look at his Department's annual report and at what it says about the manufacturing sector and its production. What happened to it in the last year? It went down by 0.5 per cent. Senator Button-who said that Senator Lewis does not like the nice publicity he gets-is presiding over a manufacturing sector which had declining output, according to the annual report of his Department. It is about time Senator Button was a little less smart alec, and a little less skilful at describing, as he does quite effectively, some of the things that are required for success, and started to come to grips instead with the reasons why we have such widespread failure.

Over the last few years the Opposition has been as supportive as it could be of the positive aspects of the Government's industry plans. We have taken a positive stance because we believe that the problems of this country are large. We believe that in a sense those problems are beyond politics. If the Government is prepared realistically and courageously to try to solve some of Australia's problems, it should have the support of the Opposition. Therefore, to the extent that industry plans have involved accepting the reality of the need for greater international competitiveness and a movement towards that, we have supported them. I had intended to quote in this debate some of my own remarks about the reservations we had about what we saw as a bureaucratic approach to industry policy on the part of the Government; but I do not think time permits. I just compare what Senator Button conceded in an interview with the Australian on 7 December 1987. He said:
In some ways the steel plan was the worst thing I ever did . . . Worst in the sense that everybody liked it so everybody started to come here and say `Well, we want a steel plan too'.
Some industries . . . need a plan like they need a hole in the head.
The problem with the plans as such is that they tend to be bureaucratic, which Australians love, and that doesn't add to your competitive advantage.
I wish that Senator Button had been gracious enough to stop and consider some of the things that the Opposition had been saying to him over the last few years. In October 1986 I said:

Australian producers have a history of seeking, and obtaining, very specific guidance and assistance. Broad guidance is fine, but there is a very fine line between a benign and helping hand and being told your next move:

I might be wrong, but I imagine that part of the appeal of the Car Plan, the Steel Plan, the more recent heavy Engineering Assistance package, is the fairly explicit direction they give. I get the distinct impression from many of the business people I meet that to be handed your very own industry plan, with its own administrative board, is the ultimate dream.

. . . I am a little sceptical of these industry-specific plans, although I applaud their stated aims. If they help change attitudes and promote interaction and co-operation between related industries and between management and employees, that is welcome. But to the extent that they can be used as a shield against the need for more rapid adjustment, I think we must remain cautious.
In particular, I doubt if Australia has the time to adopt the bureaucratic approach to removing restrictive work practices which is part of the Heavy Engineering plan.

My simple point is that this Government has adopted an approach which has in many respects inhibited Australian manufacturers facing up to the reality which they cannot escape. The miserable investment record under this Government is a sure sign of the fundamental failure that we are presently witnessing.

I am sorry that this debate is not a longer one. I conclude my contribution by saying that the Opposition has, in a quite explicit way, set out that it believes that we will not get the new investment in Australia which is required until we meet four broad requirements. We believe that there must be reduced and restructured taxes, made possible by reduced government spending; we believe that there must be reduced and less costly regulation of business activity; we believe that there must be a restoration of the rule of law in industrial relations and a flexible labour market; and we believe that there must be rigorous control and reduction of business input costs, especially government taxes and charges.

It is all very well for Senator Button to say that he encourages Australian investment abroad; so does the Opposition. But if Australian investment abroad is due to the fact that people are simply not prepared to invest in their own country, and if we are no longer an attractive destination for investment by foreigners, we will never work our way out of the hole that we are now in. The pathetic approach to reform of industrial relations and wages policy, which has been a hallmark over recent years, is one of the major reasons why this country has continued to decline. The total failure of Senator Button, widely acclaimed as a successful Minister, to face up to the realities of the environment for carrying on business in this country, is something that will haunt him for the rest of his days.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, of course, the role of oppositions to oppose and, in opposing, often they can fall into the role of being destructive, carping and negative. That is what we have seen this afternoon. In rising to close the debate on behalf of the Government, I draw attention to the huge absence in any of the speeches by Opposition senators of an alternative proposal. We had, from Senator Chaney as he closed the debate for the Opposition, a cadet actor's attempt at modulating his voice after the manner of amateur theatrics. He talked about investment and concluded with the door slamming application of his magnificent four points-matters concerning tax, government expenditure, industrial relations and business regulation. All of those points are trite in the sense that, while they deal with subjects, nothing that has been said by either Senator Chaney or, indeed, the person who led this debate, Senator Lewis, explains what exactly they propose to do. They sit back and criticise what is being done. They try to cast a negative pall over what have been some benchmark successes in our industry approach. Senator Chaney, in the latter part of his speech, concentrated on wringing his hands and directing personal gibes towards Senator Button. He has concentrated on doing exactly what he accused Senator Button of doing. He has tried to empty a bucket over the most popular and successful industry Minister that this country has seen.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that we expected something better from Senator Lewis, who opened the debate. We expected something pithy, earthy and with some content. We got an exercise in the negative and the trivial. One could say that the speech of Senator Lewis was deeply superficial. What did he speak about? He spoke about the problems that he believed existed in that not everyone had an industry plan. I draw attention to the fact that Australia has a mixed economy.

It is not the intention of this Government to intervene willy-nilly across the board in this economy. It is the intention of the Government to target industry plans in specific areas where there is need. That is not so in every area. That some areas do not have a plan is not an indication of failure; it is an indication that other industries, in the competitive climate in which they have to dwell and succeed, are concentrating on getting on with business. It is odd for someone aspiring to be a believable spokesman on industry policy-someone who I believe supports at least a mixed economy or a market economy-to call for more, and larger, diversified plans. The other matter he talked about was how one writes tenders and whether the Commonwealth writes them properly. That is a massive contribution to informed debate in this country! All the other matters he spoke of were matters that Senator Button demolished in his reply.

The fundamental weakness in what members of the Opposition have put forward is the lack of a credible, cohesive or believable alternative model. Until they come up with some new ideas, some policy directions that can be contrasted with what the Government is doing, all that they propose are merely carping criticisms-criticisms that paint them as negative, destructive and defensive. This Government is trying to get on the front foot, and is succeeding in doing so, in industry policy, to convince Australians-I refer by way of example to the booklet that the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has produced, which has been the subject of some criticism here-by way of role models that success is possible, that innovation is achievable and is a fact of life in Australia today, that companies can win significant export contracts, and that there are ways in which one can succeed in industry in Australia. By holding up those role models-an important act in itself for the rest of industry-we will encourage industry to try a bit harder, get its settings right and be more successful in terms of exports, import replacement and, indeed, in terms of its whole business operation. That is what the booklet is about.

It seems that this whole debate about fundamentals in industry policy is an attack upon a so-called `glossy' produced by the Department. If honourable senators opposite want it to be produced in a matt finish rather than in a glossy finish, I am sure that can be organised. The significant thing about the book, overlooked by all Opposition contributions, is that it gives specific examples. It names names; it produces records; it shows that excellence in Australia is achievable by industry and, by so doing, points the way to other industries to follow suit. However, we have seen a series of basically unsubstantiated, superficial and narrow interpretations.
I want to reply to this matter of public importance, as it is called, by referring to its terms:
The Government's failure to address the underlying problems facing Australian industry.

That is what we are supposed to be debating. A benchmark statistic that has been seemingly ignored by the Opposition is that in the years 1986 to 1987 export of Australian manufactures grew by 25 per cent in nominal terms and by 14 per cent in real terms. That represents a significant growth in the number of manufactured goods exported from Australia. It compares with the figure for real average annual growth of 4.9 per cent between the years 1977-78 and 1983-84-years in which the Opposition, which has launched this matter of public importance, occupied the treasury bench and was responsible for industry policy. Our performance, as evidenced by a 25 per cent nominal rate and 14 per cent real rate, can be compared to the Opposition's performance-a 4.9 per cent rate of real term growth; yet it criticises us.

I ask the question: What is the Opposition saying? It has raised tax as a general heading. It says, `Yes, tax is a problem, and until that gets better, nothing can be done'. This Government has organised the most significant tax reform package this country has ever seen and is now in the process of reviewing business taxation. This review of business taxation is being undertaken with a view to lowering the rate of taxation and to see whether more incentive can be introduced into the taxation system.

The Opposition talks about over regulation. Of course, we have set up the Business Regulation Review Unit which has kicked out of the structure a number of regulations which we inherited from the Opposition. We have gone further. We have reduced tariffs to increase the competitive environment within Australia in order to encourage Australian industry better to sustain its products on an international market. Interest rates across the board have fallen generally. Rather than resorting to citing the figures, I just remind the Senate that that is the case, that is the record, that is the achievement and that is the commitment for continuance in the future. If this debate were being held a year ago, one of the things we would have heard a lot about is the level of the deficit. That has been absent from the Opposition's argument today, because in fact no deficit is projected at all. It is a major benchmark that we are looking to a surplus of $580m in this budgetary year. We have not heard any reference to deficit because we are moving into surplus through effective fiscal management, and we are looking at the possibility of strengthening that direction with a May statement next year.

Industrial relations is Senator Chaney's new-found fetish. He likes to talk about industrial relations. On the industrial relations front the record is that the number of disputes, the number of people involved in disputes and the number of man days lost through disputes in Australia have fallen significantly under this Government. What does the Opposition offer by way of alternative? It offers an alternative model which generates confrontation, animosity, distrust, disbelief and disputes throughout Australia, as we saw in the years of the Fraser Government. That is the model being put to us by the conservative Opposition here. Our record is one of reducing disputes at a time when wages needed to be adjusted downward in order to put Australia into a better economic and industry competitive position so that we could get some control over some of the inputs of production and start to expand and lift living standards again as we gained a bigger share of the world market with the goods that we produce.

I dwell for a moment on the issue of industrial relations by referring to what has commonly been regarded in the past-certainly during the Liberal years of administration of this country-as an area of massive industrial unrest, the Pilbara area of Western Australia, the export iron ore mining centre of this country. In that area disputes were seemingly endemic. Under the policies of this Government, by bringing employers, governments and unions together to approach the underlying problems that gave rise to disputes and to work out constructive solutions we have seen a massive reduction in industrial disputes there. At the last Australian-Japan iron ore conference, held in October at Observation City in Scarborough, not one single Japanese delegate raised the question of industrial relations in the Australian iron ore industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —You played a key role in setting up that process.

—It is very kind of Senator Tate to draw the Senate's attention to that. But this was not done for my self-congratulations; it was done so that the industry could become a more competitive exporter and employer of labour in Australia. Indeed, I will quote from the speech delivered by the Chief Executive of BHP-Utah Minerals International, Gordon Freeman, to the Japanese at the Australia-Japan iron ore conference. Referring to the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council, the mechanism through which we were able to help achieve this reduction in industrial activity, Mr Freeman said:

SPEECH.PARA: This approach by the MUA-
that is, the Mining Unions Association-

can be seen as a manifestation of the success of the joint discussions between governments, unions and employers under the umbrella of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council. Improvements in reliability of supply continue to be achieved as more harmonious working relationships among employees, unions and management development. We have been able to build stockpiles of iron ore with a degree of co-operation not seen before.

I reiterate: the Japanese never raised the question of industrial relations or the question of reliability of supply and, importantly, we are beginning to turn around the negative view, promoted by conservatives in this country, that Australia is an inefficient and unreliable supplier. It is about time we heard something a little more patriotic from the Opposition benches and it is time that we started to praise achievements rather than carp and criticise what have been faults-faults which we are addressing and in respect of which we are finding paths to improvement. So much for industrial relations. (Quorum formed) My time has been eroded by the Opposition's juvenile device of trying to interrupt my speech by calling a quorum. However, I go to my concluding point. Senator Austin Lewis, in a statement to the Australian newspaper, described the booklet produced by the Department that has been under attack here. He said that Senator Button and his Department:
were acting more and more like pushy salesman with a shonky product.
If the so-called `shonky product' is Australian industry, I think Senator Austin Lewis should be censured by the Senate for this fundamental attack on the quality of products in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The discussion of the matter of public importance is completed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report on the operation and administration of the freedom of information legislation, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I also seek leave to have my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Committee, and its parliamentary predecessor, the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, conducted an extensive review of the operation and administration of the Freedom of Information Act. Our report contains 126 recommendations, of which all are unanimous except the 15 from which Senator Stone has dissented.

It is the Committee's unanimous view that the Freedom of Information Act has been, and is, of considerable benefit to the Australian community. We unanimously agree that the existence of freedom of information legislation throughout the Commonwealth would be advantageous.

In our report, we discuss the responses to the Freedom of Information Act by the various parties affected by or interested in this legislation. We were particularly conscious that some State agencies, and some individuals about whom information is contained in Commonwealth records, have displayed some opposition towards the Act.

We are pleased to confirm that the FOI Act has attracted more support than opposition. The vast majority of individuals and organisations, and even Commonwealth agencies, informed the Committee of their support both for the FOI Act and for the benefits which they have seen as flowing from its operation. Even agencies which encounter difficulties discharging their obligations under the FOI Act, such as the Australian Federal Police, expressed their general support for the Act.

Of course, the operation of the FOI Act has presented some difficulties. Our report recommends a number of changes designed to minimise these. For instance, we have recommended that documents created by `crime intelligence agencies' should be exempted from the operation of the Act in the same way as are documents created by ASIO.

On the other hand, we have tried to identify provisions in the FOI Act and interpretations of the Act which lend themselves to abuse by overly secretive bureaucrats. Where possible, we have recommended amending the Act, on other occasions we have simply recorded our conclusions in order to guide administrators in their application of the Act. For instance, we have recorded our conclusion that it should not be possible to refuse to release documents because a decision-maker considers that the disclosure of the document might lead to unnecessary debate.

With Senator Stone in dissent, we have recommended that the Act be amended to delete the provision which requires agencies and ministers to consider whether it would be misleading to release a document which has been edited to remove information which is exempted from disclosure under Part IV of the FOI Act. In the majority of the Committee's view, it is wrong to take into account the possibility that an applicant might be misled by the contents of a document for the purpose of refusing to release it. The question is merely whether the information contained in the document is exempt.

Much of the debate about the operation of the Freedom of Information Act has centred upon the charges which were imposed upon processing of requests for access to documents by the 1986 amendments to the Act. We noted that the Attorney-General's Annual Report on the FOI Act, which was tabled last Wednesday, did not make any real attempt to assess the impact of these charges. The same is true for most of the annual reports which have been tabled recently. For instance, the 1986-87 annual report of the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services which was tabled last week merely comments that these charges `do not appear to have markedly discouraged applicants'.
Nonetheless, we are very concerned that the possibility that limitless charges will be applied to the processing of requests is deterring people from using the Act.

On balance, we have decided to accept the existence of some charges for processing FOI requests. However, we do so only on the basis that an upper limit be imposed. Senator Powell has joined with the remainder of the Committee in this conclusion. But we note in the report that for Senator Powell this is very much a second best option. The report records Senator Powell's commitment to the principle that the provision of access to documents under the Freedom of Information Act should be free to applicants.

In deference to disparities between types of requests, the Committee has recommended a lower maximum be applied to requests for access to personal documents than should be applied to other requests. Where an applicant seeks access to personal documents, the Committee has concluded that the maximum fee chargeable for any request should be $85. Senator Stone has dissented from the Committee's recommendation to reduce the application fee from $30 to $15.

In the report, we have made a series of recommendations to the effect that the fee for applications should be reduced from $30 to $15; and that agencies and ministers should be allowed to charge for only a maximum of 2 hours for each of search and retrieval time and decision-making time.
The Committee has recommended a higher maximum be applied in for applications to access of non-personal documents.

The Committee has concluded that the maximum fee chargeable for the provision of access to non-personal documents should be $540. For this calculation, the Committee has recommended that the charges be limited to a maximum of 15 hours for each of search and retrieval, and decision-making.

The Committee has also recommended that the size of the fee for lodging applications for review with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal should be reduced. This time with Senator Stone's dissent, the Committee has recommended that a fee of $120 be payable for lodging applications with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Senator Powell endorses this recommendation as a second best option to no fee at all.

The Committee has made numerous recommendations in respect of exemption provisions and the procedural provisions of the Freedom of Information Act. The Committee has also noted with approval a number of suggestions for procedural reform advanced by the Administrative Review Council.
Time does not permit me to mention all of these recommendations here, so I refer only to some of the most important.

The Committee has recommended that two of the restrictions upon the section 48 right to seek the amendment of records be removed. The Committee has unanimously recommended that requests for amendment should not depend upon the applicant having previously gained access to the record under the FOI Act. And with the exception of Senator Stone, the Committee has recommended that the right to seek correction should be open to all persons in Australia, regardless of their citizenship or residential status.

We are aware of the suggestions that there should be restrictions upon the rights of non-citizens, or at least people who have not been granted permanent residence. However, with the exception of Senator Stone, we have rejected this view and have recorded our conclusion that there should be no discrimination in this regard.

However, because of the pressures said to have been placed upon the administration of the FOI Act by FOI request from illegal entrants and illegal residents in Australia, the Committee has recommended that the restrictions on charges which I mentioned earlier, should not apply to applicants whose presence in Australia at the time of making the application is illegal.

At a technical level, the Committee has recommended that the Act provide for the transfer of parts of requests, and the transfer of requests for the amendment of records. The Committee has also recommended that the section 24 workload test should be amended to make it clear that applicants' motives are not to be taken into account for the purpose of this test, and that requests should not be aggregated. The Committee has also specifically recommended that the fact that the processing of requests will exceed the maximum times for which charges may be levied, in accordance with the earlier mentioned recommendation, should not be treated as a factor relevant to the workload test.

I should mention here that Senator Stone has dissented in respect of the recommendations about applicants' motives. Broadly, it seems that Senator Stone departs from the remainder of the Committee, in that he takes the view that applicants' motives are relevant to their rights of access under the Freedom of Information Act.

With the exception of Senator Stone, all of the members of the Committee are strongly of the view that the Freedom of Information Act should be interpreted to confer upon the public at large a right of access to documents in the possession of the Commonwealth, regardless of applicants' interests in the information contained in the documents and that this right should not be constrained by any consideration of motives.

In so doing, we affirm our commitment to the principle expressed by Senator Durack when he introduced the FOI Bill in 1978: that access to information under this legislation is not to depend upon the showing of any special interest in that information.

The Committee has decided that the system of conclusive certificates should be retained. However, in the Committee's view, this system rests upon the principle of accountability of ministers to the Parliament. The Committee (with the exception of Senator Stone) has therefore recommended that whenever a conclusive certificate is issued, the responsible minister must report this issue to the Parliament. The Committee (again with Senator Stone in dissent) has recommended that conclusive certificates should be valid for a maximum of two years. At the end of this two year period, it should be possible for an application for access to a document previously the subject of such a certificate, to be considered afresh.

The Committee has made various recommendations extending the reverse-FOI procedures. The Committee has recommended that consultation in respect of business documents be mandatory, and that third parties consulted under reverse-FOI applications who wish to oppose the release of documents be required to seek the internal review of such decisions before approaching the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Committee is also of the view that people about whom documents contain personal information of the type contemplated by section 41 of the Act should be consulted before disclosure of such documents. In this, the Committee has agreed with the amendment of the Act which was proposed by in clause 5 of the Privacy (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986.

I have referred only to a few of the Committee's recommendations and conclusions. Before concluding, I would like to thank the staff of the Committee for their work on this inquiry. I am sure that the remainder of the Committee joins with me in acknowledging their work. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
