DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Puplick for calling a quorum to enable me to get back into the chamber. I understood that debate on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987 would take a little time but, apparently, under the guidance of my colleague Senator Puplick, it went through in a flash.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is now about to debate a package of Bills: the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1987, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill 1987, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill 1987, Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill 1987 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1987. It is an absolute disgrace that the Government has brought these Bills on for debate cognately. They are a massive package. One could quite easily spend 30 minutes debating the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, or the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill, or the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill. I cannot deal with all the legislation in this speech, so I will have to leave it to colleagues of mine to deal with certain aspects of the package, in particular, the Bass Strait legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Lewis has referred to a cognate debate. Is it the wish of the Senate to debate these Bills cognately? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

—I did not take any exception to your suggestion, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would have liked to say no, and not permit the Senate to debate the Bills cognately, but in order to get this legislation package, and all the other legislation that we have to get through, through by Friday evening, we have been blackmailed, in effect, into accepting that this legislation be dealt with as one package.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is present, would be the first to acknowledge the difficulties that have been experienced in relation to this Bill. The Bill deals with the harmonised tariff legislation first enacted in June of this year. That legislation was contained in 532 pages of a Bill. It tried to introduce a harmonised tariff. By a `harmonised tariff' we mean tariff words and schedules in accordance with those which are used around the world. The Opposition supports tariff harmonisation, so we supported the legislation enacted in June. We will be supporting this legislation, which amends the June legislation.

This Bill is a very detailed amending Bill. Although it has been reduced to 26 pages it is still very complex. Unfortunately, it still contains a number of anomalies. The Bill has been introduced to try to correct the anomalies and mistakes contained in the original legislation passed in June, the Customs Tariff Act, of some 532 pages. The Government has now brought in this substantial amending Bill to try to correct the anomalies. When I examined the correcting Bill we are now debating, in conjunction with my staff, and as a result of representations made to me by many people in the industry, we discovered a large number of mistakes, oversights and matters which needed correction. The Minister has written to me, giving the Opposition a number of undertakings about various amendments and changes which the Government will make. It is for that reason that we do not propose to amend the Bill.

In our view, this Bill is very much an interim Bill, designed, as I say, to correct the worst anomalies of the harmonised tariff legislation enacted in June of this year. We have co-operated with the Government to avoid non-Government amendments because I was concerned that any amendments I might have been able to draw, with my limited resources in opposition, might have created unintended distortions to a complex classification schedule. So on each occasion when I was concerned about an amendment I wrote to the Minister and pointed out the anomaly or the correction which needed to be made. In due course the Minister has written back to me saying that he would make the corrections. So I am prepared to accept the Minister's undertaking and the amendments which might occur in due course. However, I move:
At end of motion, add: `, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should:
(a) ensure that imported second-hand engines meet the full requirements of Australian design rules; and
(b) correct anomalies that result in upward adjustment before phasing down of tariff'.
I shall explain this amendment later. In relation to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 I foreshadow that I shall move the following amendment:
Leave out all words after `That', insert:

`the second reading of this Bill be made an Order of the Day for the first day of sitting in 1988, to allow customs agents and the industry time to make appropriate representations in relation to the Bill'.

I shall also explain this amendment later. The Government's decision on the classification schedule of the harmonised tariff was to remove most domestic sub-headings on the basis that assistance effects would not be significant for Australian industry overall and would be outweighed by the simplified tariff with what was described as `a few minor modifications'. The few minor modifications, according to the Industries Assistance Commission, reimpose about one half of domestic tariffs. However, most of those tariffs have a phasing down component to cushion the effect of the harmonisation tariff. That seems to the Opposition to be a sensible compromise although, clearly, it was not to the liking of the Industries Assistance Commission.

This tariff Bill and the Government's amendment to it represent Opposition initiatives, among them the discovery of additional anomalies since the Bill was tabled. It covers everything from vegetables to textiles, from motor vehicles to pharmaceutical products, and from handbags to plastics industries. As I said, the coalition supports the concept of harmonised tariffs as a step in the right direction, as a culmination of negotiations with the International Customs Union and all major customs countries, although the complexity of the language leaves a lot to be desired. Let me give as an example one of the matters which came to our notice in relation to the importation of saucepans and other cooking equipment. The schedule under which that item is now disclosed, item 8419, has a very long heading which I will not bother to read out. The heading includes these words:
Machinery, plant or laboratory equipment, whether or not electrically heated, for the treatment of materials . . .
It goes on:
. . . for domestic purposes.
So it is a very wide heading. Included under that heading is item 8419.8:
-Other machinery, plant and equipment:
A sub-heading under that is:
--For making hot drinks or for cooking or heating food.

When I looked at that, I discovered that that imposed a tariff of 25 per cent. I complained to the Minister about that tariff and in due course I was told that it would be reduced. It has been reduced in the amending Bill. I thank the Minister for that, but I simply point out the very difficult and complex nature of this matter. Quite frankly, in the first instance I was unable to follow it. For some considerable time I thought that what we were dealing with was people's opinions about what words meant, as if we were Alice in Wonderland, rather than dealing with the legal interpretation of words so that a cooking instrument meant a saucepan and did not mean some other complicated thing to do with heating:
. . . whether or not electrically heated, for the treatment of materials by a process involving a change of temperature . . .

The Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, in announcing a comprehensive review of Australia's customs and excise laws by the Law Reform Commission, admitted on 1 December that the two Acts and 11 other pieces of related legislation had become outdated and too complicated. He said:
The Commission has been advised to emphasise simple English expression in any draft legislation it may recommend in an effort to reduce uncertainty over its meaning and operation.

I totally agree with that. It should be a priority consideration. It has been reported that the Government is considering a much wider pattern of tariff reductions to be introduced during the autumn session of parliament next year. I urge the Minister to provide better lead time and closer consultation with industry to avoid the confusion created by this Bill, thus providing the stability which is essential in good commercial practice.

There are other problems with the harmonised tariff, described by one Customs agent as `an unmitigated disaster,' but because of the number of anomalies now being corrected in this Bill, it should not be delayed. For example, pumps for diesel injectors are not manufactured in Australia but are now lumped with motor vehicle parts. As such, they attract a 25 per cent tariff. In other words, pumps for diesel injectors jump up to a 25 per cent tariff rate, even though no one in Australia produces them. But because the pumps are not manufactured in Australia, manufacturers of pumps for diesel injectors are able to seek a concessional entry order which would attract only a 2 per cent duty, which is the current duty. So diesel pumps are classified as attracting a 25 per cent tariff. If we can find our way through the 500-odd pages of the legislation to find diesel pumps, we will see that there is a 25 per cent duty rate. We might think, `Gee, that is a great worry'. But if a person happens to be in the know or gets in touch with Customs officers of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, that person will be told, `Do not worry about that. Diesel pumps are not manufactured in Australia so you are entitled to apply for a concessional entry order. The duty is then only 2 per cent'. That strikes me as being a most unusual, complex and convoluted way of handling the matter. But, I suspect, it is just one of the problems arising out of this harmonisation exercise.

Another problem is that the machinery for obtaining concessional entry is also cumbersome and time-consuming with a statutory 28-day period to apply. So the importers of diesel pumps have to wait 28 days after they make their application. I have been telling all the importers who have been in touch with me that they should lodge their applications quickly and should not wait until 1 January 1988 before they get their application in, because they would then have to wait for 28 days. They are entitled to lodge their applications now. I hope that departmental officers have already received applications from all the importers of these pumps. Even so, there is likely to be an overlap period. With a 28-plus day delay, it is likely that some applications will not have been dealt with by 1 January. I point out that neither the Customs Tariff Act nor the Customs Act gives the Comptroller discretion to accommodate this problem. It seems extraordinary that the Government did not encourage the people involved to seek a concessional entry order much earlier.

I suppose the Government has a lot to do, but I think it should have been in touch with these people, telling them what to do, to apply for this concessional entry order. I also believe that the Bill should contain some discretionary power whereby this problem could be overcome by the exercise of a discretion. Failure to do so has led to speculation that tariff harmonisation has been utilised as a revenue-raising exercise and will result in exploitation similar to that connected with metrication. I remind the Senate of the cost to the nation of our marvellous metrication system.

There is also a problem with concessional entry, as exemplified by Davies Craig. It is unable to import flat electric motors at the concessional rate because Preslite Australia, an Australian manufacturing company, says quite rightly that it makes electric motors for use in fans. The problem is that Davies Craig uses a flat electric motor. Preslite does not produce a flat electric motor; it produces a bigger motor that goes on the back of fans. Davies Craig says that it wants to import flat electric motors and Preslite says that it makes electric motors for fans. The Comptroller has decided to impose the higher tariff on these motors, notwithstanding the fact that Preslite does not make a flat electric motor. Davies Craig says Preslite's motor is not any good for the fan it wants to make.

The thing that really worries me is that the Comptroller's decision is non-appealable-there is no appeal. I have another example, in relation to the police speed radar. State governments will pay some $700 or $800 a year extra for every radar used by police forces around Australia. This example is very similar to the problem with the flat electric motor-and, as I say, there is no appeal. Let us take another example. Currently, detergent packs are admitted free. Under item 3402.20.00 they were to be subject to a 20 per cent tariff. The Minister has now amended this to zero. Clearly, it is another case in which the harmonisation tariff has resulted in increases.

I give another example. Charles Alvey and Son Pty Ltd makes marvellous side fishing reels. This excellent Queensland company, which is Australia's major manufacturer of fishing reels, produces a first-class quality product which is widely sought by discerning Australian and overseas fishermen. The company does not want any tariff protection. It is quite happy in its market not to have any protection for its reels. But as from 1 January, the tariff on all imported fishing reels will jump from 2 per cent to 25 per cent, simply because they are to be classified as items which attract a 25 per cent tariff. Notwithstanding the fact that Alvey is not seeking any increase in tariff-in fact, there is not a product which competes with the Alvey reel; the imported reels are not the side reel that it makes-Australian fishermen will be lumbered with a 25 per cent tariff imposed on imported fishing reels simply because they fit within the new harmonisation description. With the Government decision to reimpose about half the domestic tariffs, it seems quite inept to provide tariff protection to an industry which has not sought such protection. This lends support to speculation that the tariff harmonisation procedure is being used as a revenue raising measure rather than simply as a method of getting our tariff harmonised with those of the rest of the world.

Another problem concerns the importation of Japanese second-hand engines which are sold as scrap in Japan. My amendment seeks to ensure that imported second-hand engines meet the full requirements of Australian design rules. It turns out that engines sold as scrap in Japan are not required to comply in full with Australian design rules when they are brought into Australia by an importer. I believe that the Government should require them to be so covered. Australian second-hand engines should not be lumbered with the full requirement of Australian design rules while imported second-hand engines are able to get away with avoiding that requirement.

As I have said, this measure poses two problems. The first concerns the Australian design rules for emission control, which the Federal Government has washed its hands of; it says that that is a State matter. Secondly, having been sold as scrap in Japan, there must be a dumping element as the engines have a much higher value when sold as second-hand engines rather than as scrap. I appreciate that the Minister will say that this is a very complex question, that it is not really his fault, and avoid responsibility for it. But, frankly, there is no excuse for the Government not addressing the problem. I do not have time to address all the problems associated with harmonised tariff. I urge the Minister to ensure that future legislation is dealt with separately and not cognately.

I now turn to the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill. This is the second Bill in this cognate debate on eight Bills and I have already used 23 minutes of my time. Frankly, this piece of legislation is disgraceful. It is simply a tax on the Utah Development Co. Such a tax was imposed as a windfall gain tax by Mr Hayden when he was Treasurer in the Whitlam Government in 1975. It is not a duty on coal, because no coal produced by any other company is so taxed. The incidence of this tax is restricted to mines operated by Utah. I can understand the Australian Labor Party, with its great hatred of the American community back in 1975, saying, `Let's get stuck into Utah'. The truth of the matter is that Utah is now wholly owned by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP). So this tax is designed specifically to cover BHP-Utah. No other coal company pays it. Every time it appears that a coal company might have to pay this tax, the Government changes the rules and regulations so as to excuse every other company. The only company that ends up paying the tax is BHP. I do not have time to examine that matter in any greater detail. No doubt my colleague, Senator Parer, will expand on that problem.

I now turn to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) which is another major piece of legislation. It is disgraceful that the Government should wish to deal cognately or in haste with the complex issues involved in this Bill. The Minister is well aware of the concerns that have been expressed over the Bill, yet he has failed to address them. In the other place, Government members would have us believe that the coalition parties in the Senate are, in some way or other, defending shonky practices. That is absolute nonsense. The boot is very much on the other foot. Under the Customs Act, the Comptroller has far-reaching powers and has not hesitated to exercise them. In 1986-87, goods to a total value of $16m were seized and about $9m was recovered in fines, reparations and additional duty demands.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) announced on 1 December that the Law Reform Commission will inquire into the Customs Act, the Excise Act and 11 related Acts and report to the Government by 30 September. Although the Attorney-General has acknowledged that the legislation is complex, here we are trying to deal with the matter at this stage. What we have said is that the Government is trying to push this through. The industry simply has not had an opportunity to give it the consideration which it needs. We say that this Bill ought to be left until the autumn session so that industry can make the representations which it wishes to make. I have received dozens of representations about the Bill which I would like to debate in the Senate. Fortunately, I understand that the Australian Democrats intend to support my foreshadowed amendment that the Bill be debated further during the autumn session, which will give us an opportunity to look at the problems involved in this legislation. I have had an indication from the Government that I can seek an extension of time. On that basis, I refer briefly to the fact that the Customs Agents Federation of Australia, the Australian Federation of Air Freight Forwarders Ltd and various companies have made very long and complex submissions to me on the difficulties inherent in the Bill.

The Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the three Bass Strait Bills propose amendments to incorporate into the relevant Acts changes resulting from the Government's decision to deregulate crude oil marketing with effect from 1 January 1988. The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill involve various excise proposals and the Bass Strait package enables the implementation of transitional arrangements for the marketing of Australian produced crude oil from the current allocation scheme to a deregulated or free market. At least that is the way the Government puts it. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has drawn our attention to clause 9 of the Petroleum Excise (Prices) Bill and the powers of entry, search and seizure. In particular it pointed out that the issue of a warrant by a judicial officer is always preferable to the conferral of a power of entry without warrant. Sub-clause 9 (1) of this Bill would permit a `person' to enter on to `any land or premises' without the safeguard of having obtained a search warrant from a judicial officer. I ask the Minister to tell us what he proposes to do about that reference from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. I seek leave to extend the time of my speech by another five minutes just to finish off these few matters.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The actual manner and form of the Government's action demonstrate a remarkable lack of consistency in policy. On 2 April 1981 Mr Keating said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Labor Party is opposed to import parity pricing . . . is opposed also to the use of the crude oil levy as a mechanism for taxing oil producers. It is inefficient and inequitable and should be removed and replaced by a properly designed resources rent tax which is neutral in effect, and a better mechanism to divide this wealth between the companies and the community.

This legislation changes the basis of calculating excise on crude oil from import parity pricing to a formula based on what is called volume weighted average prices-given the special term `volware'-which are the prices realised for crude oil sales by the Bass Strait producers. Excise tariff rates will move with the consumer price index. The Government claims:
The net result of this policy is that as crude oil prices change, Government revenues will remain the same overall and petrol price changes are kept to a minimum.

The Automobile Association of Australia has estimated that this move will result in an initial drop of about 1.3c per litre in the price of petrol at the pump. Excise concessions are proposed in an attempt to encourage the exploration and development of petroleum following recent reductions in crude oil prices.

What has happened here is that the Government has, virtually, destroyed the oil exploration industry. On the one hand it is now trying in some way to grant some concessions in an attempt to re-establish some oil exploration, but on the other hand it has introduced the resource rent tax which, in effect, has placed this industry in a precarious position. Whilst the Opposition does not oppose this package, it is critical of the increasing use of the petrol bowser to raise taxes for general revenue. I point out that since this Government's election, excise has increased from 6c per litre to 20.83c per litre as at 1 October 1987, and the Government has failed to allocate adequate revenue from that petrol excise for road funding. As can be seen right around this nation, various government road construction authorities, both State and local government, have been unable to construct the necessary roads. As one of the engineers recently said to me, `We are being funded on the basis that our roads will last for 85 or 90 years, whereas in fact with the money that is available we are able to build them to last for only about 10 or 15 years.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Lewis has indicated, there are quite a number of Bills before us. I do not wish to speak to all of them, only to the first three-the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) introduces changes to the Customs Tariff Act 1987, which introduced to Australia, as Senator Lewis said, the harmonised tariff. Harmonised tariff-the most revolutionary customs change since Federation-will operate from 1 January 1988. Along with 60 other nations, Australia will adhere to the new international harmonised system developed by the Customs Co-operation Council, which classifies all tradable goods into about 5,019 categories defined by function and purpose. Australia currently has about 2,700 customs categories. The Bill before us contains amendments which correct errors and anomalies created by the translation of current assistance arrangements to the harmonised system. One of the errors not addressed by this legislation is the reduction in the tariff on imported pressure gauges from 25 per cent to zero. In the Industries Assistance Commission report entitled Medical and Scientific Equipment, the IAC admits, on page 174, that it has made a mistake. It states:

In its report on the Harmonized Tariff, the Commission recommended that pressure gauges (classified to 90.24.1 (b) in the current Tariff) should be duty free on implementation of the Harmonized Tariff. That recommendation was the result of an oversight which occurred during the Commission's rationalisation exercise. The Commission has reviewed the decision for these goods and will propose in this report that they retain their present tariff assistance.

Despite this very clear recommendation by the IAC to the Government to rectify the mistake, the Government has decided not to do so in this legislation. It wants to wait to make a decision on all of the recommendations of the IAC report on medical and scientific equipment. The Australian Democrats believe that the mistake should be rectified now so that Australian producers of pressure gauges can be sure that the imported products will be be admitted duty free from 1 January, which is only a few weeks away.

I note in passing that my colleague Senator Janet Powell made a request in relation to this matter to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) on behalf of Budenberg Gauges (Australia) Pty Ltd of Ringwood, Victoria, and Mr Barry Jones said he was hopeful that a decision on the medical and scientific equipment report would be made before 1 January. I believe that the Government does intend to make some announcement on this matter during this debate, and I hope to hear that the matter will be rectified. Budenberg Gauges and J. A. Floyd & Co. Pty Ltd of North Essendon, Victoria, are two manufacturers of pressure gauges who claim that they will simply have to stop producing if this error is not corrected by 1 January. The Democrats will therefore be moving a requested amendment, which has been circulated, to this effect:
Page 24, Schedule, after item 124, insert the following item:
``124A. Omit 9026.20.90, substitute:

The alternative to charging tariffs by legislation is to make the change through customs tariff proposals. The tariff is increased from the day the change is tabled. If Parliament is not sitting, the changes are gazetted and need to be passed through both Houses subsequently.

Another requested amendment we seek to make is with respect to solar cells and assembled solar arrays. The Government in this schedule is changing the tariff from 20 per cent to 21 per cent. While there is a manufacturer of solar cells and arrays in Australia we believe, particularly in the light of the debate last evening, that it is very much in the interests of the use of alternative energy systems that the tariff on imported cells remain low. Therefore, we will be moving the second amendment that has been circulated to the effect that:
Page 20, Schedule, item 99, proposed new item 8541.40.00, leave out ``20% DC: 15%'', insert ``2%''.

The final matter on this legislation relates to the motion which the Opposition is appending to the effect of requiring second-hand engines to meet Australian design rules, an amendment which we will be supporting.

The Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to adjust downwards the tariff on certain specifications of coal. In further emphasis of the remarks that I made earlier this afternoon, I wish to say that the Government is proceeding in the wrong direction-and clearly the Opposition would do likewise if it were in government-in relation to exports of coal and the coal industry. Again, I would like to put on record that, through a variety of industries, not least the coal industry, human industrial development is changing the composition of the global atmosphere faster than at any time in the earth's history. I am not just talking about the time since human beings have been on Earth. Since the beginning of the industrial era, fewer than 200 years ago, the concentration of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased from 270 parts per million to round about 340 parts per million at present, and it is rising at the rate of about half a per cent per annum. That is an absolutely unprecedented change in the composition of the atmosphere, which will have enormous consequences for every aspect of life-increasing world temperatures, increasing ocean levels, changing climate patterns, changing the ability to grow food in certain areas, rendering the whole global national parks system obsolete because those national parks will be in the wrong place to preserve the species for which they have been set aside. Those are the sorts of consequences at which we are looking, and for governments to be deliberately, encouraging, in any sense, the further consumption of fossil fuel, through changing tariffs downwards, would seem to us to be a retrograde step.

On the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Australian Democrats accept the proposition put by Senator Lewis with respect to the complexity of this Bill and the difficulty being faced by many people in this industry in making adequate representations to the Government in the limited time which was available for the making of those representations and for getting this legislation properly discussed and possibly modified.

I made representations to Senator Button's office some weeks ago, when this legislation was coming up, and it was more than a week before anybody from Senator Button's office got back to me and by that time I was in Adelaide and it was not possible to meet with these people. It is only in the last few days that quite intensive negotiations have been entered into, and I regard that as a quite unsatisfactory opportunity to get back to those who made representations but, more particularly, for those people to approach the Government directly and enter into the necessary negotiations and come to some understanding. Therefore, we shall be supporting the Opposition's amendment on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), namely, to the effect that the Bill be held over until the autumn session of Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on just one of these Bills-the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1987. Before doing so, I should like to make a brief comment on the remarks made by Senator Coulter, who said that he believed that this reduction in export duty was proceeding in the wrong direction and that, by implication, he would like to see the duty increased, presumably so that the price would go up to the extent that it would make our coal less competitive as compared with that produced by the rest of the world. That is the most incredible suggestion from the Australian Democrats, although no more incredible than some of the other suggestions that we have heard in recent days. I draw the attention of the Democrats to the fact that Australia produces about 10 per cent of what is produced in the United States and 10 per cent of what is produced in China. Other major producers are South Africa, Poland, Colombia, and so on.
—They are going to be in the same position as we shall be if they go down the same road.

—Senator Coulter has no realisation of what the real world is like out there. Coal is not in short supply. We are competing with the rest of the world, and if we do not supply coal, someone else will. Simply by adding the costs, and bearing in mind the difficulties the coal industry is in, and that the Government has seen fit recently to offer the coal industry in New South Wales $40m to keep it alive, what Senator Coulter suggests makes no sense whatsoever. It just gives an indication of the funny thinking that occurs among some of the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish briefly to discuss the background of the Bill. We are discussing legislation that was introduced in 1975, in the dying days of the last Whitlam Government. It imposed an export duty of some $6 a tonne on hard coking coal, and $2 a tonne on other coal. Because of increased demand, prices for coal had increased, and because of the reckless spending of the Labor Government in those days-a level of spending that we are seeing again today-it was decided to impose yet another secondary tax on the industry. It was not too different from the resource rent tax that we debated earlier today. The tax was imposed on an industry which had already suffered because of government interference in the form of export controls and the use of those controls, quite improperly, to decide which mines could open and which could not. These conditions were imposed on a growing industry which had never sought government assistance or interference.

In October 1976, the Fraser-Anthony Government decided to reduce the coal export duty, with a view to its total removal. It was prevented from removing it totally because of the previous excesses of the Whitlam Government. The Labor Opposition opposed the reduction of the levy primarily because, in the words of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who is now the Treasurer:
The Government has not announced its intention to introduce a tax measure as a substitute for the coal export duty-
and that-
the industry was healthy enough to sustain a selective tax.

Another major reason why the honourable member for Blaxland opposed the reduction in duty was the perceived level of foreign ownership in the coal industry. What these foolish proponents of a secondary tax failed to understand was that an artificial cost on a mine, whether it be an export duty or an artificially high rail freight or port charge, reduces the level of economically recoverable reserves, thus reducing the mine life. Restrictive work practices which reduce the level of output per man employed has a similar effect, particularly in the labour intensive underground mines.

In view of our current balance of payments problem, we can be thankful that the emergence of the Fraser Government prevented the Whitlam Labor Government from destroying the developing coal export industry. Without it, we would be in diabolical trouble today. Over the years, the coal export duty has been steadily decreased, so that the duty is now paid by only one company. It was a discriminatory tax to start with, but it is even more discriminatory today. That company is, of course, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-Utah International, and the interesting thing is that it is not paid on all its coal. Coal is currently exempted from export duty if it is mined at depths below 60 metres and has an ash content of 12 per cent or more and a free swelling index of three or less.

This amendment reduces the specified ash content to 10.5 per cent and increases the specified free swelling index to five or less. Both those factors are used as a gauge to determine classifications of coal. Generally, the swelling index indicates whether the coal is a steaming coal or a coking coal. The ludicrous situation has occurred whereby the blending of coals which were previously exempt with coals which were dutiable to produce coal of a quality to satisfy a particular market meant that full duty was payable on the blended product. The Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), in his second reading speech-I find this incredible because it casts doubt on the credibility of either this Government or its department-made clearly incorrect statements. He said that the purpose of this Bill is to ensure that certain exports of coal to steaming coal markets at lower prices operating in those markets do not attract the coal export duty which is currently set at $3.50 a tonne. He went on to repeat the background of why the levy was introduced in the first place, which was to pick up what were called windfall profits. The Minister stated:
The present policy objective of the Act is to only make dutiable high quality coking coal destined for world steel industry markets.

That is totally and utterly incorrect. How the Minister could put this in his second reading speech is beyond me, particularly as I assume he would have received departmental advice. A lot of high quality coking coal which goes to the world steel industry does not attract duty. Yet this is the statement in the second reading speech. It says that these coals attract a price premium relative to steaming coal which is exempt from export duty. Steaming coal has been exempt for a long time. But quite a lot of coals which are not dutiable go to the world steel industry.

The Minister also stated that this coal will end up in power stations. Again, I challenge that statement because my understanding is that this coal goes to a particular market in Japan. It is what is called non-IQ coal or non-import quota coal. It is a coking coal; there is no doubt about it. It goes into the steel mills. Yet we are led to believe that what we are dealing with is a type of coal that ends up as a steaming coal. That is not correct. Furthermore, if it has an FSI, or crucible swelling index, of five it is a coking coal; it is not a steaming coal. Steaming coal does not have any swell and that is why it is used. It cannot be used to make coke but coking coal can be used for either purpose. I would be interested to hear the Minister in responding to this debate justify the remarks made in both the second reading speech and in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill which I believe are incorrect.

I turn to what is dutiable and what is not. There is a $3.50 a tonne export duty payable for coals which come from BHP-Utah coal mines, produced at depths above 60 metres, with an ash content of 10.5 per cent or less and a crucible swelling index of five or more. We are opposed to secondary taxes, particularly on the coal industry, which at this stage is going through difficulties. I would have liked very much to have been able to propose an amendment to the Bill which would have changed the specified ash content to about 7 per cent and increased the crucible swelling number to eight. Such an amendment would have exempted all coals from export duty. However, I understand that this Bill is considered to be a Budget Bill and for this reason we will not be introducing such an amendment. I again reiterate that it is a duty that should have never been imposed in the first place which goes back to the days of the Whitlam Government. It is selective and discriminatory and at a time when the coal industry is experiencing enormous difficulties the tax should have been removed altogether.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a raft of eight Bills at the second reading stage in what I accept was agreed between the various parties would be a cognate debate covering this grouping of Bills which ranges from customs tariff amendments, customs and excise legislation and petroleum excises to Bass Strait freight adjustment levies. It is extraordinary for the Senate to have to do this so late in this Budget session. The reason is the enormous bunch of legislation over recent weeks due, without any doubt, to the utter mismanagement of the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans) in programming the work of this chamber. I think it is an absolute disgrace, firstly, that the Senate is sitting so late in the year and, secondly, that in so doing we are still being rushed in a pressure cooker atmosphere which means it is absolutely impossible to give important legislation the consideration that it needs and warrants if we are to be seen to be exercising our proper democratic parliamentary processes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills that we are talking about tonight, although they vary one from the other in their degrees of importance, collectively add up to an important package of legislation. They touch on the whole area of the Government's industry policy and therefore they touch very importantly on the whole thrust of economic policy. In their detail they have specific and important implications for individual manufacturers, producers, importers and other units of economic activity in this country.

We had a very interesting debate in the Senate earlier today on the Government's failure to implement and conduct a proper industry policy. It was one of the most important debates that we have had for some considerable time. It was pertinent for it to be brought on on a day when we are debating the legislation that is now before us because the relationship between industry policy and the specifics of at least some of these Bills is crucial. It was an indictment of the Government's industry policy that we had to bring forward for discussion the matter of public importance that we did-the failure of the Government and in particular the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, to face up to the realities of the problems facing this country in terms of getting its industry vibrant, growing and dynamic. The failure of the Minister and the Government to recognise that is probably the largest single problem in this nation today in getting down the very rocky road that anyone with half a brain would know we face over the next one to two years. The Government's failure to recognise the real significance for this country of the fall in the stock market back in October and the impact and the flow-on effect that that will have on the productive economy of our nation is extraordinary.

The Government's laid-back attitude towards this whole matter is one that we will rue as a nation for a long time to come. The chickens are coming home to roost in this country as a result of the policies of this Government over the last four to five years, with falling productivity and falling output-as we heard today in the figures taken from the annual report of the Minister's own Department. This is at a time when we are also experiencing inflation rates far higher, relative to the rest of the world, than we have ever faced in our history. That has really been the pattern over the last two to three years under this Government. We still have record interest rates-record by our own historical standards-although admittedly there is some temporary fall in interest rates at the moment. But the prospects of that drop being maintained into the future would have to be very questionable.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were no falls under Howard; just rises.

—Let me just pick up Senator Richardson's interjection. Under the previous Fraser Government there was never the gap between inflation in this country and inflation in the rest of the Western world, or the gap in interest rates in this country compared with those in the rest of the Western world, that we have today.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of relativities, under this Government we are experiencing and have been experiencing for the last two to three years the most uncompetitive situation in our history. All that honourable senators on the Government side of the chamber have done to try to overcome that situation is to let the exchange rate for the Australian dollar fall. We have had a fall of about 30 per cent in the value of the Australian dollar since this Government came to office-and that is not the solution to this country's economic problems. Indeed, one can very well argue that it is a counter-productive measure because it allows the Government, at least on a short term basis, to get off the hook of responsibility that it ought to be exercising in the areas of wages policy, fiscal policy and monetary policy. This Government has been totally and absolutely dilatory in all those areas. As a result, I repeat: the fundamental situation of this economy is very grave.

So that is the economic policy side in very broad terms, and it impinges very considerably-we cannot distinguish between the two-on industry policy. Today we heard about the Government's institution, over recent years, of a number of sectoral plans for industry. The Minister himself, the architect of these plans, has got up when it has suited him and lauded these plans, but he is now saying-he said it recently in relation to the steel industry plan-that possibly the worst thing that he ever did was to introduce the steel industry plan because of the precedent that that potentially set for other industries, given the very real problems in sectoral plans, such as their inevitable and inexorably growing bureaucratic operation and the inflexibility they they produce in the industries themselves and, therefore, the delay that they cause in allowing the necessary readjustments and restructuring of industry in this country.

Today the Minister accepted that. That was an extraordinary admission by this Minister. I think it was a correct admission, but it is a pity that he is saying it at this stage rather than having had the courage of his convictions and acting in a more responsible manner for the sake of industry restructuring in the past. He has tried to con Australian industry and the Australian public into believing that they do not have to worry about reduced government spending, reduced government taxes, or regulation of industry or wages policy; they can get away without worrying about all those things. All they need to do is to devise a plan for the particular industry sector. As we have seen from past experience, and as I believe we will see increasingly from future experience-and as Senator Chaney so eloquently put it in his remarks earlier today-that is a recipe for doom in this country. If this Government does not wake up to that and turn its own policy directions around very quickly, that potential doom will very soon become a reality.

Turning to some of the particular aspects of the Bills before us, I just want to comment on two or three of them. First of all, I wish to support very strongly the remarks that were made by Senator Parer in relation to the Customs Tariff (Coal Export Duty) Amendment Bill. This Bill is desirable in the sense that it proposes to remove a potential anomaly-something which the Opposition certainly supports. But a couple of questions really ought to be asked in relation to this Bill. The first and fundamental question is: Why do we have a coal export duty at all? This duty, which was imposed by the previous Whitlam Labor Government in August 1975, has cost the coal industry of this nation about $1 billion during the 12 years of its operation. That is a crazy policy to have when the biggest problem facing Australia at the moment is the external constraint due to our balance of payments problems. We are putting a restraint on our largest export earner-at least, it was last year. Coal contributes a very significant amount of our total export income and it makes no economic or logical sense at all to maintain a tax on that product, particularly with the changes in the coal market and the world outlook for the coal industry that have occurred in the years since it was first imposed. I would like to see the coal export duty abolished. That is what this Government ought to be doing in this Bill. As I have said, if it does not take that step, we will not oppose the proposed change; but we ought to be getting rid of this levy completely and for all time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) has also caused concern for many people in manufacturing industry in Australia. I will not say much more about it in this second reading debate because we wish to raise certain matters in committee. Suffice it to say that it is a problem Bill for certain producers in this country. In that context, one of those producers, Budenberg Gauges (Australia) Pty Ltd, a small producer in my State of Victoria, had a problem as a result of the tariff harmonisation that occurred earlier this year, amendments to which are being caught up in this present legislation. That company had a problem due to an error that was made by the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) in its report on measuring and scientific equipment earlier in the year. It made a factual mistake in its analysis of the industry of which Budenberg is a part. It claimed at the time that the products of interest to Budenberg were free of duty, whereas they were dutiable at 25 per cent. Under the tariff harmonisation procedures, the net effect of that error flowing through was that, as from 1 January next when the harmonised tariff arrangements come into force in Australia, the products of that industry would have been facing duty-free entry from abroad compared with the 25 per cent duty now. That would have been a severe problem which probably would have put Budenberg out of business. I am pleased to say that as a result of the matter having been raised by Senator Lewis and others with the Minister, Senator Button, the Minister announced last week the necessary changes to prevent that occurring. The Opposition thanks Senator Button for taking that action which was obviously necessary to correct a factual error that had been made by the IAC.

The other piece of legislation that I wish to conclude my remarks on is the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The Bill proposes a series of amendments to the principal Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901. The most important of those amendments is to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act and the introduction of consequential enforcement and penalty provisions. There are some very important elements of this Bill, many of which might be better suited to debate in the committee stage. I will foreshadow some of the concerns that the Opposition has. We are concerned with the fact that various issues that arise under this Bill have been matters of concern to a range of people in the private sector including some manufacturing companies which import certain products. One major company in particular is concerned with the new treatment in the Bill of inland freight in the country of purchase of a raw material that it imports for use in its own manufacturing process. There has been a change in this Bill in the treatment of inland freight for duty purposes. This would have a very significant impact on this company and is a matter of great concern to the company and to the Opposition. We are also sharing the concern of Customs agents throughout Australia of various provisions of this Bill, particularly so far as its enforcement and penalty provisions are concerned. Several provisions appear to have some almost draconian implications and content. We believe that they are matters that should be looked at much more carefully and the opportunity given for much fuller discussion between the clients of the Australian Customs Service and the Government before they come into legislation. That is the reason why Senator Lewis, on behalf of the Opposition when opening this debate earlier this afternoon, foreshadowed the following amendment to the motion for the second reading:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert:

``the second reading of this Bill be made an Order of the Day for the first day of sitting in 1988, to allow customs agents and the industry time to make appropriate representations in relation to the Bill''.

I think that is a very important and very necessary proposal by the Opposition. I think I am correct in saying that it has the support of the Australian Democrats. It will enable necessary discussions to take place over the recess period between industry, Customs agents, the Government and its agencies so that when we come back for the autumn session next year the concerns that clients have about aspects of the Bill will at least have been fully considered and thought through by all parties. Because of the pressure cooker environment in which we are all operating there is evidence at the moment that aspects of this legislation have been rushed. That is the surest recipe for getting things wrong. We should allow a stay of proceedings for a few months so that we all can have a much more careful look at this legislation. This would obviously be the most sensible thing to do in the circumstances. As far as I am aware, it will not have any financial impact or other adverse implications. We hope that the Government will accept that proposal. I think it will be in the interests of all concerned. I conclude my remarks on that note. I look forward to pursuing some of these very important matters in the committee stage or during the further consideration of the Bill, hopefully next session.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pick up from where Senator Short left off and deal specifically with the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and deal, very particularly, with the question of inland freight and insurance charges being made dutiable by this piece of legislation. I think it is important to put on the record the background and the facts as to why inland freight and insurance have, heretofore, not been duti- able plus the fact that the Government has deliberately made a policy change to make them dutiable under the legislation. I quote the beginning of the second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes a series of amendments to the principal Customs Act 1901 and Excise Act 1901, the most important of which are the amendments to the valuation provisions of the Customs Act 1901, (division 2 of part VIII) and the introduction of consequential enforcement and penalty provisions . . .

To effect the second instalment of the Government's strategy to combat commercial practices designed solely or predominantly to understate the value of imported goods, so as to minimise or avoid customs duty.

My difficulty with that statement in the second reading speech is that it asserts that the reason that duty is not paid on inland freight and insurance is simply that people are attempting to avoid or minimise the amount of duty payable when, in fact, the historic reason is quite clearly to the contrary. Indeed, it is fallacious to say that the main reason that duty is not paid currently on many items of inland freight and insurance is in order to understate the value of imported goods.

The history of this practice lies perhaps with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), where the concept of the transaction value of goods was established. It defines transaction value as the price actually paid or payable for goods when sold for export to the country of importation, adjusted in accordance with the provisions of article 8. Article 8, in turn, provides that the inclusion or exclusion from Customs value of freight and insurance is entirely the decision of the signatory country. Thus it was within Australia's purview to decide whether or not to include inland freight and insurance as part of the transaction value. A deliberate decision was made not to do so.

Section 159 (3) (g) of the Customs (Valuations) Amendment Act 1981 states that any inland freight or inland insurance should only be taken into account when they are paid, or payable, directly, or indirectly, by the purchaser to or for the benefit of the vendor. Thus, if the inland freight and insurance were paid to a third party which was at arm's length it was, quite properly, not dutiable. I repeat that the assertion made in the opening of the second reading speech that it is a question of avoidance to undervalue the goods that are being imported is quite wrong.

The decision to introduce by legislation a duty on all inland freight and insurance is a deliberate policy change and, as such, discussion and consultation with the industry affected are essential. Thus a deferral of the consideration of the Bill to allow consultation with industry is essential. One reason the 1981 decision did not include inland freight and insurance within the dutiable component is very simply that to do so could well prejudice the people who are importing from a source which is considerably inland. I would like to cite an example. It concerns soda ash. Soda ash is a commodity which is used by many companies in Australia. It is obviously an ingredient of glass making and packaging. This commodity is manufactured in Australia but is mined in the United States. It has been the custom of one user of soda ash to import something like 20 per cent of its requirements in the form of mined soda ash from Wyoming in the United States. The soda ash has to be taken across the United States continent before it can be shipped to Australia. The effect of imposing a duty on the inland freight and insurance component of that shipment will be to force up the price of soda ash by some 40 per cent.

The history of soda ash is interesting. It was considered as part of a package by the Industries Assistance Commission which broadly recommended that the duty of 20 per cent be phased down to 15 per cent. Subsequently, it was investigated by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce which could see no good reason why duty should be payable on it at all. Notwithstanding this, the duty was suddenly put back to 20 per cent because of some lobbying from one source or another. It is important that the landed commodity coming into Australia should compete in price with the manufactured commodity. As the manufactured commodity of soda ash is subject to parity pricing, it is only reasonable to have an actual landed price that is in some touch with reality.

The difficulty with this Bill is that it sets out to establish a premise which is not correct-that is, that the decision not to have inland freight and insurance dutiable was somehow not deliberate when it was deliberate. The Government has made a distinct policy change, which it is implementing through this Bill and, as such, there needs to be time for consideration. If this consideration does not take place and perhaps no solution is found, what will result is a dramatic increase in the cost of this commodity and others which are likewise affected. The net result will be an immediate adverse impact on the costs of a wide range of products which are manufactured in Australia and use the sorts of ingredients and commodities which are affected by this Bill.

One tends to find a similarity in thinking behind this package of Bills and the new tax- ation legislation in that the difficult parts are overrun somehow because of the main thrust-the Government wants to see its legislation put in place immediately. The move of the Opposition and, indeed, the Australian Democrats to have this legislation deferred until the autumn session is not only reasonable but also essential.

I think it would be useful to recap and restate the background to our position so that the Government will be concerned to look at the true ramifications of this Bill when further consideration and discussion take place. First, under GATT the signatory countries were allowed to make up their own minds. Secondly, in 1981 a deliberate decision was made not to include inland freight and insurance as a dutiable component. Thirdly, in 1987, as part of a two-step mechanism, the Government has introduced a change in policy and wishes to see inland freight and insurance become dutiable. I do not think it is good enough to say that traders in commodities which have not been affected before have been avoiding duty or trying to minimise landed value. They have been using the law as it was properly meant to be used and they ought not to be treated in the way that this Bill sets out to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —This cognate debate covers eight Bills involving a range of customs tariff, excise, export duty and freight levy matters. My remarks will be directed at and be most relevant to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. This Bill deals with a number of tariff matters, a significant one being the harmonising of tariffs from 1 January 1988. This proposal gives rise to certain anomalies in the application of customs tariffs. Some goods previously free of duties are now being brought into dutiable categories. Therefore, goods previously free of tariffs will now have tariffs applied. So tariffs are inadvertently being placed on goods where industry did not seek such assistance. There are other instances in this legislation where tariffs of a lesser amount on certain imports are being rounded up.

SPEECH.PARA: Such consequences from this legislation necessarily direct our attention to the whole question of tariff protection and trade policy. It is also necessary to direct our attention to this matter in the light of the outburst of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) against the trade policies of the United States of America, Japan and Europe in Tokyo on 3 December 1987. The Prime Minister claimed that Australia's standard of living has suffered because Japan, the United States and Europe are acting against their own self-interest with regard to trade policy. That may well be the case, but it is also a matter of the pot calling the kettle black. Despite the extravagant claims of this Government, favoured sectors of the Australian economy remain heavily protected.

The average effective rate of protection for manufacturing industry has fallen only marginally from 21 per cent to 19 per cent over nearly half a decade during which this Government has been in office. During 1984-85 that effective rate of protection increased to 22 per cent. That minimal overall fall is due entirely to the impact of the depreciation of the Australian dollar in reducing the measured quota assistance to textiles, clothing, footwear and passenger motor vehicles. The average effective rate of protection of these four specific industries has fallen from a massive 176 per cent to a somewhat lower, but still massively excessive, 120 per cent over the past two years. I emphasise that this is not the result of the positive initiatives taken by this Government but rather because of the depreciation of the Australian dollar which, of course, is a sad reflection on the ability of this Government to manage Australia's economy.

When these four industries are excluded, the average effective rate of protection has remained virtually unchanged at 14 per cent over the life of this Government. Similarly, the effective rate of assistance afforded to manufacturing industry, excluding those quota protection industries, has shown little change, remaining at between 18 and 19 per cent since 1982-83. Consequently, levels of assistance will increase if per chance the Australian dollar appreciates while quota protection remains in place.

In addition to the Government's failure to achieve real tariff cuts, a variety of new assistance measures, often described as positive assistance, have been introduced recently or modified in an effort to direct resources to potential growth industries and to diversify our export base. These measures include provisions to increase expenditure on research and development, to help industry upgrade its performance in the commercialisation of new technology and to assist in marketing, particularly with regard to exports and innovation.

Some of the new assistance measures that have been introduced are available to all industries and are related to perceived shortcomings in market processes. An example of this is research and development assistance. Other new forms of assistance have also been designed to provide selective support for industries with high technology characteristics or some orientation towards export markets. An example of this is the offsets program which has always been highly selective in its application and which will now give greater priority to high technology projects. Most of these forms of assistance can be distinguished from the traditional forms of assistance, but they have similar effects. An example is government purchasing arrangements which provide Australian industry with a further margin of protection against import competition. That measure clearly has effects similar to tariff protection.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before my remarks were interrupted by the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was making the point that, despite the claims of this Government, there has been no real reduction in the effective rate of protection which is provided for manufacturing industry in this country, and, indeed, a number of new forms of assistance have been introduced. In addition to those matters which I raised before dinner, the Government has also introduced elements of protection through sectoral plans for mature industries. These industries include the passenger motor vehicle industry, the textile, clothing and footwear industries, the steel industry and heavy engineering. The failure of these particular sectoral plans is quite evident, and was the subject of a matter of public importance debate earlier today. We also have assistance in the form of development strategies for growth industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The basis of selectivity in each of these arrangements is the view that, because particular attributes are often possessed by industries that are internationally competitive, other industries can become more competitive if they are assisted to acquire these attributes. In practice, assisting an industry to use advanced technology or to export will not necessarily enable it to make a greater contribution to the growth of real wealth. It may acquire the specified outward appearances of competitiveness but remain reliant on public support. Such measures inevitably impose costs elsewhere in the economy. This is the case whether the measure used is in the form of tariff or quota protection or whether it is budgetary support to encourage new product development and the acquisition of new technologies and skills.

There is evidence to suggest that some positive assistance measures detract from rather than improve the performance of the economy overall. Providing assistance to new export industries must ultimately be judged not in terms of its effect on export revenue alone but on the income from other exports as well and, more importantly, from general production in the economy. Export growth is only in the national interest if it increases national wealth. When special assistance is required to encourage selected export activities the probability of this occurring is significantly reduced because each element of assistance provided to such industries imposes costs on industries that do not receive that sort of assistance. This extra cost may occur directly through higher material input prices or indirectly through the cost of capital or the bidding up of wages.

Of course, when selective assistance programs are wrong and shown to be wrong they give rise to two sets of costs-the forgone opportunities for growth from alternative activities and the further adjustment required to get the structure of the economy back into line with the realities of the market. Granting special assistance to some producers-whatever form that assistance takes and whether designed to avert adjustment or to meet a particular perception of future trading opportunities-always involves a cost to others. All such policies also encourage an assistance-dependent mentality in industry generally. This is the very antithesis of what is required in the Australian economy today to make it more productive and more internationally competitive.

The motor vehicle plan, to the extent that it allows exports of Australian motor industry products, is a specific example of the pot calling the kettle black with regard to the statement of the Prime Minister in Japan earlier this month. These exports in the motor vehicle industry are being obtained through exactly the same trick that Europe and the United States of America are using to allow their agricultural products to compete on export markets against our own in the international economy-that is, through a subsidy being paid by domestic consumers and taxpayers.

Under the so-called export facilitation scheme applying to the motor vehicle industry, for every dollar's worth of export of whole cars or components-for example, engines-manufacturers earn the right to import free of duty a dollar's worth of components or whole car. So manufacturers are exporting the things we do least badly and using that entitlement to import things that we do very badly. Thus, these boosted manufacturing exports are largely artificial, being sustained by the intricate assistance arrangements in the domestic market. Australian taxpayers and car buyers are therefore subsidising workers in the car manufacturing industry, the profits of these industries, when they are made, and, of course, most importantly, the purchasers of those vehicles and motor industry products in other countries. It is clearly beyond any logic for a government to pretend that Australia can build up a big export trade in manufactured products which require such heavy levels of protection in our domestic economy and which, in the current circumstances, have priced themselves out of our domestic market.

It has been estimated that each motor vehicle being exported from Australia under the current plan is being subsidised to the extent of $10,000. That means that if the target of 40,000 units exported is achieved, it will cost Australian consumers and taxpayers $400m. Of course, that represents a transfer to overseas buyers of $400m of Australia's wealth. Hence, it can be clearly seen that protection continues in many forms. This is contrary to the interests of the great majority of Australians. They will be best served by improved access on world markets for Australian products which are genuinely competitive and for which we have a comparative economic advantage.

The influencing of the trade policies of countries such as Japan and the United States, and the European Community, will be of major importance in achieving that access for those products which are competitive. Our capacity to influence the policies of those countries will be significantly reduced if our own house is not in order. Continuing excessive levels of protection demonstrates that our own house is not in order. But the capacity to influence the policies of other countries is not the only reason for putting our house in order by reducing protection. Unilateral action to reduce protection in a more significant way will reduce the cost burden which this protection imposes on our efficient industries-both primary and secondary-which are now competitive on world markets, and will allow them to generate the national income and economic growth for Australia of which they are capable. It will also impose greater discipline in the area of wages policy and government expenditure which, in turn, will further increase the competitiveness of exporters.

The initiatives required to improve Australia's trade performance which I have outlined warrant more detailed consideration. However, in view of the large amount of legislation remaining on the Notice Paper, as a result of the Government's inability to manage its legislative program, and which must be dealt with in the next few days before the Senate adjourns, I will draw my remarks to a close to allow my colleagues the opportunity to contribute to the debates that will occur. I will therefore save my remarks on a more detailed analysis of trade issues for another occasion.

Before concluding, I emphasise that more sectors of the Australian economy must become internationally competitive and thereby develop their export potential. If this is to be achieved, more effort must be devoted to achieving real reductions in protection. This will be greatly assisted by greater independence being given to the Industries Assistance Commission. In particular, it must have its power restored to initiate its own inquiries. The restoration of this degree of independence to the Industries Assistance Commission by enhancing the transparency of our own protection regime will also strengthen our arguments against those countries, such as Japan and the United States, and the European Community, whose current behaviour with regard to international trade is both irrational and undesirable. Indeed, those countries would be hard pressed to avoid instituting similar independent analysis of their own policies if we did restore the capacity of the IAC to initiate its own inquiries. In conclusion, I therefore urge the Minister and the Government to take this important initiative with regard to the IAC so that our trading performance does have the capacity to be more significantly enhanced.
Debate interrupted.
