DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987CUSTOMS TARIFF (COAL EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there has been a fairly wide-ranging debate on these Bills. I regret that I have not had the opportunity of hearing all the discussion. I did, of course, hear the last 10 minutes or so of Senator Chapman's carefully crafted speech-not by him, I suggest. One thing he told us in that carefully crafted speech was that the Government did not have control of the arrangements for handling business in the Senate. Senator Chapman in the whole of that time did not advert to these Bills at all. There have been six speakers on these Bills and an amendment to the second reading motion suggesting that one Bill be defeated at the end of the second reading debate has been foreshadowed by Senator Lewis. That will happen, will it not?
—What?

—Well, maybe it will not happen. There have been six speakers on these Bills. I would have thought that the issues with which they are concerned were capable of some fairly compact treatment by the Opposition. But, of course, they have not turned out to be capable of compact treatment by the Opposition because the Opposition does not understand the issues. It has given a series of different reasons over the last week as to why it cannot grapple with these Bills and why one has to be dealt with at a subsequent time, and I want to come to some of the points which I understand have been made in support of that sort of view. I refer to some of the comments which I understand Senator Lewis has made in the course of his remarks. Senator Lewis suggested that certain words be inserted, which would amount to a deferment of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Effectively the Bill would be adjourned to the first sitting day in 1988:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to allow customs agents and the industry time to make appropriate representations in relation to the Bill-

and, reading between the lines, to help the Opposition to understand it. That is the burden of Senator Lewis's criticism. The first suggestion which Senator Lewis made is that insufficient notice and consultation with the industry has occurred on this Bill. I remind Senator Lewis that a number of allegations about Customs fraud were made a year or so ago, some of them by members of the Opposition. It was at that time that the Australian Customs Service took steps to see that there were no errors or loopholes in the valuation procedures and that any loopholes that were identified were closed. Legislation was introduced in the last sitting of the Parliament which identified those loopholes and started to close them off. The current legislation, of course, deals with penalties, which are a necessary corollary of taking steps to close loopholes in the legislation. I do not remember and I am not prepared to identify-it is very difficult to identify-the exact figures of fraud in relation to Customs valuation. The figure estimated for fraud in respect of Customs valuations is about $146m. The Opposition is up to its old tricks again-if the taxman cometh, let us put every obstruction in his way to stop him collecting government revenue if we can find some reason for doing so.

Senator Lewis says that this legislation ought to be adjourned so that a proper look can be had at the nature of the legislation. Let me say again that its principal focus was foreshadowed during the last sittings in the complete redrafting of the valuation division of the Act, highlighting the array of costs, charges and agreements relating to goods which may be included or excluded for the purpose of assessing the Customs value of the goods. That meant a tightening of the legislation and the actual valuation methods to close off loopholes.

Senator Lewis and other honourable senators have said that people ought to have been consulted about this closing of the loopholes, but that would have been a public invitation to those privileged few who were milking the system to an estimated extent of $146m to participate in the question of closing the loopholes which they were jumping through. Legislation had to be put in place before any consultation on this issue could be considered. The Government was not prepared to advantage commercially a few interest groups to the detriment of the community as a whole.

The second suggestion is that insufficient notice of the legislation was given. It is very important to distinguish the giving of early notice from the claim that consultation should have occurred. The Government agrees that early notice should have been given of a very important direction it was taking in relation to the valuation of goods. Notice was given as early as April 1987. It is simply not accurate to say that the importing community and the agents it employs have not had sufficient notice of this proposed legislation, which is the second instalment of a strategy to tighten loopholes in the valuation system and a second step in the strategy to crack down on fraud and avoidance practices in the valuation of imported goods.

So there were two parts to the Government's strategy. The first part, an attack on those avoidance and minimisation practices, was contained in the legislation passed during the autumn sittings of the last Parliament. In the second reading speech on that legislation I gave notice that the Government would be proceeding with the second part of its strategy to combat these practices during the Budget sittings. I take it that the Opposition is now in favour of closing loopholes but is not in favour of doing anything about it if somebody gets caught jumping through them or trying to get round them.

On the question of notice, in the weeks which proceeded the passage of that last Bill through the Parliament the Australian Customs Service issued an Australian Customs notice targeted to the importing community outlining the main features of the legislation proposed for both sittings, including notice of the proposed introduction of a system of automatic penalties similar to that contained in the income tax legislation. On 21 April I issued a Press release drawing attention to the Government's policies in this area which received widespread coverage in daily newspapers.

So it is simply not credible to claim that persons were unaware of the Government's firm resolve to stamp out valuation avoidance practices. It is not credible for anybody in the Customs agents community or in the importing community to claim that. It can be claimed by Senator Lewis, but, if he does claim it, it is incredible that an Opposition spokesman should make that sort or claim after the sorts of steps which have been taken, both within this chamber and outside it, to identify what the Government's intentions were. It is not rational to suggest that anti-avoidance legislation should be subject to public comment and scrutiny by public exposure prior to its reaching the Parliament for consideration.

With most high value, high volume imports arriving by air, any deferral of this Bill for a further three to four months, especially since the Bill includes consequential enforcement and penalty provisions to complement the reforms contained in it and the first Bill, passed in the last sittings, could result in a quite considerable customs duty shortfall owing to the continued unrestrained use of commercial practices which are principally designed to understate the value of imported goods and so avoid the appropriate customs duty payable.

Senator Lewis has to decide whether he is for or against that practice. He must decide whether or not he supports people making fraudulent and false declarations as to the value of goods. When he reaches a conclusion, perhaps he can tell us. The deferral of this legislation for three or four months is likely to result in that practice. I can only remind honourable senators of the revenue shortfall which the valuation amendments in this Bill and its partner from the last sittings are intended to address. I do not want to go into the details of those matters but it was estimated this year that one major importer had saved $4m in customs duty a year by the sorts of shonky procedures to which I was referring a minute ago. If all major importers adopted that practice there would be a revenue loss of $90m a year. Thank goodness they do not.

It is difficult to quantify exactly duty shortfalls caused by manipulation of overseas freight charges and so on, but there are plenty of examples and plenty of evidence to support the suggestion that that is happening. So much for the suggestion contained in the Opposition's second reading amendment-that Customs agents and the industry should have time to make appropriate representations in relation to the Bill. This has been going on since April this year. There have been many public announcements here and outside on what the intention was and what the Government proposed to do.

Senator Coulter has alleged that the Government was tardy in meeting any requests for briefing on the Bill. One of the frustrations which have been encountered is that, despite the allegations of inadequate or insufficient consultation, since the introduction of this legislation into the House of Representatives on 19 November, requests to my office for briefing have been almost non-existent. But after the Bill was passed in the House, and during the week's recess just after the Bill's introduction into the Senate, offers of briefing to the Australian Democrats, for which the Australian Customs Service was prepared to visit the respective States of Australian Democrats senators, were turned down. The response was simple: `Do not bother us until after the Senate reconvenes next week'. Democrats do not work in the week away from Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are a small party and they tire easily.

—That was the gist of the response. Senator Coulter's briefing was given after several attempts to arrange it, due to his commitments in respect of debates and so on. It occurred on 9 December, six days ago-not two days ago as suggested by Senator Coulter in the course of this debate. The briefing on 9 December was cut short by Senator Coulter. While the invitation for further briefing was left with him, he chose not to avail himself of that.
—He probably used up his quota of neurons for the day.
—I want it to be clear that Senator Puplick said that and not me. I would not say such a thing.
—By saying that you have just put it in the Hansard.

—Yes; that is precisely where I want it, Mr Deputy President. Some comments were made by various honourable senators about the other Bills in this package of Bills. I do not know whether it is necessary for me to go through those in any great detail.
—All good contributions.

—Were they all good contributions? The honourable senators concerned, if they wish to do so, can raise the matters at a later stage. The weight and importance which honourable senators attach to the various comments are not capable of estimation by me as I was not here. I regret that. I will deal with a couple of them. Senator Lewis and Senator Parer referred to the discrimination of imposing the coal excise levy on Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I agree that the coal export duty has shortcomings. That is conceded. In the best of possible worlds one would not have it. But the Government has sought co-operation in introducing a rational system based on a resource rent tax for all resource industries. We have not had co-operation from the States. The duty makes an important contribution to revenue and, in the light of budgetary circumstances, the Government believes that it should be retained. The BHP-Utah mines in central Queensland remain profitable and the company has continued developing the coal resources of the Bowen Basin, notwithstanding the existence of duty, enormous rail charges and a number of other imposts on the industry imposed by both State and Federal governments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer raised the question of steaming coal, saying that some steaming coal had not been used as such but rather as non-import quota coal. All I can do is to assure Senator Parer that the information received by the Government at the time the Bill was prepared was that the product being mined by Utah was to be used as steaming coal. Finally, I remind both honourable senators that the amendments assist exports as unwashed and lower quality coking coal can now be exported into steaming coal markets. The Bill is revenue neutral in effect; it neither adds to nor lessens Commonwealth charges on the coal industry.

The Government is committed to a stage by stage process of improving and closing loopholes in the customs valuation procedures. It is committed to a system which is fair and reasonable and which has teeth in terms of penalties which can be imposed on those who seek to defraud the Commonwealth or, by negligent conduct of one kind or another, fail to pay the proper contribution which they should make to the revenue of this country collected by duties. Their failure to do that is something which imposes a burden on their competitors, a burden on other sectors of the industry and a burden on the revenue. It is a source of great regret that somewhat specious grounds are being advanced for deferring the legislation until February next year. I commend the legislation to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. For someone who was not present during the debate, I find it quite incredible that Senator Button should rise in this place and make such a totally unwarranted attack on me. It is a clear indication that in the course of the matter of public importance today I got right up his nostrils over his industry policy.
—Order! The purpose of this is to explain where the honourable senator was misquoted or misunderstood. You should not attack Senator Button.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I have been misrepresented because the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), in effect, said that I have moved that the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 be not dealt with-I might say that he did not even know the name of the Bill-until the autumn session in order to give the Opposition time to understand it. As I have said, it is quite clear that the reason for making such a petulant and childish attack on me--
—Order, Senator Lewis, you are getting a bit wide of your explanation again.

—I shall certainly confine it to this area because it is disgraceful that the Government should be endeavouring to rush this legislation through the Parliament. Let me say firstly, in relation to this allegation by the Minister, that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) himself announced on 1 December-

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have let Senator Lewis foam on, but there has been no suggestion yet of a misrepresentation of his position. He claimed to have been misrepresented. He just wants to get something off his chest and this is not the vehicle for that.

—Order! The point of order is valid. Standing Order 410 provides that senators may explain where they have been misquoted or misunderstood, but no debatable material may be introduced. Certainly attacks cannot be made upon other senators. Just explain where you have been misquoted or misunderstood, Senator Lewis.
—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order-
—I have ruled on the point of order. I now want you to make your personal explanation.

—On my personal explanation, I say again that the Minister said that the reason for moving that the debate on this Bill be deferred until the autumn session is-I think these were his words-to help the Opposition to understand it. What I am saying to you, Mr Deputy President, is that not only do I understand it but also in effect this is some of the most complex legislation that has ever been before the Senate. I was about to point out that the Attorney-General himself has said so. The Law Council of Australia believes that `it is most desirable that consideration of this Bill by the Senate should be deferred until the autumn session of the Parliament next year'. The reason suggested by the Minister for the Opposition moving this amendment is absolute nonsense. As I said to you, Mr Deputy President, the Minister has made these personal allegations against me and other members of the Opposition because we have got up his nose in terms of his industry policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lewis's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek some guidance from Senator Button as to the fate of the gauges section in Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. It was stated several times during the second reading debate that the Government has accepted that the tariff on pressure gauges would be put back to 25 per cent but I have received no communication from Senator Button's office to that effect. I would like to know exactly what is happening.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government announced its decision on the Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) report on medical and scientific equipment, which covered pressure gauges, on 9 December of this year. That decision included a 25 per cent duty on non-electrical gauges which would otherwise have been duty free from 1 January 1988. It is intended that all changes regarding the IAC report on medical and scientific equipment will be implemented by a customs tariff notice later next week for commencement on 1 January 1988. In this way pressure gauges have been addressed by the decision of the Government and it does not seem appropriate in the light of such a recent decision to separate this element from the total package relating to medical and scientific equipment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —During the second reading debate Senator Coulter said that one of his Senate colleagues had been in contact with Mr Barry Jones about Budenberg pressure gauges and in effect he was promoting the Australian Democrats as having been very desperately involved in that. As my colleague Senator Short pointed out in the debate this afternoon, while the Democrats have been talking to Mr Barry Jones about this matter I, as Opposition shadow Minister, have been negotiating with the Minister who is responsible, and that is Senator Button. The truth of the matter is that Senator Button, as he has already indicated, has agreed with my representations on behalf of Budenberg Gauges (Australia) Pty Ltd and has given me certain undertakings which I have accepted. As a result, the Liberal and National parties are not prepared to agree to the amendment foreshadowed by the Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am on my feet, I just say that the foreshadowed amendment in relation to solar arrays and solar cells is the sort of amendment which the Democrats are inclined to move from the hip or at the drop of a hat. I would like to know whether they have consulted industry, whether they have consulted the Government, or whether they are aware of what may be the ultimate consequences of this amendment. I just cannot agree that some sort of amendment should be made to this legislation by the Senate without that sort of consultation.

I say to Senator Coulter that he should have listened to what I had to say during the second reading debate. I made the point that I had received numerous representations about many amendments to this legislation. But my attitude was that I was not prepared, on behalf of the Opposition parties, to move the amendments. I went to the Minister and said to him, `You are the people with the expertise in this area. Are you prepared to move the amendments? Are you prepared to correct this anomaly? Are you prepared to correct this injustice?'. I have accepted the Government's undertakings so to do and that is why we do not have any amendments to this legislation. It seems to me that the correct approach for an opposition with limited resources on such a particularly complex and difficult piece of legislation is to say to the Government, `You fix it. We do not have the ability to fix it. If you do not fix it we will have to look at your refusal to fix it and we may take some other action'. Notwithstanding the Minister's personal attack on me, he has agreed to fix up every one of the matters that I have raised with him in this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really very grateful to Senator Lewis for acknowledging that I am such a decent chap after--
—That is putting it a bit too high.

—The honourable senator thinks that that is putting it too high. He acknowledged that I was a decent chap after the horrendous attack I made on him tonight when I said that he was incredible, which I do not think is a very nasty thing to say about anybody. Senator Lewis is right about pressure gauges. He wrote to me about that issue and I replied-and delivered the letter myself, did I not, Senator Lewis?
—Yes, you did, in the Senate.
—I was here when you did it. I corroborate that.

—Yes, Senator Stone was there when I did it. I am in real trouble now as I have got into a conspiracy. I caught both Senator Stone and Senator Lewis together and I delivered a letter. Senator Coulter also made representations to me about pressure gauges and I hope that the reply I have given him is sufficient to satisfy his concerns, as it was for Senator Lewis and as it ought to be for any reasonable man-I was going to say like Senator Lewis, but that would be a mistake and it would be taking it too far.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will not accept the proposed amendments concerning photovoltaic cells. We decided to retain the general tariff of 20 per cent for assembled solar arrays and solar cells following negotiations with the industry. The decision was based on the fact that this level of protection is consistent with protection currently available to other electronic products and to alternative products such as power generators. They are all in one classification. Moreover, the Government considered that the integration of the photovoltaic industry with other industries-electronics, communications, et cetera-would offer the scope for the development of complementary innovative products and components in that sub-sector of industry. The amendment is not accepted and that explanation has already been advanced to Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his explanation. As a person recently elected to the Senate, I must say that it is sad to find fellow senators on a broadcast day simply trying to claim that they were the ones who got this amendment up, or that they were the ones who had been successful. The point to be welcomed is that the matter of the pressure gauges has been sorted out. As several other remarks were made earlier, I must explain that, when Senator Button said approaches had been made to my office in Adelaide, that was perfectly true. As I recall, I approached his office almost three weeks ago, on the Thursday, and it was not until the following Tuesday that his office got back to me. I was then in Adelaide. As honourable senators will know, there is some work to do in one's office. We do not simply sit around waiting for Senator Button's Department to ring and then, at short notice, seek a meeting with him. In that week I had only three days in Adelaide. I was off to a Senate committee meeting on the Thursday and on the Friday I had another set of appointments in Melbourne. So it was quite impossible for me to meet with the officers from Senator Button's Department during that time. I find it rather depressing that I should be attacked for not being able to meet with him at such short notice.

SPEECH.PARA: Regarding the solar cells, it may well be true that, as a matter of convenience, Senator Button's Department finds it appropriate to put solar cells in with other electrical equipment. But the fact remains, as we debated last evening at some length, that there is a need to encourage alternative energy systems, of which photovoltaic cells are one, the price of which, short of this impost, is rapidly decreasing. We are achieving wider and wider application of solar cells around the country, such as in remote telephone boosters. Photovoltaic cells are being used in remote farmhouses or for pumping for electrical systems. We are getting to a situation where this form of electricity is becoming competitive in remote areas.

It is also rather remarkable that members of the Opposition are not prepared to support this request. Last night they were arguing quite vigorously against the application of $5m for alternative energy systems. We now find that they are further trying to block the use of these systems by supporting an impost of 20 per cent.

Senator Button has indicated that it is relatively easy for a change to be made between now and 1 January, when this legislation comes into effect, with respect to the pressure gauges. I simply ask him again to consider that these are not simply ordinary electrical devices; they are solar cells, photovoltaic cells, which have an important and growing use. It is important that they do not have this tariff imposed upon them.

The final point that needs to be made is that it is not true that the Australian Democrats have not consulted with industry and are not aware of the existence in Australia of an industry which manufactures solar cells. However, relative to the consumption of solar cells in Australia, this is a small industry. It is rather ironic and paradoxical to find members of the Opposition complaining that the Government was imposing protective measures on industry and arguing that it should decrease those protective measures and yet in this particular case they seem to be supporting a 20 per cent impost on imported solar cells and presumably doing that as a mechanism for protecting local industry. We believe that it is far more important that the price of solar cells be kept as low as possible and that these cells come into much wider use and much wider experience. I move:
(1) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
Page 20, Schedule, item 99, proposed new item 8541.40.00, leave out ``20% DC: 15%'', insert ``2%''.
The effect of the amendment would be to reduce the Customs duty on solar cells and arrays to 2 per cent.
Question put:
That the request (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987PETROLEUM EXCISE (PRICES) BILL 1987EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after ``That'', insert: ``the second reading of this Bill be made an Order of the Day for the first day of sitting in 1988, to allow customs agents and the industry time to make appropriate representations in relation to the Bill''.

Earlier tonight Senator Button said that the reason we are moving for the deferral of this legislation is to give us time to consider it. This is absolute nonsense from the Government. It is disgraceful that the Government should wish to deal in haste with the complex issues raised by this Bill and try to push it through. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is well aware of the concerns that have been expressed over this Bill, yet he has failed to address them. In fact, he has alleged tonight that the coalition parties are in some way defending shonky practices. That is an absolute nonsense. The boot is very much on the other foot. In fact, the Government is adopting the same attitude towards the revenue raising provisions within this Bill as the Commissioner of Taxation is adopting in relation to the taxation Act. People are not entitled to organise their affairs in any way so as to minimise the amount of duty or tax that they may be required to pay under the relevant legislation. The moment they bob up their heads in any particular way they will get them shot off by the Government. This Government will pin people to the absolute maximum with regard to the tax that they may be required to pay or, in this particular case, with regard to the customs tariffs which they may have to pay.

Let us now look at this complex legislation. On 1 December the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) announced that the Law Reform Commission would inquire into the Customs Act, the Excise Act and 11 related Acts and report back to the Government by 30 September 1989. He gave the Law Reform Commission not 12 months, but only until 30 September 1989 to look at this complex legislation and come back with some simple changes to it. The Attorney-General acknowledged that the legislation has been described as `complex and labyrinthine'. It was specifically recommended for urgent review by the task force established by the Comptroller-General of Customs to examine alleged shortcomings in Customs legislation and practice. That task force reported in March 1987 and the Government has claimed that this legislation is the result of its recommendations. But that report has never been made public. The Government has refused to reveal its contents yet it expects the Opposition to accept its assurance that this legislation results from that report.

The Government also argues that because of the importance of customs and excise legislation, recently announced amendments should proceed and would not prevent other amendments which might become necessary. I refer the Senate to a letter that I received from the Law Council of Australia dated 4 December of this year. In this letter the Secretary-General of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Bennett, says:

The Law Council of Australia believes it is most desirable that consideration of this Bill by the Senate should be deferred until the Autumn Sittings of Parliament next year. The Council believes that this course is necessary to enable its complex provisions to receive the consideration they deserve.

The Customs Law Committee of the Business Law Section of the Law Council has given this Bill such consideration as has been possible since its introduction on 18 November 1987 and has provided a report in which it has said as follows:

As the Bill had a speedy passage through the House of Representatives, the committee has not had time to undertake anything but a fairly cursory view of the issues raised by the Bill in the time available to it.

I will not read the rest of the letter, which goes on for another one and a half pages, but it contains a plea that the Senate do not deal with this legislation in a hasty manner but that the Opposition be given the opportunity to consider it in detail. That is what the Opposition seeks to do by this proposal now before the Senate.

I have had an enormous number of representations from Customs agents and industry. I ask that the Senate defer consideration of this Bill in order to give these people time to make the appropriate representations to the Government. I do not want the Opposition to be placed in the position of having to move amendments to correct the Bill. These people say that there are major defects in the Bill. They want time to consider the Bill and to make their representations to the Government. That is what the Opposition is proposing by this measure.

Let me deal with some of the problems that arise from this Bill. For example, there is the problem of the value of goods in Australian currency. We must consider whether their value is in accordance with the current rate of exchange at the date of purchase, the date that they are imported or some other date. The Government appears in this legislation to be attempting to overturn the decision of my very good friend-although I have not seen him for 10 years or so-Mr Justice Marks, a judge of the Victorian Supreme Court, in the recent case of AMI-Toyota Ltd against the Commonwealth.

Let me point to another problem in this legislation. The Government is changing the value of the transaction from the actual transaction value to the free on board or free on rail value. Frankly, I do not think that Government back- benchers or the Government committee understand what this proposed change means. Let me try to explain it to them in a way that they might understand. Let us presume for a moment that an importer is buying, say, rural industry products such as tractors. If he is buying small tractors which are capable of being placed in a container, and he buys them from a company in the middle of the United States of America or, if you like, in the middle of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, those tractors have to be taken from that factory works and transported overland to a ship which will then carry them to Australia. One must consider what free on board or free on rail value is to be placed on them.

One might find this incredibly difficult to believe. When I first heard it and understood it, I found it difficult, too. If the tractor is sufficiently small that it can be placed in a container at the factory works, its value is considered to be the free on rail value at the point of works. So the tractor might be worth $40,000 ex-factory; it is placed in a container at the factory and $40,000 is considered to be its value. If the tractor, the harvester or whatever is so big that it cannot fit into a container at the factory and must be loaded on to railway flat-top, transhipped across country at a cost of, say, $5,000 and loaded on to a ship at the port, the free on board cost becomes the cost when it is loaded at the port.

From the point of view of importing the vehicle, duty is imposed on one product at the rate of $40,000 because it was loaded into a container at the factory where it was manufactured but, in the other case, the vehicle was transported and loaded on to a ship, and the value becomes the cost of the product plus the cost of freighting it across the country. It is absolute nonsense to think that the tariff we impose should depend on whether the product can be loaded into a container at the works or whether it must be loaded on to a railway flat-top. I am sure that Government senators and members really have not understood that that is what this legislation is all about in regard to the free on board and the free on rail problem.

One particular company in Australia has a major difficulty in relation to that matter. I refer to Australian Consolidated Industries, which imports soda ash from the United States of America. Soda ash is a product which is not loaded into a container where it is purchased from the mine in the middle of the United States. It is shipped in open rail containers from the mine to the port and loaded in the ship in the way that one would expect a mineral to be loaded and shipped to Australia. What will happen is that there will be a 40 per cent increase in the tariff on that product because the cost of the product will include the cost of freighting it across the United States. What absolute nonsense is that? The cost of the freight should not in those circumstances be added to the cost of the product. But this Government is changing the provisions in order to, as I said, follow people down the burrow.

The Minister says, `We have to be very careful. Some people may be cheating here. Some people may be doing some deal with the freighters. So we have to be very careful and impose this tariff on the full value, including the cost of freight'. If the Government were to lower the tariff I would accept that maybe we ought to include the whole of the freight. But then we run into the difficulty which is in fact created by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade: that once the goods are loaded into a container they are considered to be free on board. So the Government is facing this major problem. What is it doing? It is ignoring it. That is the sort of thing to which this Government needs to give consideration. It is the sort of thing on which industry needs to have the opportunity to make its representations.

I point out that if that measure were applied in reverse-that is, to Australian products-we could visualise what would happen to tariffs imposed on our coal exports. Everyone knows that many of our coal exports in Australia have to be loaded on board rail in the State in which they are mined and transhipped by rail from the place where they are mined to the port. This is done at great expense, which is in fact a revenue earner for the relevant State government. If other countries around the world apply the principle that we are going to apply to them-if they apply in reverse the principle to Australian coal and other mineral exports-we will find that our coal and mineral exports will have this sort of tariff embargo placed on them, very possibly to the substantial detriment of this nation. I see a couple of members of the Government backbench sitting nodding their heads as they begin to understand the major problems in this matter. It is for these reasons that the Liberal and National parties are moving to have this Bill delayed until the autumn session.

I point out also that the Customs Agents Institute of Australia, the Customs Agents Federation of Australia and the Australian Federation of Air Freight Forwarders Ltd have all made similar representations to me. In addition, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has made similar observations. It said that clause 16, proposed new sub-section 165 (1), would provide no limitation period for the collector's power to demand further duty if the duty had been short levied by reason of fraudulent conduct. The example cited for comparison was that of the position of a private individual who had suffered loss on another's fraud. Such a person, the Committee said, is normally barred from recovering loss six years after he or she might with reasonable diligence have discovered the fraud. The Committee said that clause 16, new sub-clause (2), is a standard transitional provision which precludes new interest provision from applying in respect of goods entered for home consumption prior to the date on which the Act receives royal assent. Contrary to the interpretation suggested by the explanatory memorandum, the sub-clause explicitly says that the whole of the sub-section, and not the new interest provision only, would come into effect after the commencement of the section. Other matters are raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which I will not deal with in detail, as I am sure that honourable senators will read its report.

I have also received representations from accountants who act for Customs agents and individual clients in this matter. The sorts of points that I have heard are, for example, that the opportunity for a contribution to be made by commerce on both occasions that this Bill has been considered has been restricted to the period when the legislation has been before the Parliament. I heard the Minister tonight saying that this matter has been in the wind since April of this year. It may have been in the wind, but the only time that the industry and those associated with the industry have had an opportunity to consider this matter has been since the legislation came before the Parliament last month.

Accountants have pointed out to me that foreign freight, as I have mentioned in regard to rail freight, and insurance costs from the factory to the container are to be dutiable under this legislation. Existing and past legislation specifically provides for these costs to be non-dutiable, provided payment or benefit did not accrue to the overseas supplier. This placed goods containerised at the export port on the same dutiable footing as goods containerised at the factory. That so called equality is now removed. I ask: How are Customs going to determine the genuine freight for something shipped from, say, Moscow across the Trans-Siberian railway to Vladivostok? How are we to find out from the Soviet Union what was the rail cost of freighting goods across the Soviet Union? Are we going to write a letter to the Premier because the Soviet Union will not expose the cost of shipping goods across the country for export?

The Liberal and National parties do not object to the Government protecting its revenue, but there are changes which may have the most significant impact on importing activities. They deserve closer examination. Generally, these matters include, firstly, the fact that Customs valuation is moving away from a factual concept as envisaged under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, in other words, from the price stated on commercial documents, to some sort of manufactured value which the Australian Government will impose upon these goods. Secondly, there is an increase in dutiable values and the inclusion of foreign inland freight and insurance, which may also be counter-productive for our own exports. Thirdly, there is increasing inclusion of the value of services and obligations in dutiable values. But, for example, the Government intends to include agents' commissions on the purchase of these goods.

Another matter which deserves examination is the increasing intrusion into privacy by the beaurocracy and the increasing reliance on past the post examination procedures when goods have gone into the market with little chance to recover costs.

In summary, even discounting the self-interest of the Customs agents, a strong case has been made out for the Bill to be deferred to the autumn session. I also mention the Comptroller's powers to enable him to prosecute breaches, which he has successfully done, although section 183 of the Customs Act, which gives him wide powers, does not appear to have been utilised. The argument put forward by the Department that it is essential to have this legislation in place by 1 January 1988 does not appear to the Liberal and National parties to be justified in the absence of the use of section 183 and successful prosecutions under existing legislation.

Finally, I put it to the Government that it is a legitimate, reasonable and sensible approach that the Liberal and National parties are proposing to the Senate, which is that we give the industry, the lawyers, the accountants, the Customs agents and the individual companies an opportunity to examine the legislation and then make their representations so that the Government can make the changes which need to be made to this legislation, so that the Government can have its experts apply their minds to the sorts of representations that are being made and can solve the problems. Then the Government will be able to introduce the amendments. It will not require the Opposition parties to introduce the amendments. The Government will then have the support of the Liberal and National parties for this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I make only three points. First, the Australian Democrats will support this amendment by the Opposition. I would like to place on record that the Democrats are not about putting penalties in the way of the taxman, as asserted by Senator Button. We strongly support the proper and fair collection of tax. Our reason for supporting the amendment has nothing to do with any penalty being imposed on the Government by way of blocking this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that Senator Button has pointed to the importance of this legislation. He gave a figure of $140m as possibly being the amount of tax avoided in this area. If this legislation is so important, why is it being put through with such haste and so little consultation? It is not adequate for Senator Button to say that notice was given of this legislation back in April. This is a new Senate. Senator Button must know that he will not get legislation through unless he gets the support of at least one other party. In the light of that fact, he should have given more opportunity--

TALK.START.PARA: —You were given a month and you would not go into the blasted briefings that were offered to you.

—That assertion was made earlier by Senator Button. It is completely untrue. I repeat for Senator Tate's information, as he was not in the chamber earlier, that I approached Senator Button's Department-the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. It did not contact me during the several days remaining in that week while I was still in Canberra. I was contacted on the following Tuesday when I was back in Adelaide. I was leaving on the Thursday morning to go to Melbourne for a Senate standing committee meeting, and I stayed over in Melbourne until the Sunday, when I came back to Canberra. It was simply not physically possible to meet with officers from Senator Button's Department during that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, Senator Button asserted that one Customs agent had avoided paying $4m per year-I think that was his assertion. I simply point to the logical stupidity of such claims, because if that was known, the question must be posed, `Why was that Customs agent not taken to court for that avoidance?'. For that reason, the figure cannot possibly be known. It must remain an unsubstantiated assertion. Primarily for the reason that insufficient time has been given on this legislation, the Democrats will support the Opposition amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no point in entering into any lengthy defence of an untenable position, given the numbers in the chamber. I understand that Senator Lewis foreshadowed this amendment earlier and that Senator Button indicated why the Government was opposing, as it must of course, this proposition that there be a further delay in the passage of this extremely important legislation for the protection of revenue. But if the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are so minded, the sooner we have the division the better.
—Order! The question is that Senator Lewis's amendment to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate now turns its attention to the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987. This Bill amends the River Murray Waters Agreement and establishes a Murray-Darling Basin Commission. It will provide legislative recognition of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council and provide for the Ministerial Council to establish a Community Advisory Committee. In summary, the Bill replaces the River Murray Commission with a Murray-Darling Basin Commission which, in addition to assuming statutory responsibilities of the old Commission, will have an advisory role to the Ministerial Council on water, land and environmental matters in the Murray-Darling Basin not covered in the 1982 River Murray Waters Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: The four governments-the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian governments-will provide two commissioners each to represent water, land and environmental interests. The old Commission had four commissioners in total. The legislation establishes a ministerial council, comprising three Ministers from each of the four governments who are responsible for water, land and environment policies. The previous ministerial arrangements were for water Ministers only. The legislation establishes a Community Advisory Committee to bring together and present to the Council community views on the management of the natural resources of the basin. The chairman of the Committee is Professor John Burton of the University of New England and there are approximately 17 representatives of regional and national organisations. Complementary State legislation is presently before the State parliaments. Approximately six additional staff will be employed to provide advice on land and environmental matters at a cost of about $320,000, to be borne equally by the four governments.

I turn now to the issues raised by this proposal. The new Commission will have no additional constitutional power. It will continue to exercise the traditional authority to regulate the flow and division of Murray River water between the three States and the more recent power over water quality in the river and the advisory function of water quality in the State rivers flowing into the Murray. The stated purpose of the new arrangement encompassing the Murray-Darling Basin is to broaden the advisory role to include land and water and environment management in the basin. We hope that the inclusion of the responsible Ministers and officials will result in greater co-operation and co-ordination in the policies of each of the governments in relation to the region.

In 1985, Queensland refused to join the Council and Commission, but it has had an observer on the standing committee. Since 1985, there has also been a standing committee of the 12 departmental heads, which largely duplicates the Commission, which has eight of the same 12 officials. There is no commitment to additional finance to assist in the control of salinity-high water tables and drainage, for example, are beyond that allocated in the Federal waters assistance program (FWAP) and, to a lesser extent, in the national soil conservation and afforestation programs.

The taxation concessions-I refer to section 75 (d)-are also allowed for certain on-farm works for salinity control. This assistance is less in real terms than that provided by the coalition government in the national water resources program, and considerably less than the proposed bicentennial water program. Taxation concessions for on-farm works such as drainage, soil conservation, tree planting and so on were also more generous. The River Murray Commission enjoyed a good reputation along the river, usually superior to that of the States governments in relation to remedial measures. There is genuine local concern for the future of the area, and a sense of achievement with the improvement in water quality and land management practices. The rapid tourist development along the river is both a source of employment and an additional cause for environmental concern.

The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia warn of the concern of local people that their view will be ignored by the Council and the Commission. We also criticise the promotion of the new arrangement as the saviour of the area, and the inference that up until now nothing has been done by governments or farmers. That is absolute nonsense. There are problems, but much has been done. The coalition parties criticise the extra layers and numbers of Ministers and officials who will duplicate and retard the decision making process. We criticise the facade that additional bureaucratic structures will replace the need for Federal and State government financial assistance for already known remedial procedures-for example, salt interception works. We do not oppose the legislation, but I now move, in the following terms, a second reading amendment criticising the increased bureaucracy and politicisation of the decision making process and the lack of financial commitment for remedial measures:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate is of the opinion that the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement should be amended:
(a) to recognise progress made by previous governments, by the persons who live along the Murray River and in the River's drainage area;
(b) to reduce the new bureaucratic administrative and consultative arrangements for the Basin to enable efficient action and co-ordination; and
(c) so that the Government with the States provides a firm commitment to finance the already known necessary remedial measures along the Murray River which would immediately improve water quality''.

The Liberal and National parties do not oppose the legislation but this amendment makes certain criticisms of it. Whilst we have our grave concerns about this proposal by the Government we wish it well because we are desperately concerned about the problems of the River Murray. We say to the Australian Labor Party that it has a marvellous opportunity to solve the problems. The Labor Party is in government in Victoria, New South Wales and South Australia and federally, which gives it an opportunity which should not be missed to make changes which may not be possible on other occasions for political reasons. This is a marvellous opportunity for the Labor Party to get in there and genuinely do something about the River Murray.

I hope the massive bureaucracy that the Government has surrounded the River Murray basin with, and that I have referred to tonight, will not result in decisions being deferred or delayed while consideration is given to various alternatives, measures and arrangements, but will lead to action being taken. In particular, I make a plea for the reafforestation of the area because it is clear that the major problem for the land mass in the area is the high water table. As we know, trees pump water into the sky. Reafforestation of the entire area with many of the salt tolerant trees which have been developed in the Australian Capital Territory for this specific purpose should be carried out. The Government has a marvellous opportunity. I say to it: Please make sure that you take every advantage of the opportunity which you have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to speak to the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987. The legislation before us seeks to set in place a new institutional arrangement for the Murray-Darling Basin as a whole. New arrangements were agreed to by the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council in March of this year. They will give effect to the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement. This agreement amends the River Murray Waters Agreement. It establishes the Murray-Darling Basin Commission, which comes into effect on 1 January 1988. Further amendments provide for legislative recognition of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council and include provision for that Council to establish a community advisory committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The catchment area of the Murray-Darling Basin is, of course, huge-over one million square kilometres. Over 1 1/2 million people are directly affected by the River Murray, and the entire population of Australia is indirectly affected. The Murray-Darling Basin has been accurately described as Australia's agricultural heartland. As the Minister for Resources (Mr Peter Morris) acknowledged in his second reading speech, it produces about one third of Australia's total output from natural resource based industries. The area has 25 per cent of Australia's cattle and dairy farms, about 50 per cent of Australia's sheep, lamb and crops land and roughly three-quarters of Australia's irrigated land. In economic terms, this production is valued at around $10 billion annually.

Unfortunately we are forced to recognise that the Murray-Darling Basin is an area fraught with enormous problems. Of course, there is ample evidence that these problems have been the concern of many people over time, and increasingly so. I would suggest that the expression of those concerns has led to the political will to move in the direction in which we are moving with this legislation. I would simply like to point specifically to some of the problems as they are outlined in an article in November this year in the Times on Sunday by Ean Higgins entitled `A River At Risk'. One could go to any number of feature articles in newspapers and so on to come up with this range of problems. But I think it is important, when we are talking about legislation which is replacing the old River Murray Commission with a new authority with a different approach and a different base, just to look at some of the reasons why we are being asked to make some significant changes.

As I have said, the problems of the Murray River are widespread and impact very much not only on the people who live in the area but also on Australia as a whole. In the article to which I referred I think it is important to note the comments of Bruce Davidson, a senior lecturer in agricultural economics at Sydney University. He said:
. . . the irrigation program was a `terrible mistake' and has cost Australian taxpayers around $1 billion in expenditure never recouped.
He went on to say:
It was a failure economically but it was an enormous success politically.
Dr Davidson also said:
If you had a shaky electorate, you could promise them another dam. If you were really lucky, you could get two electorates; one where the dam is built and a second where you do the irrigation.

Of course, this is a bullet which is very difficult to bite. Paragraph (c) of the amendment which has been proposed to the second reading of the Bill, and which was circulated just a few minutes ago in the chamber by the Opposition', states:
so that the Government with the States provides a firm commitment to finance the already known necessary remedial measures along the Murray River which would immediately improve water quality.

I am not sure whether the Opposition is saying that it recognises the enormous problem that has been caused and that we should close down irrigation. The problem is that, after spending billions of dollars winning votes over the past century, State and Federal governments of both political colours now have to decide how to share the astronomical costs of repairing damage to the river environment.

Let me detail just some of the aspects of the damage in that river environment. Because of the increase in nutrients and because of the use of fertilisers along the river the build-up of excessive algae can clog up water supplies in the urban areas along the river. The doing away with the natural dry-wet cycle has caused all sorts of problems to the natural environment-the flora and fauna. Bob Pressey, a researcher in the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service, and one of the contributors to this article, said:
If you're interested in tucker for waterfowl which stimulates their breeding . . . water levels are very important.

This is the kind of thing that is disturbed by doing away with that wet-dry cycle which is natural in the area. As a former resident of the Echuca area and, therefore, the Barmah Forest area, I can only hope and trust that the wonderful stand of river red gum to be found in that area will be able to be sustained in the face of this change in the natural environment.

Of course, around the Kerang area in Victoria are the most spectacular examples of the enormous salination that has been caused along the Murray River. The Murray River crayfish is almost extinct locally in the Mildura area. De-snagging, which takes place because of the desire of human beings, as much as anything, to use the river for their recreational pursuits, deprives quite a number of river creatures of their homes and kills them off. The article tells us that, in the basin as a whole, 10 plant species are extinct, 37 are endangered and many more have been reduced in size and abundance. That information comes from the Ministerial Council report, which states:
. . . 20 species of small mammals are extinct and 16 are endangered. Six reptile species and 35 species of birds are also endangered.

The accumulation of a range of pollutants and the salinity problem are well known. Various studies of the Murray have come up with proposed final solutions. I am not sure which of those solutions is being referred to in the attachment which the Opposition is proposing. Rex McCann, a farmer in the Kerang district has formed the Pipe and Salt Committee. He proposes a scheme which would cost $500m to put in bores along the Murray, pump out the saline water table and run it in a PVC pipe in the middle of the river all the way to the sea.

Another proposal, known as the Pells scheme, proposes exactly the reverse: writing off the Murray, turning it into a sludge by channelling all the salt into it and constructing fresh water irrigation canals on either side of the river for its whole course, and so on. I do not know what the Opposition is referring to in its amendment. It is a last minute attempt to make some kind of political capital out of legislation which I believe clearly should be supported by everybody in this House. At the conclusion of this article, I believe the Adelaide University's Dr Walker makes a couple of particularly salient points. He states:
To fix the Murray . . . `would require a cost even government cannot accept. We are locked into a situation where solutions are apparent, but politically impractical' . . .
I do not know which of these solutions the Opposition is referring to. The article continues:
Despite its huge significance to Australia, the Murray-Darling remains one of the least understood river systems in the world.

I think we all as Australian citizens stand condemned for that fact and for not really knowing as much as we should know about this river system. However, we do have a new emphasis which the Australian Democrats are delighted about. The emphasis is as set out in the new Murray-Darling Basin Agreement, which states:

The Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian Governments wish to promote and co-ordinate effective planning and management for the equitable, efficient and sustainable use of the water, land and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin.

This approach is more holistic than previously where the focus was on the waters of the Murray and did not give adequate emphasis to the total catchment management involving co-ordinated use and management of not only water but also land, vegetation and other natural resources on a catchment basis.

As I said about three weeks ago while speaking on the sixty-ninth annual report of the River Murray Commission, the total catchment management approach, promoted for a number of years by many people, including the Catchment Education Trust-the doyen of that trust is Ernest Jackson who is now resident in the Albury area-and the Australian Democrats, is of fundamental importance and is a most desirable way of proceeding in the tasks of trying to remedy the degradation of our natural resources, conserving those resources and managing them in a sustainable way. This total catchment approach, providing as it does the most effective method of rural conservation in Australia, is part of the national conservation strategy and has been adopted by both the Victorian and New South Wales State governments in their implementation of policies on land degradation. The Democrats have welcomed the adoption of this strategy by those government. I note also in the minutes of the twenty-ninth meeting of the Australian Water Resources Council held in Perth in July this year that the South Australian Minister of Water Resources, Dr Don Hopgood, presented a keynote paper on integrated catchment management and stressed the importance of this approach in the light of the experience in South Australia.

I think it is important to put on the record here some of the challenges identified by Dr Hopgood in his paper, as a number of them are reflected in the legislation before us. They include: identification of integrated catchment management; research needs and gaps; education and promotion; public participation in integrated catchment management; and Council's agreement with the urgent need for all governments to give priority to the allocation of resources to integrated catchment management projects in a move to redress the damage of past practices. As well, Council noted a range of measures being implemented by various States consistent with the principles of integrated or total catchment management involving inter-disciplinary and inter-agency committees and workshops, extension work and publications.

There is only one effective way of tackling these problems and that is the holistic way. We are seeing the development of the whole-farm planning concept at the farm level. I mention the Potter farmland plan in Victoria's Western District, a scheme which sets up 15 demonstration farms showing the best principles of ecological farm management. The Potter farmland plan epitomises the new wave of responsible community action that is starting to emerge in some of Australia's most threatened regions. These are working partnerships between governments-State, Federal and local-private enterprise, and individual land-holders. Revegitation, tree planting, and proper planning and management of land use according to its natural soil types and environmental factors are its keynotes combined in a system of whole-farm planning.

I also refer to the National Farmers Federation kit `Caring For Our Country', which it has provided to schools for school children. This kit also takes the holistic approach-the whole-farm approach-and stresses issues such as soil erosion, salinity, and tree decline. It is a first-class kit for children. It will make a great contribution towards the educational aspects of what is necessary in this whole process and will help to secure Australia's future. The kit contains a great deal of information and attitudinal education.

This legislation also establishes a commission which will have the capacity to facilitate measures and actions based on total catchment management. It further expressly provides for public participation via a community advisory committee. I would hope that this committee will also be very useful in the promotion and education of total catchment management. In this context, I am rather bemused by the second point of the Opposition's proposed second reading amendment in which it says that the agreement should be amended `to reduce the new bureaucratic, administrative and consultative arrangements'. I hope that the Opposition is not demonstrating there a lack of support for community consultation.

In a recent article entitled `Agriculture Needs Hard Thinking on Land Usage' in the journal Inside Australia, Jim Gasteen, who is a former grazier and now land use consultant and conservationist, recognised that it is not possible to continue producing and consuming at an ever-increasing rate without proper consideration of the ecological processes essential to a healthy, balanced environment and that failure to achieve this means failure of both natural and man-made systems. Later in his paper, commenting on trying to combat issues such as soil erosion and land degradation in general, and although major advances have been made in science and technology and there has been a great upsurge in awareness of the problems facing all countries, Mr Gasteen stated:
The great difficulty of actually making things work remains.
This is crucial. Mr Gasteen continued:

Better communication is needed at all levels to bridge the gap between the rural sector and governments, and to develop better relations among administrators, educators, developers and conservationists.

He further states that in helping to create a framework for change `one of the most important steps in this process is the formation of a wide variety of government advisory and consultative committees incorporating community interests'. The Australian Democrats believe that this legislation is providing for the community advisory committee process which will do this.

Finally, I believe that the Government wants a strong, co-operative approach to better management of the Murray-Darling Basin. I commend the concerted and conscientious efforts by the governments of South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales, along with the Federal Government, in putting aside parochial views of the past in order, in the words of Jim Gasteen, to make things work.

I will comment on the first point in the Opposition's second reading amendment, in which it calls upon the Senate to recognise progress made by previous governments. I can only see that as a plea for the Senate to give some kind of pat on the back to previous coalition governments at State and Federal level in that area. Given the abysmal history, I do not see how either the coalition or the Australian Labor Party, having been in government in those jurisdictions at any time during our community's exploitation of the Murray-Darling area, could possibly want to give a pat on the back to any of the governments involved. Certainly, people living along the Murray River, who are also mentioned in this attachment, have tried and are trying at the moment to redress these critical problems. I believe that this legislation will go much further in addressing these problems and the Australian Democrats are pleased to support this new initiative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987 is to amend the present agreement between the Commonwealth and State governments involved in the River Murray in order to establish the Murray-Darling Basin Commission. The geographical area relating to this Bill is about one-seventh of Australia, so we are talking about a considerable area. It is an area which is represented by the honourable member for Riverina-Darling, Noel Hicks-a very good Opposition member and Whip of the National Party of Australia in the House of Representatives. It is also represented by the honourable member for Farrer, Mr Tim Fischer, and the honourable member for Murray, Mr Lloyd, two very good members of parliament.
—And me!

—Senator Hill says that he plays quite a part in representing that part of the Murray that goes through South Australia. Therefore, a lot of people are interested in this Bill and a lot of people represent those who are living in those areas. Obviously, if they represent those areas, they also represent the soil and the country. The area is a major producer of agriculture. In fact, it supports not only the politicians whom I have just mentioned but also 25 per cent of the nation's sheep and cattle farms, about 50 per cent of its sheep, lambs and crop lands, and almost 75 per cent of its irrigated land. It is an immense area of very productive land. In productive terms, it generates about $10 billion worth of production annually. This is a great area which produces a lot for Australia. Equally as large as the area is the bureaucracy involved in its management. Some 33 State Government departments or authorities and an additional 10 intergovernmental organisations are involved. By any judgment, this area is of unbelievable importance to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The Murray-Darling river system involves more than 20 major rivers and is the fourth longest in the world-3,780 kilometres. It provides almost three-quarters of the water used in Australia for domestic purposes, industry and agriculture. Sixteen cities draw their water supply from it. Yet over the years we have much exploited and battered this very precious resource. The rivers in this system and the country they drain have been suffering enormous problems with soil degradation and salinity for many years. Salinity problems have been getting progressively worse and today we have a situation where every 60 seconds a massive 2.5 tonnes of salt-more than 1.3 million tonnes of salt a year-flows over the South Australian border and into the State that Senator Hill represents.

In a dry year the concentration of salt can exceed the World Health Organisation's maximum desirable level for drinking water. Within South Australia itself, major inflows of saline ground water cause steep rises in salinity levels under both normal and dry conditions. Much of this salt comes from inflows of water into the river caused by rising water tables. That is one of the biggest causes of salinity. This has been caused by two factors-the clearing of native vegetation and irrigation. Native mallee trees with root systems that can reach to a depth of some 17 metres are a very effective means of extracting water. Unfortunately, many of these trees have been felled and as a result recharge rates have increased. In some areas of irrigation ground water levels have risen to such an extent that they are already at the surface. of course, as the water rises it brings with it dissolved salts. This results in wasted land. It is now estimated that some 1,219 square kilometres of irrigation land suffers from saline soils and 5,240 square kilometres overlie an ocean of salt water less than two metres below the surface. So we can see that there is definitely a problem in these areas.

I believe that the Community Advisory Committee proposed under this Bill will help to focus on community concerns about the management of the rivers. Of course, the Government would want to ensure that it listens to the community's views on the matter. The Government ought to be aware that local groups are not at all convinced that their views will be taken into consideration. This is one of my concerns with the Bill. Of course, if one is cynical one could be excused for thinking that this Government is merely window-dressing the problem-creating a bit more bureaucracy and pretending to do a little more. It is a pity that Senator Richardson has left the chamber. If he spent more attention and effort on soil degradation and some of these other things that are going on with the soil around Australia, rather than just worrying about the popular issues such as trees alone in rainforests, he would be doing a lot more for the productive resources of this great country. If this legislation turns out to be what has been suggested by some people, this Government stands condemned-as does the rest of Australia for allowing it to get away with it.

In recent months studies have been initiated at least to determine the extent of the problem and to put into some order priorities for repair. According to the Murray-Darling Basin environmental resources study prepared for the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council, high priority projects to overcome the most urgent problems would cost about $172m. To repair the entire system would cost $785m. These are not inconsiderable sums. The proposed scheme to pump salt water through the bores from the water table around the Murray and channel it into basins to evaporate is at least a start. It will cost about $27m to establish and around $1.7m annually to run.

The problems of the Murray include salinity but there are more problems than that. Salinity is one part of the overall problem of land degradation. A preliminary estimate of the annual value of agricultural production forgone through land degradation in various forms at the present time amounts to $217m, which is by far the biggest loss. Nearly $145m a year is the result of loss of soil structure-that vital resource, the soil. Other degradation problems include wind erosion on pastoral lands; sometimes during drought it also affects crop lands. Water erosion is a significant hazard in all areas. Soil acidity-due to pasture improvement and use of fertilisers-occurs extensively. Soil structure decline, a result of bad ploughing techniques, is widespread in cropping areas. Shrub invasion of semi-arid grazing lands and a decline of palatable range land species affect wide areas, and pest plants and animals cause degradation and heavy economic losses throughout the region as well.

The environmental study suggests that the primary goal in managing land resources should be to achieve efficient and sustainable production whilst avoiding or minimising off-side effects. Research needs to be done into salinity, soil erosion, acidification, desertification and pest and plant control. More work also needs to be done on apathy. It is one of the biggest problems that we have with the preservation of our natural resources in Australia. It is, after all, apathy associated with ignorance that has brought about much of today's problems. Continuing apathy will only exacerbate the problem. That is what I fear most about this legislation.

I do not believe that any government has done, or is doing, enough about the problems of salinity, soil loss, acidity and a host of other problems associated with our productive resources. It is not being done because the solutions are too hard to implement. Certainly, in recent years, farmers in northern Victoria have changed their irrigation techniques because of the rising water tables. Farmers who use the river system are only too aware of how precious a resource they are dealing with. They must be congratulated for that and for the fact that they are taking some precautionary steps at this stage. But they must be given government encouragement and support. There must be financial incentives for people to do the right thing. There must be action by State and Federal governments and, if you like, a bit more `putting your money where your mouth is'; rather than just talking about conservation, something should actually be done.

This Government, of course, is a born again greenie, chasing an environmental vote just because it is a vote, but not having an interest in the actual resource. It claims to have won the hearts and minds of conservationists of this country; I really doubt it. If that is so, let it start to prove it. Let it by all means bring forward Bills such as this to show that it is working on the problems, but let it improve this increased bureaucracy, do some real work and make some real improvements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As my colleagues Senator Lewis and Senator Brownhill have pointed out, the River Murray Waters Amendment Bill 1987, which we are debating, replaces the River Murray Commission with a Murray-Darling Basin Commission which, in addition to assuming the statutory responsibilities of the old Commission, will have an advisory role to the Ministerial Council on water, land and environmental matters in the Murray-Darling Basin which were not covered in the 1982 River Murray Waters Agreement. The Bill will provide legislative recognition of the Murray-Darling Basin Ministerial Council and provide for the Ministerial Council to establish a community advisory committee. I note in that broad context that a meeting of the Ministerial Council last Friday, which was reported in the Press over the weekend, stated that the Ministers from the three States-that is, New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria, my own State-and the Commonwealth have taken the first concrete steps to jointly fund a clean-up of the River Murray by approving a $22m desalination project. I will return to that subject later.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe, in supporting the amendment to the motion for the second reading moved by my colleague Senator Lewis, that insufficient recognition in recent times has been given to the work that has been done by previous governments of all political persuasions in terms of the River Murray situation. It is important not to lose sight of that work.
