Although I totally support the gist of Senator Brownhill's comments, a great deal more could well have been done in the past to improve the River Murray situation, and certainly a great deal must be done in the future because, as Senator Brownhill said, the River Murray system is one of the great river systems of the world. It is a major provider of irrigation water for 75 per cent of Australia's total irrigated land. It supports, as Senator Brownhill mentioned, one-quarter of Australia's cattle and dairy farms and also about 50 per cent of the sheep, lambing and cropping land of our nation. It is a very important source of water supply. It is a major and growing recreation area. It has been a fundamental part of our nation's history. The historical events that have occurred in the Murray River region form a major part of our history. A great deal of work needs to be done to improve this river system. In view of the timing arrangements for the Senate tonight, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs:
(a) whether the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1987 should apply to all wars rather than only the Second World War; and
(b) whether the definition of serious crimes in clause 6 of that Bill is appropriate,
and that the Committee consider these matters in conjunction with the other matters relating to the Bill referred to it.

The motion provides for the terms of reference of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, in its consideration of the War Crimes Amendment Bill, to be broadened to cover the question of whether `war crimes' should cover all war crimes rather than just those that occurred in the war that ended 42 years ago; and that the Committee also examine the suitability of the definition of war crimes.

To explain the importance I attach to these matters it is necessary to go back to the antecedents of this Bill, which is intended to deal with the possible nazi war criminals identified by the Menzies Review of Material Relating to the Entry of Suspected War Criminals into Australia. It is a peculiar Bill, but not nearly as peculiar as the War Crimes Act of October 1945 which it will replace. That Act set up military courts to try war criminals, most of whom were in Allied hands as a result of the unconditional surrender of Germany and Japan. There were a number of notable features about these military courts. First, they had a nice flexible definition of war crimes as `a violation of the laws and usages of war', supplemented by a list of 35 specific war crimes ranging from planning wars of aggression, murders and massacres to wanton destruction of property, cannibalism and mutilation of the dead.

The second notable feature was that the death penalty could be imposed by a two-thirds majority if the court had more than three members. Thirdly, it had extra-territorial application. Fourthly, the offences had to be committed against persons who had at some time been resident in Australia, although this provision was extended to cover Allied citizens. Finally, up to half the court could be non-Australians.

The real intention of the Act was to deal with Japanese war criminals; it was assumed that German war criminals would be dealt with in Europe. There was no thought of such people migrating to Australia. Between 1945 and 1951 the military courts tried 924 war criminals-all Japanese-of whom 644 were convicted and 148 executed. There have been no trials since 1951. Everyone thought that the Act was dead, although there were occasional allegations of war criminals living in Australia, until last year when the Australian Broadcasting Corporation produced radio and television programs that made sensational allegations that United States, British and Australian intelligence organisations had collaborated to settle large numbers of nazi criminals in Australia, with the connivance of the Menzies Government.

These sensational allegations led to the inquiry by Mr Menzies, formerly of the Attorney-General's Department. He could find no basis for the allegations. As so often happens, however, an inquiry clears one target but hits another. Mr Menzies found that there are perhaps 70 people in Australia who might be guilty of serious war crimes on Germany's behalf. He did not investigate whether there were any other war criminals in Australia because that was not within his terms of reference. In view of the very large number of migrants taken by Australia, including many displaced persons, it is astonishing that more war criminals were not able to slip through in the post-war confusion.

What are we to do about these war criminals? Although the crimes are more than 40 years old, there is general agreement that we must take action now on the serious crimes-murder and so on. It has been suggested by Dr Knopfelmacher, among others, that pursuing war criminals now, 40 years later, will cause a rise in anti-semitism. It may, but it certainly should not. The Jews were by no means the only victims of the nazi death camps. There were also large numbers of homosexuals, communists and gypsies murdered, to name only the largest groups. To blame the 60,000 Jews in Australia for the pursuit and bringing to justice of these war criminals would be absurd. The offences are outrageous-murder and mass exterminations-and no responsible government could fail to investigate and, if necessary, punish such offences by its residents. Time does not absolve murder or mass extermination. The only way we could increase anti-semitism would be if we gave the impression that the only war crimes we were concerned about were war crimes against Jews.

The Bill has peculiar features. It purports to amend the War Crimes Act, yet it is really an entirely new Act. All that remains of the original Act is the title and the commencement date. Apparently, this was done so as to pretend that the Bill is not retrospective. But of course it is. In concept it is a total reversal. The original Act dealt with foreigners who had committed crimes against Australian residents. The new Bill deals with Australian residents who have committed crimes against foreigners and applies to wars in which Australia was not involved.

Another debatable feature of the Bill is the definition of `serious crimes'-the war crimes which could be prosecuted in our courts. They range from murder and rape to wounding and `being, by act or omission, in any way directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in, or party to, the commission of' murder, wounding, et cetera. The war criminal can also be prosecuted even if what he did `was required or permitted by the law in force when or where the act was done'. These seem to go far beyond what could usefully or properly be prosecuted in an Australian court under a retrospective law. They may be necessary to bring criminals to justice but surely they should be closely examined to see whether they are really essential, for they are very draconian.

Finally, there is my fundamental objection to this Bill as it stands. We are producing what is really an entirely new War Crimes Act, recognising the fact that there may be Australian citizens or residents who have been guilty of serious war crimes and recognising that the ordinary processes of extradition do not cope with the special nature of war crimes. Yet we deal with only one war, which ended 42 years ago. What has happened to all the other wars? Since 1945 there have been 70 wars. Ten are still going on now. To take one example, the Pol Pot blood-bath in Cambodia was worse than anything that went on in Hitler's Germany. We have taken in nearly 14,000 Cambodian refugees. Are any of them war criminals? The Government does not know. Mr Menzies certainly does not know. He investigated only World War II war crimes by Germany and its associates. What would we do if we got credible evidence that one of the Cambodian refugees was a war criminal? Would we send him back to be tried by Vietnamese-dominated courts? Would we ignore the evidence? Or would we pass another special retrospective War Crimes Act?

One argument that has been advanced for the limited coverage of the Bill is that one should pass such laws only after an inquiry such as that by Mr Menzies has identified possible war criminals. But that is not what this Bill does. It covers war crimes in Africa, Asia and the Pacific, which were certainly not investigated by Mr Menzies. In the House of Representatives an effort was made to amend the Bill to cover the Soviet occupation of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, which again were not investigated by Mr Menzies. We have taken in many migrants from areas where war crimes were committed. We owe it to Australian citizens and residents-and future migrants-to make it clear how we intend to handle war crimes.

One can make a case that Australian trials of alleged war criminals for crimes committed overseas are simply too difficult and too socially divisive and that they should therefore be left to the ordinary extradition processes, provided that a prima facie case has been made out and we are satisfied that the trial would be fair. Alternatively, one can say that because of the special nature of war crimes and the obvious shortcomings of the extradition process we have to try them in Australia lest serious criminals go free. But this would surely have to apply to all war crimes. In my view the present Bill falls between these two stools.

I strongly believe that we should consider very carefully the reason for the limitation of the Bill to Second World War crimes and the proposed definition of war crimes, but I accept that at this stage of the session the Senate is not prepared to have a prolonged debate on these complex and emotional issues. The Opposition has no wish to delay the prosecution of any World War II criminals who can be identified. We also owe it to our citizens not to act in any way that stirs up community bitterness. For that reason I do not intend to force my motion to a division. I have raised the matter now so that the Senate and the community can consider the complex issues involved, the balance of difficulties, so we are ready to deal with the problems when the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee reports back to us next year on the Bill.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Processing of Legislation-Intermediate-range Nuclear Weapons-Australian Sports Commission-Local Government: Tasmania-Adult Migrant English Program-Parliament House: Provision of Parking Facilities for Motor Cycles-Spouses: Tribute-Aboriginal Culture

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence my remarks on the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty, I would just like to say a few words about the way in which legislation is being processed in these last days of the session. It is one thing for senators to play games and manage legislation almost by attrition, but I am conscious of the fact that as a result staff have been keeping the sorts of hours that I do not believe they should be working. It is one thing for us as politicians who want to change the world to work whatever hours we like, but I do not believe that whatever penalty rates the staff are getting justify the extended hours, separation from families and so on that they have to endure. I am not trying to point the finger at the Government in terms of its management of Government business, but at all of us as senators who played silly games and wasted the time of the Senate earlier in the session when we could have been addressing some real issues and thus avoided this sort of backlog.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the INF treaty that was signed earlier in the week, to which I did not get a chance to speak during Senator Teague's urgency motion. I would like to put the point of view that that treaty is a victory not for deterrence and the Western alliance but for ordinary people who have come together in their local areas around the world in what is loosely described as the peace movement. That peace movement is not an homogeneous, organised, centralised group of people but a vast mass of people concerned about the existence of nuclear weapons, their cost and their dangers. Had it not been for ordinary people around the world creating a climate for disarmament, disarmament would not have occurred.

Had President Reagan not felt that he could salvage a place in history by signing such an agreement, he would not have done so. Had Gorbachev not felt that he would get the support of his people in such an agreement, he would not have signed. It has been the peace movement throughout the world, on both sides of the Iron Curtain, which has pushed this matter, sometimes at great cost. Peace activists in the Soviet Union have been imprisoned. Peace activists have been imprisoned in Israel, the United States, Tibet and elsewhere for their peace work. People have been imprisoned everywhere for working for peace. It is a tough struggle. It has not had the sort of recognition it deserves.

The other night honourable senators tried to say that there had been a victory for deterrence and the Western alliance. It may be a victory for the Western alliance or the super-powers in that there has not been a nuclear conflict since 1945, but that does not mean that it has not had a cost. As I pointed out some time ago, the very existence of nuclear weapons and their deployment leads to the impoverishment of the Third World and political oppression around the world. The sorts of global strategies that are necessary to maintain the control one needs over one's allies lead to political oppression. The diversion of wealth from human need to military need costs the lives of hundreds of millions in the Third World.

To say that deterrence is somehow a victory or has somehow worked is a lie. It ignores the horrendous cost that is being paid mainly by the Third World but also in the developed world in the form of economic instability. The Ambassador for the United States in Australia said to us, when we went to nail an eviction notice to a door outside his place, that the United States had gone into deficit to police the world. He confessed that the United States deficit was largely the result of its military spending. Of course, the United States deficit is one of the major sources of instability, economically, in the world, and that is a cost of the nuclear military strategies that are being conducted around the world.

Deterrence has had social, economic and political costs, and is continuing to have those social, economic and political costs around the world, which are not taken into account when we argue over whether we should try to match weapons around the world-whether missiles such as SS20s should be matched by Pershings, or the other jargon of the nuclear game. We seem to ignore what it takes to have them, to keep them and to deploy them.

We need to be cautious about the INF treaty. I think it is a significant breakthrough. I am not trying to deny that there is something significant about that treaty. It represents the first occasion on which there has been an agreement to disarm-an agreement to dismantle nuclear weapons. Unfortunately, it may not lead to a reduction of nuclear weapons. On the very day that the treaty was signed, concerned scientists were pointing to the fact that the weapons would be recycled-that many of the warheads that will be taken out of the European theatre will be recycled and put on other missiles elsewhere. The other place to which the nuclear arms race is going is the sea. The nuclear arms race may be being pushed back on land, but it is certainly going ahead at a rapid rate at sea. One of the places which we are most concerned about is the north-west Pacific. At this stage there is very little hope, very little light at the end of the tunnel, of seeing some sort of disarmament agreement about sea-based missiles in the north-west Pacific.

I do not think that we, and especially the peace movement, can relax. The peace movement in the United States has still to convince the legislators that they should ratify this treaty. Five of the six hopeful replacements for Ronald Reagan have admitted publicly that they disagree with the INF treaty, and there is a strong feeling in some circles that the United States Senate may not ratify it. So it is largely the peace movement of the United States which will to have to carry its leaders the rest of the way from the signing to the ratification. I hope it has greater success than it had with the SALT II treaty.

Having listened to these wonderful statements about disarmament coming from all sides, I wish to give a couple of brief quotes. Kenneth Adelman, who was the Director of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency at the time, said:
. . . a primary role of the arms control process is to reassure the public that somehow, some way, its government is grappling with the nuclear issue.
Richard Birt stated:
The purpose of this whole process-
that is, the arms control process-
is maximum political advantage. It's not arms control we're engaged in it's alliance management.

So the disarmament process, at least in the United States, is seen as a way of pacifying its allies, such as Australia, and convincing them that it is doing something about disarmament. That will allow it to carry on with building its nuclear net.

Another thing we have seen in recent times is our own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with the ink hardly dry on the paper, using the INF treaty to justify Pine Gap and its role in verifications, and to cement the US presence on Australian soil. The verification argument is an important one. I am not suggesting that verification is not important; I am suggesting that what is required is not on-site verification by the countries involved, by both the super-powers. In fact, another breakthrough in the INF treaty was an agreement on on-site verification. The United States baulked at it for a while, but then came to the party, and both super-powers have agreed to on-site verification. That is a very important and significant breakthrough.

The fact that we have not got proper verification has often been misused as a reason why either side has not been able to conclude watertight treaties. I am suggesting that we should internationalise the verification process. Verification needs to be independently and reliably done. It is not a pipe dream. There have been all sorts of proposals for internationalised verification processes. Scientists and others around the world have proposed methods of verification which take away the verification monopoly from the super-powers. The problem with internationalising verification, and the reason why the super-powers have opposed on-site verification by international bodies, is that it takes away their monopoly on certain types of intelligence. For example, at this stage, information and intelligence about space monitoring of nuclear tests and missile firing is available only to the super-powers.

While the super-powers have a monopoly on that sort of intelligence, they have a monopoly on the propaganda war. The United States, for instance, complains about a large radar system which apparently breaches the anti-ballistic missile treaty. Who knows? I would like to know; we would all like to know. The only people who do know are in the Soviet Union and the United States, and if there were not such a monopoly on such intelligence, neither side would be able to beat the drum and say, `Look what those people over there are doing. We ought to arm ourselves to protect ourselves against what they are doing over there'. With an international arms verification process, they lose a great deal of the propaganda value that enables them to increase their weapons development.

In the United States, every year at around about Budget time, we hear more scares about the Soviets being dominant in this field, that field or the other field and that is used as a reason why the United States should develop this or that. I would not be surprised if it goes on on the other side too. The point is that if the verification process were internationalised by the use of something like a United Nations agency, or some international process, we would all know what was happening and we would have real information with which to make some sort of judgment.

I would like to make many other points, but I would also like to make some concessions to the complaints I made earlier about going late. Therefore, my last point concerns the question of multilateralism and unilateralism. Whenever there is a debate in this place, or in any place, about disarmament, the peace movement is usually accused of being unilateralist and people say that we want one side to disarm itself of everything and leave the other side with all its weapons. Unilateralism may have some relevance in the context of the United Kingdom, which has its own involvement in the whole process. There is a debate about whether Britain should come in or come out or do its own thing on disarmament and there may be some substance to the unilateralism or multilateralism debate there, but it certainly has no substance here and I do not believe that unilateralism could work anyway and I do not think that anyone else does either.

Mr Lange, Prime Minister of New Zealand, in his much publicised debate, said that multilateralism and multilateralist disarmament policies do not prohibit unilateral initiatives. The whole point is that someone has to make the first move. Every step forward, every agreement begins unilaterally, in that one person or one power takes the initiative to talk to the other power. That is a unilateral initiative. As far as I can see, the whole question of multilateralism or unilateralism is just a false debating vehicle in that successful world-wide disarmament, as the peace movement believes in it, means that absolutely everybody gets rid of nuclear weapons, that nobody has nuclear weapons. Total worldwide nuclear disarmament is what we are all on about. The question is basically one of process and any process has to begin with someone taking the initiative. If that is unilateralism, I am a unilateralist. It is a pipe-dream to believe that either side is going to throw its nukes in the ocean and say, `OK, we are getting rid of our weapons'. That is a dream. No one is going to do that. The road to disarmament comes through negotiation, the sort of negotiation that has been going on recently. I believe in unilateral initiatives that lead to multilateral disarmament.

I once again congratulate the peace movement around the world, which has been struggling for many years to achieve disarmament. There has been a breakthrough and I do not think the role of the peace movement in that has been sufficiently recognised. The role of the peace movement in securing the future of the treaty, to see it is carried through with arms being dismantled, will be important. The peace movement around the world will need to take the initiative-not pause and rest on its laurels-and try to push the current situation further along the road to total disarmament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the occasionally irritating behaviour of Senator Wood, I trust that when the High Court of Australia makes its pronouncement at 2.15 p.m. tomorrow he will find himself still with us. On the basis of my current knowledge, were the High Court to pronounce otherwise those who have been irritated by Senator Wood do not know the half of it should they get a potential replacement as has been suggested in proceedings before the High Court. Mr President, with you in the chair and Senator Richardson as the Minister on duty, I also confess a certain degree of vested interest in hoping that the High Court is possessed of the wisdom of Solomon on this occasion. If it is going to do anything particularly nasty, at least I hope it arranges to do it to as few people as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I make my other remarks, I reiterate yet again that members of the Opposition would entirely reject the thesis which Senator Wood has put forward this evening about the role of the peace movement as the primary initiator of the success of the current intermediate-range nuclear forces negotiations. I reiterate the point which my colleague Senator Robert Hill, in an extraordinarily well informed and sophisticated presentation the other evening, made about the progress towards disarmament from a position of strength. I remind honourable senators that the historical position has always been that those who pretended that this can be achieved from the position of weakness and neutrality suffered the same fate that Belgium suffered during the First World War and the Scandinavian countries suffered during the Second World War. In terms of appreciating who is responsible for the current situation, I remind my honourable colleagues of the quotation from Dante which effectively proposes that the hottest place in hell is reserved for those who in the hour of moral crisis choose to remain neutral.

Nevertheless, if I might briefly pass from the sublime to the ridiculous, I come to the Australian Sports Commission. My purpose in rising this evening is simply to indicate to the Senate that, following the dissenting comments which Senator Reid, Senator Vanstone and I entered into the report of Senate Estimates Committee F about the processes which that Committee adopted in coming to a conclusion about the participation of certain senior public servants in the last Federal election campaign, I have received correspondence from Mr A. E. Harris, the Chairman of the Australian Sports Commission, which he wishes me to place on the public record, defending the role of the Australian Sports Commission and senior officers of the Commission for what he believes to have been an attack upon them which, in his opinion, was unjustified. I simply seek the concurrence of the Senate to table the correspondence which I have received from Mr Harris on that matter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the correspondence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise for being one of the adjournment speakers who are keeping people here late tonight, but this is the only time at which I can raise a matter that has been a major concern of mine since coming to this place. I refer to the effect of the new funding arrangements for local government and in particular its effect on my State of Tasmania-in other words, what has been the effect of the change from the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1946 to its replacement Local Government (Financial Assistance) Act 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Those people who have been following with some interest my passage from Tasmania to this place-and there are one or two of them-would have noted that I have asked a series of questions. On numerous occasions the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) has said in answer to those questions that the new system of payments is operated on a more equitable basis. This may have been the intention of the Government but the fact is that, in practice, it is not working and my State of Tasmania is receiving a reduction in real terms of 5 per cent this year. Next year it will face a similar reduction of 5 per cent. We know that this year the total funding for local government in Australia has risen in line with inflation, yet this year and next year Tasmania will receive a reduction of 10 per cent. Is this equitable? The Minister, in answer to a question by Senator Knowles concerning loss of income to local government by the substitution of annual payments with quarterly payments, said:
. . . when I was speaking to some 13 local authorities in south-east Queensland I received an assurance from them that they were prepared to do their bit in terms of exercising this restraint.

Is it then expected that Tasmanians show restraint when we know that the rest of Australia will be receiving Commonwealth financial assistance that has been updated in accord with inflation? Instead, the Minister continues to say that funds are allocated on a more equitable basis. On 29 October, in answer to my colleague Senator Panizza, Senator Reynolds again stated:

It is true that this year, and following the Self National Inquiry into Local Government Finance, a new system of distribution throughout the country on a much more equitable basis, a needs basis, was introduced.
On 2 November, Senator Reynolds, in answer to a question asked by me, stated following an interjection from my good friend Senator Boswell-who is not with us tonight; he is probably home in bed:

If Senator Boswell would care to have some information about the number of councils in north Queensland which will benefit over the next six years by between a 20 per cent and a 40 per cent increase in local government funding, I would be happy to provide that answer.
She went on to say:

I repeat to Senator Calvert, and to other Opposition senators who have suddenly displayed an incredible interest in local government, and I welcome that interest, that it is a procedure that involves partly per capita and partly needs. It is a new system which the majority of local authorities have welcomed because it is a more equitable process of distribution.

I do not believe that it is on a more equitable basis. How can this be when north Queensland will benefit over the next six years with increases of some 20 per cent to 40 per cent and, at the same time, as far as can be ascertained, our State of Tasmania will be facing a reduction of 10 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been involved in local government for longer than Senator Reynolds has ever had an interest in it.
—That may be so. I am just stating the facts and I want to roll them all together, if I can.
—For how long were you a warden?
—Four years. Again, on the same day, Senator Reynolds said in answer to a question from Senator Chaney that funding is on a part per capita and part needs basis. She stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the per capita basis we are looking at a 30 per cent figure, but the remainder of funding is distributed on a needs basis. I repeat that it is a very complex procedure; it is a procedure which I do not propose at this stage to outline in detail to the Senate.

How can the Minister continue to say that it is on a more equitable basis when she says that north Queensland will be getting a 20 per cent to 40 per cent increase and Tasmania as a whole will be reduced by 10 per cent in the next two years? It could be seen by some confused people that the money is being handed out on a climatical basis. The fact is that the Government tried to devise a scheme to favour the western suburbs of Melbourne and Sydney for its own political gain. It has not worked, and I think Senator Reynolds is as confused as everyone else. On 23 November I again asked a question as to why Hobart, the capital of Tasmania, and another major city, Glenorchy, were going to lose over $1m in funding in the next two years. The answer was as confusing as before. In her polite way, the Minister again invited me to a briefing and continued her explanation. She stated:
What happens in the process of Commonwealth funding going to the States is that each State has to submit a set of broad principles for the more equitable distribution of Commonwealth fundings.
She then went on to explain, once again, how fair the new funding was. She stated:

Some councils, especially those in growth areas and a number of rural areas, have not been getting the attention they deserve. The focus of the Self inquiry was to try to bring about a more equitable system throughout Australia.
Finally, the Minister decided it was time to shift the blame. The final piece of advice was given to me when she said:

It has to be remembered that it is the State Grants Commission to which Senator Calvert should be directing his concerns, because it is the State Grants Commission that ultimately determines the distribution. The Commonwealth only accepts the broad principles.
The saga continued and I was more interested to see that three days later, on 26 November, the Minister was asked a dorothy dixer by Senator Childs. He asked, God knows why:

Can the Minister for Local Government inform us of the effects that the Commonwealth's new general purpose financial assistance arrangements for local government are having on rural local councils? Is it true that the new system discriminates against councils outside the capital cities because the grants are now determined on the basis of population and the needs of councils are not taken into account?
Senator Reynolds stated in answer:
It is not true that the new system discriminates against rural councils.

The Minister may believe that, but how can we in Tasmania believe that when we see promises of increases to other States and prospects of reductions to our own State? We certainly have plenty of rural councils, but on investigation I found that five of the 46 councils in Tasmania this year will get increases in real terms and 41 will receive reductions. We have every right to ask questions on this important matter because there is no doubt that this Government is attacking Tasmania financially as no other government has ever done. Following reductions to the State Government of $270m, we now see that local government is being attacked.

Finally, the Minister has tried to shift the blame to the State Grants Commission. When I looked at its annual report I was very interested to see that it pointed out the inequities. On page 5 we found that Tasmania's share of funds for 1987-88 is $19,161,106, a paltry increase of only 2.4 per cent compared with the previous year's funds. The significantly less than average increase is explained by the movement towards a straight per capita distribution between States as provided for in the new legislation. On page 7 of that same report we find the truth of the matter. The report states:

The Commission firmly considers that the previous basis of allocation has resulted in an equitable distribution of the funds, a distribution which has found the general acceptance of the great majority of local government authorities in Tasmania.

However, the new principles of allocation proscribed in the Commonwealth Act, together with a desire for uniformity between States have led the Commission to the inescapable conclusion that significant changes would have to be made, notwithstanding the substantial effect on some existing grants. In this respect, the best that the Commission can do to cushion the fairly considerable loss of funds by some municipalities-
I think I have proved tonight by most municipalities-
is to ensure that the new methodology is phased-in over as long a period as possible.

For the Minister to say, as she has on many occasions, that finally it is the State Grants Commission which is to blame for the reductions is, of course, not true at all. My investigations find that the Commonwealth has insisted on not only having draft principles but also a rough calculation of the amounts involved. In other words the Grants Commission has been blackmailed into accepting reduced funding from the Commonwealth and on top of that the Minister has tried to blame it for the unfair treatment handed out to our State in an attempt to gain votes in the big cities. Finally, it is also a fact that the Minister has said that she has consulted with local government in Tasmania. That may be true and my colleagues in local government in Tasmania welcomed that initial consultation and they were very pleased with it. But it is interesting to note that once funds became available and the figures were made known, no input has been asked for and none has been given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to refer to two matters. The first relates to the program which for some years has been part of the rehabilitation section of the Woden Valley Hospital and that is the teaching of English to migrants who are part of that program, migrants for whom English is a second language, a difficult language, and one in which they have few skills. In particular it has been a part of the adult migrant English program. I refer to a letter, a copy of which I have received from Mrs Jane Wingfield, who has been a teacher in that program, addressed to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young). She states:

SPEECH.PARA: Can you help? After happily teaching in the AMEP-
that is, the adult migrant English program-
for twelve years I have now been given a task that I cannot bring myself to do.

I have been associated with the English classes held at Woden Valley Hospital on and off for most of these years. When I started there the classes were already established as the result of an innovative program . . . There were classes on five mornings and two afternoons. When the mainstream classes moved to Woden TAFE the rehabilitation classes continued at a maximum of four afternoons and with four teachers in the class giving a high teacher/student ratio . . .

Over the years, with successive cuts to the program, these classes have been greatly reduced. In 1987 I was the sole teacher there for only two hours on two afternoons each week despite the fact that the need is as great as ever.

She enclosed for me a sample of some of the work that the students have done. She explained that one of the people whom she has been assisting has had two brain tumours and takes a considerable time to write his own name. Another is a quadriplegic who speaks using a head wand and a spelling board but others have much greater skills. Apparently the program is to come to an end. The men in this program have been injured in industrial accidents and are now in hospital being rehabilitated. The hope of improving their English skills is really the only hope they have of ever finding a new job or of becoming a part of this society again. With their injuries and without English they are doomed to be institutionalised for virtually the rest of their lives. This program is not a luxury as far as they are concerned. Mrs Wingfield stated:
I have now been given the task of telling these men and women that with the reallocation of existing DILGEA-
that is, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs-
funds the class which holds out their last chance of self-sufficiency has been totally axed.
She poses this question to the Minister:
How can I break this devastating news to them?
Mrs Wingfield sent this letter to those of us who represent the Australian Capital Territory and to a number of others on whom she calls for help to assist in maintaining this program.

This Government boasts of being a caring government and of running programs for the benefit of people who need help. If an alternative program is to be put in place instead of the adult migrant English program, why is it that Mrs Wingfield does not know about it and is not able to tell those whom she teaches? How is it that a program that now has so little left in it cannot continue for the sale of those in that rehabilitation program? For those who have almost no English, what is the point of trying to rebuild their lives if they are not to have the opportunity to obtain these skills? These people have been working hard and they have not had the opportunity to attend English classes previously. They need that help now. I hope that this matter will be drawn to the Minister's attention and that the means of teaching these people English will be restored. I do not want to hear some argument about one program or another; it is a matter of a need which should be met within the rehabilitation system.

The other matter to which I wish to refer relates to the parking of motorcycles in the vicinity of this building. A group of staff wrote to Madam Speaker on 6 November 1987 and subsequently they followed up that letter with another dated 14 December 1987. Without going into great detail, I point out that in the new parking area there are no dedicated parking spaces for motorcycles. Motorcyclists either park illegally-some of them have run into difficulties with ACT parking inspectors as a consequence-or they take up a whole parking space for each motorbike. This matter should be able to be resolved quite readily. In fact, the staff suggests that no more than two, or perhaps three, motor car spaces would be sufficient for the number of motorcycles in the area. Mr President, it is a matter in which you may be able to give some assistance, or perhaps use your good offices with the relevant Minister to see that this quite silly problem is solved quickly. Perhaps one lunchtime we could go and paint in the motorcycle spaces ourselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Reid. I am aware of this problem and I have taken steps today-I hope-to alleviate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very quickly, I wish to pay a tribute to all the spouses of the people who work in this place for the fact that they have been waiting at home a lot because we sit late. I pay tribute to the wives of politicians who support their husbands and work behind the scenes to help them get into this place. I also wish to thank the spouses of the women who are in this place, either as politicians or as attendants and so on. All these people behind the scenes are never thanked. It is interesting to note that Senator Peter Baume, who is in the chamber at the moment, celebrates his twenty-ninth wedding anniversary today. I congratulate him on that because his spouse has obviously stayed behind him a long time in order to make sure that he got where he wanted.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to quote a little homily which I dedicate to those people behind the scenes who have done so much at different times for everyone who works here. This is an extract from an article entitled `That's country life' and it is subtitled `The 12 days of harvest', by Christina Hindhaugh. It is a tribute to the men who work on properties and perhaps the wives as well-I am not being sexist in saying this. The tribute goes like this:
On the first day of harvest, my true love said to me, with the kids home from school to help, he wouldn't need me.
On the second day of harvest, the kids all laughed in glee, because all the jobs around the house would now be up to me.

On the third day of harvest, my true love said to me: `Could you whip this sample over to the local silo for a moisture test, and while you're there, check it for protein content and find out if they're working on Sunday. Then, when you get back, could you dash out on the bike and check all the ewes, `cause we're too busy?''

On the fourth day of harvest, my true love said to me: ``About lunchtime we're moving to another paddock. Could you bring out the ute, fill up the diesel tank and hook it up behind? And don't forget to bring the toolbox the grease gun and the tin of spare bolts.''

On the sixth day of harvest, he called on the CB: ``The portable silos are both full and I can't get the truck unloaded! Could you bring the old tipper out to the far crop paddock fast as possible, but make sure the fuel, oil and water are okay?''

On the seventh day of harvest, my true love said to me: ``We've got a bit of damp wheat which we'll have to store in mesh bins! Could you have some new plastic liners delivered, then show the kids how to erect the bins down by the silo?''

On the eighth day of harvest, my true love said to me: ``This belt is badly frayed. Could you dash into town and pick up another as fast as you can? We need some more bearings as well. But please bring the lunches out to the paddock before you go, and this time for goodness sake don't forget the tea.''

On the ninth day of harvest, in a flat and wet gully, my true love got the truck and tractor bogged, so he called on the CB: ``Get the old David Brown out of the shed! Find the drag chain! Drive on out here to the paddock as fast as you can and pull us out!''
On the tenth day of harvest, my true love snapped at me, as I stood by the header handing his tools up to him, very nervously.

On the eleventh day of harvest, my true love roared at me: ``Could you auger out the next load of wheat while we eat, then fill the header with diesel, then dash home and get two tarps and re-fill the water bottles `cause it's stinking hot out here when you're working?''
On the last day of harvest, my true loved grinned at me: ``If all goes well, we'll finish about five. Aren't you glad this year we didn't need your help, hon-ey?''

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to the artistic comments of Senator Brownhill by commenting on the annual report of the Australia Council, which, of course, looks after a much wider cultural field in Australia. In particular, I draw the attention of honourable senators to that part of the report that relates to the Aboriginal Arts Board. I believe some areas of that report highlight some very fundamental problems at the moment of direction in a number of areas of Aboriginal policy and our relationships with Aboriginals in Australia. Obviously, the Aboriginal Arts Board sees its role as very diverse, and I commend it for that. But I do not believe it goes far enough in drawing the distinction between the arts of the tribally oriented Aboriginals in Australia and those of the Aboriginals who are much more urbanised and settled in a traditional Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Arts Board is very unfair in the way it distributes its funds with its stated objectives. For example, if we are talking about arts as they relate to Aboriginal culture, the top and priority program ought to be the total preservation of traditional Aboriginal culture. I draw the Senate's attention to the activities over the past 17 years of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation Inc., which is a body that has enjoyed very wide support and is the only national organisation totally owned and controlled by tribal Aborigines. The problems that I see arising from the Aboriginal Arts Board are that it is dominated in its membership by Aboriginals who are urbanised and part Aboriginal in descent and does not have an adequate simpatico with the full cultural Aboriginals. If one looks at the Budgets for the past three years and the allocation of funds to the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, one sees that its funds have in effect been slashed by some 50 per cent. Of course, this threatens the very existence, and the continued existence, of the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, which is very significant, particularly to the ceremony leaders, and the Aboriginal practitioners in the Northern Territory and in the tribal areas of Queensland, Western Australia and parts of South Australia.

We need to look at this report very closely together with the proposals that are currently being mooted by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, in a document that he tabled in the House of Representatives last week entitled Foundations for the Future, which the Government has not yet had the guts to table in this place. Obviously, it is leaving it until the last day of the sitting of the Senate to avoid an open debate on that issue. If we look at Mr Hand's report, we will see that many of the weaknesses in the direction that he is taking relate to the fact that insufficient attention is given to tribal Aboriginals as opposed to the other members of the Australian community who are of part Aboriginal descent. We need to be very careful in looking at how all of these matters are put together.

The proposals to which the Government will turn its attention in 1988, after Australia Day-because it does not want any decent consultation with the non-Aboriginal community in the meantime-need to be very carefully watched because of the implications of groups such as the Aboriginal Arts Board that are not giving adequate priority and recognition. I believe that many of the problems that are arising from that Board are inherent in the proposals that Mr Hand has flagged, and therefore require very careful consideration.

We need to ask very serious questions, such as what tribal representation is proposed on the various boards of the new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and its subordinate bodies, and what tribal representation there is on the Aboriginal Arts Board, which slashes funding to traditional, cultural, ceremonial Aboriginals in such a heartless manner. When we look at future Budgets, how can we be sure that there will be a continuation of funding that recognises programs that have already been set in place? The report of the Australia Council lists all of the grants that have been made for the current year, but gives no comparisons, as is normal in Government budgeting and estimating, with the previous year. One tends to overlook a body such as the Aboriginal Cultural Foundation, whose budget has been slashed from $286,000 in 1985 to $180,000 in 1987.

Similarly, if the Minister is proposing a number of new bodies that will have wide and embracing effects on ceremonial, cultural Aboriginals, I believe we need to be sure that there is adequate protection in all of the new programs that will eventuate, that they will be fully accountable to parliamentary scrutiny, and that the appointments to the various boards properly reflect true Aboriginal heritage and the priorities that need to be given to those communities.

The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it true that Australian produced powdered milk is, or has been, shipped in bulk to Singapore, and then mixed with powdered milk from other countries, before being tinned and shipped to Bangladesh.

(2) Is it possible that Australian milk powder could have been mixed with milk powder from European countries with high radiation levels originating from the Chernobyl nuclear disaster; if so, does the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy accept that by not permitting a nuclear industry on Australian soil, there would be a definite commercial advantage to the value of Australian products on the international market.
(3) To what extent did New Zealand's overseas exports increase in quantity and quality as a result of the effects on primary production in Europe of the Chernobyl nuclear disaster.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Reports from both local and overseas sources indicate that Australian milk powder has been shipped in bulk to Singapore and repacked and shipped to Bangladesh from there. The jurisdiction of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service in export control extends only to point of export from Australia, and the question of whether or not Australian milk powder is being mixed with product of other countries in Singapore, for export to Bangladesh, is appropriately a matter for the authorities in those two countries. However, in response to allegations in March that Australian milk powder had been mixed with radioactive product from Europe, four representative samples of product labelled ``Made in Australia'' were obtained from Bangladesh for testing. Results showed no detectable levels of radioactivity.

The Chernobyl nuclear disaster appears to have affected the demand for and marketing of some agricultural products from areas where the effects of the Chernobyl accident have been detected. Although it would be difficult to quantify because of other parallel factors affecting supply and demand for agricultural commodities, exporters unaffected by the Chernobyl accident may have benefited. Such benefits would have arisen from the absence of the effects of Chernobyl, not from the absence of any nuclear industry in the exporting countries.

(3) It is not possible to provide any estimates of the effect, if any, of increases in quantitative or qualitative terms on New Zealand's exports of milk powders as a result of the Chernobyl accident.
